Bridging Industrial Expertise and XR with LLM-Powered Conversational Agents

Author: Tomkou, Despina1; Fatouros, George1; Andreou, Andreas2; Makridis, Georgios3; Liarokapis, Fotis2; Dardanis, Dimitrios3; Kiourtis, Athanasios3; Soldatos, John1; Kyriazis, Dimosthenis31 Innov-Acts Ltd.,,Nicosia,Cyprus2 CYENS Centre of Excellence,Nicosia,Cyprus3 University of Piraeus,Piraeus,Greece

Publication info: Tomkou, Despina; Fatouros, George; Andreou, Andreas; Makridis, Georgios; Liarokapis, Fotis; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/bridging-industrial-expertise-xr-with-llm-powered/docview/3246330666/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 21st International Conference on Distributed Computing in Smart Systems and the Internet of Things (DCOSS-IoT) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 9 Conference End Date: 2025 June 11 Conference Location: Lucca, Italy This paper introduces a novel integration of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) enhanced Large Language Models (LLMs) with Extended Reality (XR) technologies to address knowledge transfer challenges in industrial environments. The proposed system embeds domain-specific industrial knowledge into XR environments through a natural language interface, enabling hands-free, context-aware expert guidance for workers. We present the architecture of the proposed system consisting of an LLM Chat Engine with dynamic tool orchestration and an XR application featuring voice-driven interaction. Performance evaluation of various chunking strategies, embedding models, and vector databases reveals that semantic chunking, balanced embedding models, and efficient vector stores deliver optimal performance for industrial knowledge retrieval. The system's potential is demonstrated through early implementation in multiple industrial use cases, including robotic assembly, smart infrastructure maintenance, and aerospace component servicing. Results indicate potential for enhancing training efficiency, remote assistance capabilities, and operational guidance in alignment with Industry 5.0's human-centric and resilient approach to industrial development.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Despina&amp;aulast=Tomkou&amp;atitle=Bridging+Industrial+Expertise+and+XR+with+LLM-Powered+Conversational+Agents&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FDCOSS-IoT65416.2025.00158&amp;title=Bridging+Industrial+Expertise+and+XR+with+LLM-Powered+Conversational+Agents&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=1050&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

From Creation to Diffusion to Application: The Evolution of AI Innovations From a Dynamic Network Perspective

Author: Gao, Kaige

Publication info: Gao, Kaige. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/creation-diffusion-application-evolution-ai/docview/3245782655/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is reshaping global economies, yet we lack a holistic understanding of how AI innovations evolve across interconnected communities. This dissertation examines how interactions among heterogeneous actors and artifacts across open-source communities, academic fields, and commercial industries influence AI innovation's creation, diffusion, and application. Unlike previous research focusing on isolated breakthroughs, this study provides a comprehensive view of AI's evolutionary trajectory through a dynamic network perspective. The first introduces "network variability" as a novel construct to analyze how open-source collaboration networks adapt to changing environments, revealing that meaningful structural reconfigurations significantly enhance project development outcomes under increasing complexity. The second study examines how open-source AI models function as boundary objects bridging developer and academic communities, demonstrating that model network positioning influences scholarly impact through complex temporal patterns. The third study investigates cross-boundary knowledge transfer to industry contexts, analyzing how AI knowledge integration strategies affect patent generation and firm valuation in autonomous vehicles, revealing that exploration-oriented approaches yield greater market value than exploitation strategies. These findings establish AI innovation as a networked phenomenon with distinctive evolutionary dynamics that differ from traditional technologies, characterized by complex feedback loops across multiple interacting communities rather than a linear progression.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Kaige&amp;aulast=Gao&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=From+Creation+to+Diffusion+to+Application%3A+The+Evolution+of+AI+Innovations+From+a+Dynamic+Network+Perspective&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798291598122&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

Workforce Management Strategies for a Multigenerational Workforce: Challenges and Difficulties of an Aging Workforce

Author: Bartels, Michael Edward

Publication info: Bartels, Michael Edward. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/workforce-management-strategies-multigenerational/docview/3232358784/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The problem addressed in the study was that many organizations struggled with workforce generational differences as four generations coexisted in the labor force and Baby Boomers were leaving the workforce at an estimated four million a year leaving an ill-prepared workforce to handle the loss of institutional knowledge thus necessitating the need for multigenerational workforce management strategies. As a result, managers, supervisors, and organizations face challenges in continuing business as usual and merging diverse generational perspectives. The purpose of this qualitative single case study was to examine workforce generational differences, challenges posed by Baby Boomers leaving the workforce, and effective multigenerational workforce management strategies to address institutional knowledge loss. The study followed the Generational Cohort Theory, which helped explain how generational experiences play a role in shaping what happens in the workplace. This qualitative single-case study employed semi-structured interviews and demographic questionnaires with 20 participants aged 18 to 69 years from a traffic management company in northeast Oklahoma. Participants represented Baby Boomers, Generation X, Generation Y, and Generation Z cohorts. The analysis of data followed thematic coding guided by NVivo and Braun and Clarke’s step-by-step approach. Trustworthiness was established through triangulation, member checking, peer debriefing, and reflexive journaling. The results indicated that individuals from different generations communicated differently, used technology differently, and had differing work values and learning approaches. Baby Boomers preferred face-to-face communication, whereas digital communication was preferred by the younger generations. Key challenges included knowledge transfer barriers, differences in communication, and motivational factors. Successful management practices involved open communication structures, strength-based management approaches, mixed-generation teams, adaptive training methods, and formal mentoring programs. The study concludes that organizations must develop comprehensive, intentional management approaches, viewing generational diversity as a strategic advantage rather than a challenge. Among the recommendations included setting up knowledge-sharing programs, nurturing intelligence across ages among top managers, and encouraging environments that allow different age groups to contribute their ideas, leading to improved performance and creativity in organizations.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Michael&amp;aulast=Bartels&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Workforce+Management+Strategies+for+a+Multigenerational+Workforce%3A+Challenges+and+Difficulties+of+an+Aging+Workforce&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798288859717&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Michael&amp;aulast=Bartels&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Workforce+Management+Strategies+for+a+Multigenerational+Workforce%3A+Challenges+and+Difficulties+of+an+Aging+Workforce&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798288859717&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

Research on the Online Update Method for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) Model with Incremental Learning

Author: Fan, Yuxin1; Wang, Yuxiang2; Liu, Lipeng3; Tang, Xirui4; Sun, Na5; Yu, Zidong61 School of Engineering and Applied Science, University of Pe nnsylvania,Toronto,Canada2 School of Business, Stevens Institute of Technology,New York,USA3 College of Engineering, Peking University,Beijing,China4 College of Computer Sciences, Northeastern University,Boston,USA5 Independent Researcher,Newark,USA6 Syracuse University, College of Engineering and Computer Science,San Jose,USA

Publication info: Fan, Yuxin; Wang, Yuxiang; Liu, Lipeng; Tang, Xirui; Sun, Na; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/research-on-online-update-method-retrieval/docview/3230555676/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 5th International Conference on Neural Networks, Information and Communication Engineering (NNICE) Conference Start Date: 2025 Jan. 10 Conference End Date: 2025 Jan. 12 Conference Location: Guangzhou, China In the contemporary context of rapid advancements in information technology and the exponential growth of data volume, language models are confronted with significant challenges in effectively navigating the dynamic and ever-evolving information landscape to update and adapt to novel knowledge in real time. In this work, an online update method is proposed, which is based on the existing Retrieval Enhanced Generation (RAG) model with multiple innovation mechanisms. Firstly, the dynamic memory is used to capture the emerging data samples, and then gradually integrate them into the core model through a tunable knowledge distillation strategy. At the same time, hierarchical indexing and multi-layer gating mechanism are introduced into the retrieval module to ensure that the retrieved content is more targeted and accurate. Finally, a multi-stage network structure is established for different types of inputs in the generation stage, and cross-attention matching and screening are carried out on the intermediate representations of each stage to ensure the effective integration and iterative update of new and old knowledge. Experimental results show that the proposed method is better than the existing mainstream comparison models in terms of knowledge retention and inference accuracy.
