AI-EDGE: An NSF AI institute for future edge networks and distributed intelligence

Author: Ju, Peizhong1; Li, Chengzhang1; Liang, Yingbin1; Shroff, Ness11 Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio, USA

Publication info: Ju, Peizhong; Li, Chengzhang; Liang, Yingbin; Shroff, Ness. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/ai-edge-nsf-institute-future-networks-distributed/docview/3090976246/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This paper highlights the overall endeavors of the NSF AI Institute for Future Edge Networks and Distributed Intelligence (AI-EDGE) to create a research, education, knowledge transfer, and workforce development environment for developing technological leadership in next-generation edge networks (6G and beyond) and artificial intelligence (AI). The research objectives of AI-EDGE are twofold: "AI for Networks" and "Networks for AI." The former develops new foundational AI techniques to revolutionize technologies for next-generation edge networks, while the latter develops advanced networking techniques to enhance distributed and interconnected AI capabilities at edge devices. These research investigations are conducted across eight symbiotic thrust areas that work together to address the main challenges towards those goals. Such a synergistic approach ensures a virtuous research cycle so that advances in one area will accelerate advances in the other, thereby paving the way for a new generation of networks that are not only intelligent but also efficient, secure, self-healing, and capable of solving large-scale distributed AI challenges. This paper also outlines the institute's endeavors in education and workforce development, as well as broadening participation and enforcing collaboration.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Peizhong&amp;aulast=Ju&amp;atitle=AI-EDGE%3A+An+NSF+AI+institute+for+future+edge+networks+and+distributed+intelligence&amp;stitle=AI+Magazine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Faaai.12145&amp;title=AI-EDGE%3A+An+NSF+AI+institute+for+future+edge+networks+and+distributed+intelligence&amp;volume=45&amp;issue=1&amp;date=Spring+2024&amp;spage=29&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Peizhong&amp;aulast=Ju&amp;atitle=AI-EDGE%3A+An+NSF+AI+institute+for+future+edge+networks+and+distributed+intelligence&amp;stitle=AI+Magazine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Faaai.12145&amp;title=AI-EDGE%3A+An+NSF+AI+institute+for+future+edge+networks+and+distributed+intelligence&amp;volume=45&amp;issue=1&amp;date=Spring+2024&amp;spage=29&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Full text: Headnote Abstract
This paper highlights the overall endeavors of the NSF AI Institute for Future Edge Networks and Distributed Intelligence (AI-EDGE) to create a research, education, knowledge transfer, and workforce development environment for developing technological leadership in next-generation edge networks (6G and beyond) and artificial intelligence (AI). The research objectives of AI-EDGE are twofold: "AI for Networks" and "Networks for AI." The former develops new foundational AI techniques to revolutionize technologies for next-generation edge networks, while the latter develops advanced networking techniques to enhance distributed and interconnected AI capabilities at edge devices. These research investigations are conducted across eight symbiotic thrust areas that work together to address the main challenges towards those goals. Such a synergistic approach ensures a virtuous research cycle so that advances in one area will accelerate advances in the other, thereby paving the way for a new generation of networks that are not only intelligent but also efficient, secure, self-healing, and capable of solving large-scale distributed AI challenges. This paper also outlines the institute's endeavors in education and workforce development, as well as broadening participation and enforcing collaboration.
INTRODUCTION
The recent breakthroughs of AI and Machine Learning (ML) as well as their successful applications in a broad range of domains provide a unique opportunity for designing Al-driven next-generation networks that are "intelligent" in many different ways. The NSF AI Institute for Future Edge Networks and Distributed Intelligence (AI-EDGE) was established to fully explore the power of AI to revolutionize next-generation edge networks. AI-EDGE will develop new foundational AI tools for designing next generation intelligent edge networks (6G and beyond), and enabling true distributed intelligence. Our objective is to cultivate an environment that will not only foster innovation in cutting-edge technologies but also prepare a new wave of professionals equipped to navigate this rapidly evolving landscape.
To address the above mentioned challenges, the institute is made of a strong, diverse, and growing consortia of research leaders from university, industry, and government labs that will work collaboratively to realize the overall vision of designing next generation edge networks and distributed intelligence (AI-EDGE 2023).
The overarching mission of the institute's research is to design next-generation hyper-scalable, heterogeneous and dynamic networks that are highly efficient, reliable, robust, and secure. New AI tools and techniques will be developed to ensure that these networks are self-healing and self-optimized. These networks will in turn be designed to unleash the power of collaboration to help solve long-standing distributed AI challenges, making AI more efficient, interactive, and privacy-preserving. Applications and practical use cases at experimental scale are the pillars (Figure 1) that will be built on and will interact with this foundation in a virtuous cycle to deepen our understanding and magnify the impact of our work. Use Case 1 is built around sensing and re-engineering the wireless network environment. Use Case 2 is built around extreme mobility applications where machines, humans, and in some cases network elements could be in motion at the same time. Use Case 3 focuses on the development of programmable and virtualized edge networks. Looking to the future, our institute will develop the key underlying technologies for distributed and networked intelligence that will have an impact on future transformative applications well-beyond the institute's funded years.
The success of the institute will be measured on several fronts. On the research front, success will be measured by the development of (i) a new intelligence plane for designing next generation edge networks, (ii) how that plane will be used to enable distributed AI, and (iii) the integration of the research tasks to successfully implement the three key use cases identified by the institute. Success in education and workforce development will be measured by the impact on AI-EDGE in helping to build a large and diverse workforce in AI and networks.
The research is currently conducted across eight interrelated thrust areas under two main themes: AI for Networks and Networks for AI, as shown in Figure 1.
Alfor Networks: While preliminary successes of AI for Networks have been promising, developing ML tools to networking with minimal or no human oversight poses many important research challenges that need to be explored. In Thrust , we re-engineer the physical fabric for 6G and beyond (6G+) wireless communications through AI, thus treating the fabric itself as a controllable entity. In Thrust , we develop new AI techniques for the design and control of these next-generation networks taking into account practical resource constraints. In Thrust , we further generalize these techniques to allow for multi-agent, possibly noncooperative, network entities. In Thrust , we develop AI methods to secure the network edge.
Networks for AI: The vision of distributed intelligence requires capabilities beyond today's AI algorithms. The research foundation here starts with Thrust , where distributed AI adapts its operation seamlessly by taking into account computation, communication, and data constraints. In Thrust , we go further by aiming to re-engineer the networks themselves to better serve the needs of distributed AI operations. In Thrust , we investigate collaborative (human + machine) analysis of data produced by our application drivers, which will be far more effective than with either humans or machines in isolation. In Thrust , we design and control the network such that it is privacy-aware and can be optimized to facilitate protection from information leakage and attacks.
In the rest of this paper, we will provide a sampling of the institute's recent representative work along the above two main themes. Additionally, we will outline the institute's endeavors in education and workforce development, as well as broadening participation (BP) and enforcing collaboration. More details can be found on the institute webpage (AI-EDGE 2023).
RESEARCH THEMES OF AI FOR NETWORKS
The growth of edge networks in scale and complexity implies that intelligent and autonomous design becomes paramount. We describe below in detail two key learning areas that the institute has been exploring that will have a demonstrable impact on edge network design and control: (i) reinforcement learning and (ii) meta learning and active learning.
Reinforcement learning (RL) empowered edge network control
RL is a major AI paradigm in which an online learner interacts with an unknown environment sequentially in order to achieve a large expected cumulative reward. Such a mathematical framework precisely captures how edge networks acquire, process, and communicate data, and hence can play a vital role in designing data-driven network resource allocation and control mechanisms. AI-EDGE has made a number of fundamental contributions to reinforcement learning with a primary focus on addressing challenging issues that practical edge networks encounter, including various constraints such as resource and safety constraints and switching cost, partial observability, model misspecification, and so forth.
Edge devices are generally subject to resource constraints such as power, computation, and memory constraints. Their data processing can be modeled as constrained Markov decision processes (CMDPs). AI-EDGE researchers have developed several innovative algorithms to handle such constraints while maintaining the best possible performance. For example, Wei, Liu, and Ying (2022) developed model-free RL algorithms with optimal regret and constraint violation guarantees. Ghosh, Zhou, and Shroff (2022) further expanded our exploration to larger, potentially infinite, state spaces via a new model-free constrained RL algorithm that also enjoys near-optimal performance bounds. These novel algorithms exhibit significant performance improvements in comparison to existing solutions, especially in edge networks with latency and energy constraints.
Unlike energy constraints which are typically cumulative over time, safety and power constraints are instantaneous at each step/time. For example, in autonomous driving, improper operations at any time can cause catastrophic consequences such as crashing of a car. Thus, such safety-critical systems need to avoid violation of safety constraints at each time instance. It is highly challenging because the safety at each step should both depend on history steps due to the system evolution and predict the impact on future steps. Recently, we made a fundamental breakthrough in Shi, Liang, and Shroff (2023) to address such a challenge, where we constructed novel safe subgraphs to design safe exploration and planning, and showed that our approach achieves a regret that nearly matches the state-of-the-art regret in the unsafe-action setting and that in the unconstrained setting.
Meta-learning for autonomous transportation
Meta-learning is a powerful learning technique to reduce sample requirement for learning tasks while still maintaining the desired performance. AI-EDGE researchers have made several significant contributions to these learning methodologies and have further demonstrated their successful applications in multimodal fusion design for beamforming over autonomous vehicles.
Autonomous vehicles typically move in dynamic conditions, and thus a car may encounter new environments that were not explicitly included in an apriori training dataset. A major challenge here is that a single pre-trained model is unable to generalize well. We approached such a problem by leveraging a popular meta-learning framework of model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML), for which we first made several innovative contributions, including characterizing the optimization performance (Ji, Yang, and Liang 2021), understanding the statistical convergence guarantee (Collins et al. 2022), and characterizing the generalization performance in the overparameterized regime (Ju, Liang, and Shroff 2023). Equipped with these powerful tools, we further demonstrated the advantages of MAML over traditional deep-learning techniques wherein a model retrained in the unseen test environment (i) uses a fraction of the data compared to classical retraining, which, in turn, simplifies data collection and storage, and (ii) results in equal or higher accuracy in optimal beam selection compared to the case when the new environment dataset is fully available during initial training. Our results in Gu, Collins et al. (2023) reveal that our MAML implementation on camera images for the objective of beam selection improves test accuracy by up to 86% with fine-tuning when encountering an unseen non-line-of-sight (NLOS) environment compared to conventional supervised learning. We are currently comparing MAML-based approaches with traditional transfer learning, using initial results in our earlier work (Gu, Salehi, et al. 2023).
RESEARCH THEMES OF NETWORKS FOR Al
Future Al problems will be at large scale, for which federated learning (FL) implemented over edge networks is a powerful paradigm to decentralize the computation, protect data privacy, and offer maximum design flexibility. To this end, we have made substantial efforts in designing innovative network-aware FL algorithms that address various challenges of edge networks such as node heterogeneity, communication constraints, unequal client participation, uncertainty of wireless communication medium, and so forth. We also investigated more complex Al problems, decentralizing which requires further novel designs. Below, we discuss in more detail about our work along these directions.
Network-aware federated learning (FL)
Nodes in edge networks typically have different computational capabilities, quality of datasets, and levels of participation. Hence, we have extensively addressed these types of network heterogeneity and proposed new FL algorithms that are communication-efficient, personalized, straggler-resilient, and privacy-preserving.
As one such work, we studied model heterogeneous FL for classification where different clients have different model architectures (Regatti et al. 2022). Unlike existing works on model heterogeneity, we do not require access to a public dataset, nor do we impose constraints on the model architecture of clients. We also ensure that the clients' model architectures and data are private. We developed a communication-efficient algorithm with provable convergence and generalization properties that aligns conditional distributions of each client in the feature space and achieves a consensus on the final layer classification weights.
We also proposed a novel straggler-resilient FL method that incorporates statistical characteristics of clients' data to adaptively select the clients in order to speed up the learning procedure (Reisizadeh et al. 2022). The key idea is to start the training with faster nodes and gradually involve slower nodes once the statistical accuracy of the data corresponding to the current participating nodes is reached. The proposed approach reduces the overall runtime (theoretically and via numerical evaluation) required to achieve the statistical accuracy of data of all nodes, as the solution for each stage is close to the solution of the subsequent stage with more samples and can be used as a warm-start.
Federated learning with diverse structures
AI problems can have diverse structures in order to capture various practical domains, encompassing the basic risk minimization problem such as supervised learning, the minimax problem such as robust adversarial training and generative adversarial networks, and the bilevel problem that captures meta-learning, hyperparameter optimization, neural architecture search, and so forth. Building on our work on decentralizing the basic minimization as discussed in the preceding subsection, we have recently pioneered the research on FL into the much wider scope of minimax and bilevel problems while still addressing network constraints and heterogeneity.
More specifically, we recently proposed a general federated minimax optimization framework (Sharma, Panda, and Joshi 2023), that accounts for heterogeneity across clients and subsumes several existing methods like local stochastic gradient descent-ascent (SGDA). To fix this mismatch caused by heterogeneity, we proposed normalizing the client updates by the number of local steps undertaken between successive communication rounds. Our algorithms showed significant improvements over existing computation and communication complexity results.
EDUCATION AND BROADENING PARTICIPATION
There is a tremendous demand for Al-related skills not only in computer science and engineering, but also across many disciplines, from agriculture and manufacturing to business and entertainment. Further, the growth of future-generation wireless edge networks will require a large workforce with expertise in wireless networking and communications, security, and privacy. Thus, it is a priority to educate students, professionals, and practitioners in AI and networks and substantially grow and diversify the workforce. Since it was founded, AI-EDGE has made significant progress in educating undergraduate and graduate students, practitioners, and professionals, and expanding our reach to under-represented communities. Some highlights are provided below.
AI-EDGE team members received a major grant for establishing and growing the workforce needed to expand 5G and broadband access in Ohio 5G-Ohio website (2023) This has led to synergistic work between AI-EDGE and the 5G-OH Broadband and 5G Connectivity Center to establish BS specialization and Professional MS programs at OSU.
AI-EDGE has developed an educational repository for AI and networks, where the course contents have been partitioned into self-contained modules covering different topics, each with student notes, lecturer notes, and appropriate paper reading assignments. The course repository also includes bridge projects to integrate learning across AI and the networks, personalized curriculum for individual students and professionals, and professional MS programs via "stackable certificates" with modular contents from across universities.
Further, AI-EDGE consistently provides industrial experience and training opportunities for students and post-docs. We currently have multiple ongoing collaborations, where PhD students and postdocs work with scientists and engineers across several industries.
To facilitate synergistic research interactions and expand our students' scope of knowledge, the institute hosts a highly successful regular online seminar series that feature research talks and tutorials given by students, faculty, and postdocs of the institute, as well as world-leading researchers in networking and AI. Recordings of the talks are maintained on the institute's website for easy access. We also organize regular institute-wide meetings, during which the students and postdocs are given opportunities to present lightning talks and posters about their research outcomes, which significantly encouraged their engagement in this multidisciplinary research program.
Inclusivity and BP are cornerstones of AI-EDGE's ethos. We continually keep this focus at the forefront of our institute's activities. We next summarize three key BP activities and efforts that we have made during the initial 2 years of AI-EDGE's establishment.
Building a large diverse workforce: AI-EDGE has partnered with another OSU-AFRL led large-MSI consortium to develop a community of under-represented engineers and scientists and provide them with opportunities to develop science, technology, and leadership skills. By leveraging this consortium, AI-EDGE has recruited undergraduate students from under-represented groups (URGs) and run two 8-week summer programs during which the students work with their mentors who are faculty and post-docs/graduate students at AI-EDGE. The research projects that students can select cover a broad range of topics in ML, networking, and security.
Women in AI program: The institute has launched an institute-wide virtual "Women in AI program" participated by all female faculty, students, and postdocs as well as other institute's members. The program events are organized by a student committee and monitored by the BP committee. The institute has organized several networking events with different themes for women students and postdocs, including research highlight presentations, panel discussions on topics of interest such as the process of academic job search, work-life balance, and strategies for a successful career, and more.
Community outreach and engagement: AI-EDGE faculty members have given several interviews to local and international news organizations, at libraries, and keynotes/invited talks on the importance of AI and networking technologies. Our faculty, students, and postdocs across the institute have actively participated in various outreach events for high-school and undergraduate students and teamed up to give tutorials at various high-school summer camps.
CONCLUSION
In this paper, we have introduced the AI-EDGE institute, which seeks to build on the synergies between AI/ML and networking to develop intelligent next-generation edge networks and distributed AI. We have provided an overview of the institute's key focus areas and summarized some of our exciting research advancements on various learning methods (such as RL and FL) and their applications. We have also highlighted some main AI-EDGE endeavors in education, workforce development, and BP.
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS The AI Institute is primarily funded by the NSF and DHS through NSF grant 2112471. The Institute has also received additional supplements for NSF 2225561 for extending the work of the institute. CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT The authors declare that there is no conflict. AUTHOR BIOGRAPHIES
Peizhong Ju received his B.S. degree in Electrical Engineering from Peking University, Beijing, China, in 201, and Ph.D. degree in Electrical and Computer Engineering from Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, USA, in 2021. He is currently a Postdoc Researcher at the ECE Department at The Ohio State University and is also affiliated to AI-EDGE Institute. His current research interests are about analyzing the performance of various machine-learning models and designing new machine-learning algorithms for multi-agent systems.
Chengzhang Li received the B.S. degree in Electronics Engineering from Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, in 201, and the M.S. and Ph.D degrees in Computer Engineering from Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, VA, USA, in 2020 and 202, respectively. He is currently a Postdoc Researcher at the AI-EDGE Institute, The Ohio State University. His current research interests are machine learning in edge networks, real-time scheduling in 5G, and Age of Information (Aol).
Yingbin Liang received the Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 2005. She is currently a Professor with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, The Ohio State University (OSU), and a core Faculty Member of the Translational Data Analytics Institute (TDAI), OSU. Currently, she is also serving as the Deputy Director for the AI-Edge Institute, OSU. Before she joined OSU, she served on the Faculty of the University of Hawaii and Syracuse University. Her research interests include machine learning, optimization, information theory, and statistical
signal processing. She received the National Science Foundation CAREER Award and the State of Hawaii Governor Innovation Award in 2009. She also received the EURASIP Best Paper Award in 2014.
Ness B. Shroff received the Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering from Columbia University, New York, NY, USA, in 1994. He joined Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, USA, immediately thereafter as an Assistant Professor with the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering. At Purdue, he became a Full Professor of ECE and the Director of a University-Wide Center on Wireless Systems and Applications in 2004. In 200, he joined The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA, where he holds the Ohio Eminent Scholar Endowed Chair in networking and communications, with the Departments of ECE and CSE. He is currently the Institute Director of the NSF AI Institute for Future Edge Networks and Distributed Intelligence. He holds or has held Visiting (chaired) Professor positions with Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai, China, and the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mum-bai, India. He was the recipient of numerous best paper awards for his research and is listed in Thomson Reuters' on The World's Most Influential Scientific Minds, and has been noted as a Highly Cited Researcher by Thomson Reuters in 2014 and 2015. He is currently the Steering Committee Chair for ACM Mobihoc and was Editor in Chief of the IEEE/ACM TRANSACTIONS ON NETWORKING. He also was the recipient of the IEEE INFOCOM Achievement Award for seminal contributions to scheduling and resource allocation in wireless networks.

Gamification in Learning and Development: A Qualitative Study on the Indian Mining Sector

Author: Sharma, Aprajita1; Pandey, Saumya1; Singh, Sharda2; Ghatak, Indrani21 Management Student, Human Resource Management Program, Xavier Institute of Social Service, Ranchi, Jharkhand, India2 Assistant Professor, Human Resource Management Program, Xavier Institute of Social Service, Ranchi, Jharkhand, India

Publication info: Sharma, Aprajita; Pandey, Saumya; Singh, Sharda; Ghatak, Indrani. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/gamification-learning-development-qualitative/docview/3062726349/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: In the dynamic volatile, uncertain, complex, ambiguous (VUCA) landscape, industries like metals and mining face a pressing challenge of skill scarcity due to the struggle to keep up with technological advancements. To revitalize their workforce and appeal to younger generations, integrating gamification into learning and development approaches holds immense potential. Employee motivation and knowledge retention can be elevated by infusing game mechanics such as badges, points, and leaderboards. Gamification fosters engagement, teamwork, and innovation through interactive experiences. This approach can effectively address the skill shortage by enhancing the industry's attractiveness and competitiveness. The paper aims to investigate the skill deficit in the metals and mining sector and explore how gamified learning methods can effectively alleviate this challenge, ultimately aiding in talent acquisition and retention. The study used purposive sampling, and data was gathered through semi-structured interviews with primary stakeholders of learning and development functions. Further, the qualitative data was subjected to thematic analysis using NVivo software. Two significant themes, from eight sub-themes that emerged from thirty codes, were identified. The first theme was issues with the young generation, and the second was the benefits of gamification in learning and development. The study suggests the need for and advantage of gamification in human resource management's learning and development function.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Aprajita&amp;aulast=Sharma&amp;atitle=Gamification+in+Learning+and+Development%3A+A+Qualitative+Study+on+the+Indian+Mining+Sector&amp;stitle=IUP+Journal+of+Organizational+Behavior&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Gamification+in+Learning+and+Development%3A+A+Qualitative+Study+on+the+Indian+Mining+Sector&amp;volume=23&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=51&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Aprajita&amp;aulast=Sharma&amp;atitle=Gamification+in+Learning+and+Development%3A+A+Qualitative+Study+on+the+Indian+Mining+Sector&amp;stitle=IUP+Journal+of+Organizational+Behavior&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Gamification+in+Learning+and+Development%3A+A+Qualitative+Study+on+the+Indian+Mining+Sector&amp;volume=23&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=51&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Full text: Headnote In the dynamic volatile, uncertain, complex, ambiguous (VUCA) landscape, industries like metals and mining face a pressing challenge of skill scarcity due to the struggle to keep up with technological advancements. To revitalize their workforce and appeal to younger generations, integrating gamification into learning and development approaches holds immense potential. Employee motivation and knowledge retention can be elevated by infusing game mechanics such as badges, points, and leaderboards. Gamification fosters engagement, teamwork, and innovation through interactive experiences. This approach can effectively address the skill shortage by enhancing the industry's attractiveness and competitiveness. The paper aims to investigate the skill deficit in the metals and mining sector and explore how gamified learning methods can effectively alleviate this challenge, ultimately aiding in talent acquisition and retention. The study used purposive sampling, and data was gathered through semi-structured interviews with primary stakeholders of learning and development functions. Further, the qualitative data was subjected to thematic analysis using NVivo software. Two significant themes, from eight sub-themes that emerged from thirty codes, were identified. The first theme was issues with the young generation, and the second was the benefits of gamification in learning and development. The study suggests the need for and advantage of gamification in human resource management's learning and development function.
Introduction
There is a shortage of skills and talent in the metal and mining industry. Paucity of qualified and experienced professionals is undeniably a global issue. Around 73% of the companies identified skills gaps in the local labor market as the biggest barrier to the adoption of new technology (ICMM, 2021). The challenges metal and mining companies face in attracting and retaining talent are certainly exacerbated by the industry's perception of them as unattractive and slow to respond to rapid technological changes (Chikatamaria and Prasad, 2019). The metal and mining industry has been through a significant technological transformation. These continuous innovations and technological changes make it more challenging to draw and hold young talented professionals in any sector that is unfashionable to younger generations, perceived as damaging to the environment, and requires hard physical work (Mateus and Martins, 2019).
According to a study conducted by McKinsey and Company (Abenov et al., 2023), 71% of metal and mining leaders find that due to the immense shortage of talented professionals in the company, there is a grievous impact on production targets. It is obstructing the planned objectives of the company as well. Recruiting and retaining talented people in specific fields, such as mining, metallurgy, and process engineering, is more complex than others. According to recent data from Minerals Tertiary Education Council: Key Performance Measures Report 2018, there has been a significant 63% decline in the enrolment ratio for Mining Engineering in Australia since 2014, and a notable 39% decline in courses like mining graduating in the US since 2016. The data demonstrates that the mining and metals industries do not attract young technical experts.
It is extremely disappointing that there is an unprecedented shortage of skills in the metal and mining industry, which will undoubtedly negatively impact the sector's overall productivity and growth. The metal and mining industry has a complete dearth of motivated and trained workforce. Chikatamaria and Prasad (2019) suggested that mining businesses must embrace business risk management practices and integrate change management with developing digital technology to maintain operational sustainability and transparency. The authors also highlighted that one of the major issues in mining industry in India is lack of skill/competent labor. Emerging digital technologies should be incorporated into the training of the next generation of mining professionals to facilitate real-time data collecting, better data analysis, reporting, and process monitoring.
Digital transformation makes businesses more flexible and competitive. There is an urgent need to nurture a learning-friendly culture by introducing different strategies to enhance innovative minds. This learning culture will accelerate the organization's sustainability in digital transformation, raising employee wellbeing and retention (Jain, 2022).
Gamification is one of the most effective and engaging transformations for learning and development. It is a concerted effort to apply different game mechanisms in working environment gaming designs to increase collaborative participation through purposeful and enjoyable interaction. It enables employees to participate wholeheartedly in an interactive experience sharing. It makes learning more enjoyable and inspires and motivates the users to effectively engage with the content. Games incentivize employees to learn and accomplish more skills, which can eventually transform the compelling approach to enjoying and doing approach. It was also reported that a significant number of people are motivated and work more effectively in a competitive environment. Gamification will provide prospects for competitive openings for rewards, incentives, and leaderboard rankings (Mulkeen, 2018).
In this context, one of the major online platforms, Deloitte Leadership Academy, provides a course with multiple components that cover a broad range of themes in consultation. The course aims to simplify several executive training and development initiatives, particularly for those at higher levels. With the aid of Badgeville Game Mechanics, Deloitte adds particular guidelines and incentives like leaderboards, badges, etc., which appear as appropriate gamified features. Trailing leaderboards and status signals is made easier with the app. It also aids in determining how many individuals enroll in, continue, and complete the course. This app aims to generate prompt feedback on the participants progress and eventually guide them toward timely and successful course completion. The prime motive for developing gamification is to boost the senior executives motivation and morale toward completing the training program.
Literature Review
The foremost apprehension in the metal and mining industry today is intrinsically training, motivating, and attracting new talent (Kowalski et al., 2001). The evolving mining workforce has several training issues, like differences between colleagues and their nature of executing job roles. For example, let us compare the newly joined workers who are the youngest (Generation Z) and the existing working population (Boomers) concerning their physiological, mental, social, and cultural characteristics. We can identify a considerable gap. There will also be noticeable differences in their learning modes and job expectations.
Work accomplishments among millennials at the workplace depend on their understanding of work requirements and job roles, which positively influence their learning capacities and motivate them to work more effectively within organizations. According to Jain and Dutta (2019), it is high time to modify the learning contrivances as per millennials preferences and styles. Based on several theoretical studies, the gamification model allows millennials to implement their learning optimally. Adding game elements to the work environment satisfies the needs for immediate satisfaction, accomplishment, and recognition. Researchers recommend that employee gaming platforms should have competitive leaderboards and quick feedback mechanisms.
Gamification in employee training and development is the process of enhancing training and educational exercises with gaming principles, making learning fun, and adding an element of friendly competition to encourage employees to engage with, understand, and retain training content better (Flanagan, 2022). Gamification helps build a learning culture, promoting employee growth and development through fun and engaging training programs (Kaikhosrosh vil i, 2023). It creates a culture that strengthens company culture, builds team spirit, and enhances the training experience. Gamification in training allows employees to see their progress as they learn, which can be very powerful for workplace learning and development. It makes the process more engaging, productive, and enjoyable for employees and improves worker recruitment and retention (Hawley, 2023). Gamification can lead to more engaged, driven, and productive employees. It can also make employees inclined to stay and grow with the company (Flanagan, 2022). Gamification can be incorporated into existing training efforts to make lessons more engaging and successful or build new learning and development initiatives (Hawley, 2023).
Gaonkar et al. (2022) stated that gamification in learning and teaching increases social impact, motivation, and learner engagement. Learners often view gamification as a highly attractive approach to enhance motivation, engagement, and social influence in learning and instruction. Games combine nostalgia, curiosity, visual appeal, and staff involvement to create an emotionally engaging ambience for the player and raise their level of emotional literacy, while inspiring them to explore new avenues and chances. By improving employee engagement and enriching the internal work environment, appropriate gamification makes work enjoyable for staff members. A straightforward example of a game-like tool designed to encourage users to interact with a concept more fully is Linkedln's profile completion tool.
Impact of Gamification on Learning and Development
A study of various research works and journals revealed that the metal and mining industry could revive its attractiveness for young talents with the help of gamification (Kowalski et al., 2001). The benefits of gamification include more adaptive and personalized learning experiences. It provides a clear picture of participants' career growth, increased participation, engagement, and motivation to complete the training through advanced and interesting platforms like VR and online courses. Learners can learn at their own pace, with application-based learning modules at their fingertips and with easy accessibility. Improved retention can help the employees apply the learnings in real-life work scenarios and create a knowledge-sharing environment that provides a platform for interactive peer learning.
Gamification is all about motivating people to achieve their own goals. It is often understood that employees' personal goals are aligned with organizational business goals. If the industries can identify their goals and share them with the employees, then with the help of gamification, employers can encourage employees to achieve their goals, which will eventually help the industries accomplish their targets (Kowalski et al., 2001).
As the global mining industry rebounds from the last downturn, it faces several critical challenges that extend beyond the mining sector. Across various industries, the impending retirement of experienced personnel from the baby boomer generation and the timeintensive nature of developing technical expertise pose significant concerns. This issue is exacerbated by the aging workforce, with alarming statistics revealing that the mining industry's average age is 46.5 years, well above the national average (Ashutosh, 2023).
Furthermore, there is a concerning breakdown in the executive replenishment cycle, with new talent entering the workforce having limited experience compared to the retiring generations of executives. The cyclical nature of boom and bust cycles and traditional cost-saving layoffs during downturns have resulted in a significant loss of middle and lower management, creating a substantial experience gap underneath senior management (Ashutosh, 2023). The industry's struggle to attract young talent further compounds the challenge. Mining engineering enrolments are on a downward trend globally, and the industry's reputation as unstable and its remote work locations make it less appealing to the tech-savvy and convenience-oriented millennial generation (Ashutosh, 2023).
Now, addressing these challenges requires innovative solutions. The impact of gamification on learning and development presents a promising avenue. Studies emphasize that gamification enhances learning experiences and motivates employees to engage actively with training content. Through adaptive and personalized learning modules delivered via advanced platforms like VR and online courses, gamification addresses the slow development of technical expertise by providing accessible and enjoyable training opportunities.
Research Problem: Why is there a skill shortage in the metals and mining industries?
Objective
* To understand the reason behind the skill shortage in the metal and mining industries;
* To know the impact of gamification on learning and development; and
* To examine how gamification can bridge the skill gap and attract young talent to the metal and mining industries.
Data and Methodology
The study adopted thematic analysis as proposed by Barun and Clarke (2006). The objective was to understand skill shortage and the role of gamification in attracting young talent to the metal and mining industry. Thematic analysis helps identify various themes and sub-themes in addressing the research question.
The target population for the study comprised senior officials, HR managers, employees, and job applicants in the metal and mining industry. A purposive sampling technique was adopted to reach out to content-rich participants for the study (Robinson, 2014). Respondents were contacted personally and through snowbowling techniques. All the participants were briefed about the purpose of the study and assured about the confidentiality of their identity. All the respondents signed a consent form to document their personal information and experiences only for research purposes. All the interviews were conducted offline and recorded using audio recording devices. All the recordings were anonymous, and a code was assigned for analysis.
Ten candidates were identified and requested to participate in the present research. The interviewers created 15 open-ended questions (see Appendix). The experts approved the questionnaire. As per experts' feedback, a few sensitive and very personal questions were removed. Some of the questions were reframed for better responses. Respondents were asked to spare 20 to 30 minutes for the interview. The study was conducted in 2023.
Demographic Details of Participants
The average age of the ten respondents was 30.25 years. Reflecting the traditionally maledominated nature of the industry, all respondents were males. 30% of the respondents had a bachelor's degree in engineering or related fields, 40% had a diploma in mining technology, and 20% had advanced degrees in Geology or Metallurgy. Respondents belonged to the following job roles: mining engineer, geologist, equipment operator, safety and environmental officer, and technician. 80% of the respondents had 5-10 years of work experience. All the participants belonged to Jharkhand state. In response to digital literacy, 30% reported having limited digital literacy, 60% of respondents reported moderate digital skills and only 10% reported high tech-savvy.
Data Analysis
For data analysis purposes, Barun and Clarke's (2006) six-step method for thematic analysis was used. The approach is widely accepted and prevalent in thematic analysis (Maguire and Delahunt, 2017). The steps are as follows:
Step 1: Becoming Familiar with the Data: We read and re-read the respondents' transcripts to familiarize ourselves with the data. NVivo 1.5 software was used to create memos.
Step 2: Generating Initial Codes: The data was maintained in two different files: one for the officials, and the other for workers. The data was arranged in Excel files. The Excel files were imported to Nvivo.1.5 software. Each transcription was carefully read, and an initial 31 codes were generated from the data.
Step 3: Searching for Sub-Themes: The next step was to create the sub-themes through the rigorous iterative validation process. In thematic analysis, researchers can identify the themes at two levels: semantic and latent (Boyatzis, 1998). Semantic themes are derived from the explicit and surface meanings of the data. Latent themes aim to capture the underlying ideas, patterns, and assumptions. As our workers were not very knowledgeable and seasoned enough to articulate their motives and experiences in words, the researchers used more interpretative and conceptual orientation towards the data.
Step 4: Reviewing Sub-Themes: All the sub-themes were reviewed through an iterative approach. During the process, similar or overlapping sub-themes were distilled.
Step 5: Defining Themes: Two broad themes emerged, each related to challenges and gamification of L&D. Further, each theme had four sub-themes regarding challenges and the impact of gamification. A brief schema of different themes and sub-themes identified in this process, along with their corresponding representative codes, is shown in Figure 1.
Step 6: Write-Up of Themes: The following section will have a detailed explanation of all the two themes and their sub-themes.
Results
This section elaborates on the two latent themes and their sub-themes, which emerged during the analysis. The first theme is "Issues with the Young Generation" in the metal and mining industry (see Figure 1 ). In today's ever-changing business world, metals and mining industries face a lot of uncertainty and complexity. The industry also deals with the big problem of lack of skilled workers. The first sub-theme that emerged under issues with the young generation is 'Redundant work culture' (Figure 2).
Redundant Work Culture: India's metal and mining industry is regarded as redundant. Many see these jobs as boring, old-fashioned, and environmentally destructive.
"We often get stuck using normal ways of working. When people want to use new technology or make things simpler, they often meet resistance. We often keep methods that may have worked before but might not be the best or long-lasting now" (Participant no. 6).
"Let's think about how we handle data. We still use old software and a lot of hand input. Even though there are fancier tools that could hugely boost work and cut down on mistakes, people do not want to spend the money on these changes" (Participant no. 4).
Redundancy breeds in employees because of fear of job displacement and skepticism of adopting something new. Employees worry that embracing automation or new technologies might lead to job cuts.
Lack of Peer Learning: Although it appears absent in the mining and metals sector, peer learning is essential to professional development. The mining industry employs a diverse workforce of geologists, engineers, and technicians with varying specializations in mining aspects. However, the knowledge exchange between these different roles is minimal. There is a siloed approach where everyone focuses on their tasks without much interaction or collaboration.
"We often work on tight schedule. There is literary no time to discuss anything regarding work. My friends do not want to share much about their work probably because they are also worried about losing their jobs or threat of being replaced" (Participant No. 1).
The traditional hierarchical structure in the industry fosters the culture of information flowfrom the top down, but notas much laterally between peers. Employees have a wealth of knowledge within their workforce, but it is not fully tapped. New employees especially could benefit from the experience of their more seasoned colleagues. It is not just about formal training programs but the informal exchange of insights and lessons learned on the job.
Lack of Career Growth/Opportunity: The industry has a traditional career growth opportunity, and advancement in career follows a predefined path. This can demotivate some employees to diversify their skills or explore different aspects of the industry.
"People with special skills are important, but those who want to grow within the company or do things in new areas do not get the help or encouragement from seniors. Often, it looks like a road that goes just one way" (Participant no. 1).
It can lead to a sense of stagnation. Employees might feel like their professional development is restricted. This not only affects morale but also impacts retention. If individuals do not see a clear path for growth within the organization, they might seek opportunities elsewhere.
Lack of Awareness and Education: The metal and mining sector faces a significant challenge regarding awareness and education. Many employees, especially those in operational roles, might not fully grasp mining activities and the impact of their activities on society and the environment. There is a need for more comprehensive education in the larger context of the industry.
A lack of knowledge and awareness can lead to a disconnect between employees and the broader goals of sustainable and responsible mining. Without a clear understanding of the environmental and social considerations, employees may not be as motivated to adopt practices that align with these goals.
"It is not just about completing the job; it is also about doing so with less carbon footprint. Yes, safety is a very important area. We have safety rules, but we need to keep learning about new ways and tools for staying safe" (Participant no. 10).
Employee activities require improvement in training programs related to new technologies and automation. Many employees might not be fully aware of these advancements' potential benefits and challenges.
The inputs and suggestions from respondents led to the second theme, highlighting the needs and "Advantages of gamification" in learning and development functions (see Figure 3).
Engaging and Real-Time Experiences: Gamification will add an element of excitement. The gamified training programs will instigate active participation among employees in the learning process. This engagement factor is crucial in an industry with high stakes. Gamification offers employees different learning ways that suit their learning styles and preferences. It helps them understand how they can do better in their careers. Using advanced tools like virtual reality (VR) and online courses makes learning more exciting. Gamification also makes things a bit like competition, which makes people want to take part and learn, even if they learn at different speeds.
"Our field is known for being really busy and may be old-fashioned when it comes to learning and growing. Using games can make tasks that might otherwise seem boring more fun and engaging" (Participant no. 7).
A Platform for Interaction: Gamification may turn training and learning into a collaborative experience. Effective communication and teamwork are essential in an industry as collaborative as metal and mining. Gamification may allow employees to practice and enhance these skills dynamically and engagingly. The gamification of learning may create a shared experience for employees across different roles and levels. Employees can navigate these virtual scenarios, overcome challenges, and celebrate successes together.
"Of course. Think about team-building activities as an example. We can work together using games to fix problems, agree on things, and achieve shared goals. Not only is doing well by yourself important, but our ability to team up and talk in a computer-based environment also matters" (Participant no. 7).
Reward Through Badges and Leaderboards: Introducing a system of badges and leaderboards that acknowledges and compensates young workers for their achievements and contributions will be possible with gamification. This element of competition can ignite motivation and positive rivalry, enhancing involvement and skill refinement.
"Of course, the opportunity to receive badges and rewards will take the reward and recognition to a whole new level. It will generate sportsmanship among employees. The badgeswill be considered an obvious symbol of achievement. Leaderboard may clearly state where the employee stands and what he has to do to move upward" (Participant no. 7).
Training Program Through VR: Incorporate virtual reality (VR) training programs that provide immersive and true-to-life encounters. This technology can replicate complex scenarios, creating a secure environment for young workers to cultivate skills and boost self-assurance. Additionally, VR can offer an inventive training approach, capturing the interest of technologically inclined young employees.
"Application of VR in training modules will allow the employees to operate and handle the sophisticated and technical machinery well in advance before they experiment with the real machinery. It will save time, provide on-the-job training and reduce the chance of mishandling or accidents. Employee will receive more than just mere demonstration; he can operate it and learn its functioning as well as troubleshooting" (participant no. 9).
Discussion
The mining industry faces a big problem because there are not enough skilled workers in India. This is causing issues with getting work done and meeting essential goals. Many leaders in the mining industry say that not having enough skilled workers is a big problem. This shortage of skilled workers is terrible in specific areas like planning mines, engineering processes, and working with digital technology. Because there are not enough skilled people, the industry has difficulty developing new ideas and moving forward.
Combining technology and learning is important to deal with the changing skills needed. Changing the way things are done using technology, known as digital transformation, is a big part of making industries more active and competitive. It is crucial to create a culture where learning is encouraged to ensure that employees keep learning and stay in the company. This kind of culture helps to develop new ideas and keeps the company abreast even as technology changes quickly.
One of the strategies that can really change how we learn and grow is gamification. This means adding elements of games to learning situations, making them fun and interactive. The great thing about gamification is that it makes learning enjoyable and motivating. By using things like leaderboards, badges, and other game-like things, employees are encouraged to learn and get better at their skills, which helps solve the problem of not having enough skills. A key part of gamification is that it matches up with what individuals and the company want to achieve. By connecting what employees want with what the company wants, industries can make people want to work harder. Gamification gives a structure for employees to really care about their goals, which can help the industry do well.
In summary, using gamification in learning and development is a good way for the metal and mining industry to deal with the problem of insufficient skilled workers. This approach fixes the skills problem and helps change how people see the industry by making learning interesting, personal, and aligned with big goals. In a changing and uncertain world, gamification is a strong tool to bring in, grow, and keep the talented people needed for the industry to do well and be innovative.
Recommendations: To tackle the issues encountered by the industry in attracting and managing young individuals in the metal mining sectors, here are a few proposals for learning and development programs:
First, provide interactive and immediate learning encounters by developing lively and interactive training modules that provide young workers with engaging and real-time learning experiences. Make use of technology to replicate work situations, enabling them to put their learning into practice. This practical approach helps connect theoretical knowledge with real-world skills.
Second, define transparent career advancement routes by crafting explicit paths for career progression that offer chances for skill enhancement and upward mobility. This framework can give young employees a distinct route for their professional journey, motivating them to dedicate effort to their careers within the field.
Third, provide acknowledgment via badges and leaderboards. Leader boards add an element of healthy competition. Seeing your name on the leaderboard, whether for completing training modules or achieving certain performance metrics, creates a sense of accomplishment. It fosters a bit of friendly rivalry, pushing individuals to strive for excellence, and continuously improves employees' performance.
Finally, implement virtual reality (VR) training. VR gamification transports one to different scenarios, allowing one to experience and respond to challenges as if they were happening in real life. It is an incredibly effective way to prepare for the complexities of employees' work.
Conclusion
The paper focused on the growing practice of gamification, which injects enjoyment and rewards into work to enhance employee loyalty and engagement. By integrating elements of enjoyment and incentives into work routines, gamification can potentially heighten employee engagement and diminish turnover rates. The opportunity for distinctive learning preferences to the younger generation, particularly the millennials, will significantly improve employee engagement.
The proposed model draws from qualitative research methods, outlining how gamification effectively addresses the challenges faced by the metal and mining industry in appealing to the present generation. The model considers the motivating factors for the millennials, like pursuit of immediate rewards, drive for success, and the need for recognition at work. Gamification achieves this by integrating competitive leaderboards, social learning opportunities, and swift feedback mechanisms. These aspects cater to the desire for instant gratification, foster a sense of accomplishment through healthy competition, and offer channels for recognition. By embracing gamification in this manner, the metal and mining industry can reshape itself into an attractive and rewarding workplace for the younger generation.

Appendix
1. What is your current role and job position within the company?
2. How long have you been in this role?
3. How many years of experience do you have in the metal and mining industry?
4. Have you worked in other industries before joining this company?
5. What is your highest level of education?
6. Did your educational background include any specific training in the field relevant to your current role?
7. Which age group do you fall into?
8. Are you comfortable using digital tools and technology in your daily work?
9. Have you participated in any other training or development programs offered by the company?
10. What is your overall perception of the gamification elements integrated into your learning and development programs?
11. In what ways do you think gamification aligns with the specific tasks and responsibilities in the metal and mining industry?
12. Do you feel that gamification motivates you to engage more with the learning content?
13. In what ways has gamification contributed to your skill development within the metal and mining context?
14. Do you feel that employees are comfortable with the technology used in gamified training?
15. What could be the major challenge to gamification of learning and development program in your organization?

From Learner to Innovator: Knowledge Transfer from a Parent MNE and Foreign Subsidiaries’ Local Innovation

Author: Zhou, Nan1    ; Li, Jiatao2; Bai, Changhong3; Zhang, Dan41 Tongji University, School of Economics and Management, Advanced Institute of Business, Shanghai, China (GRID:grid.24516.34) (ISNI:0000 0001 2370 4535)2 Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Management Department, School of Business and Management, Hong Kong, China (GRID:grid.24515.37) (ISNI:0000 0004 1937 1450)3 Nankai University, Business School, Tianjin, China (GRID:grid.216938.7) (ISNI:0000 0000 9878 7032)4 Patent Examination Cooperation (Beijing), CNIPA, Center of the patent office, Beijing, China (GRID:grid.216938.7)

Publication info: Zhou, Nan; Li, Jiatao; Bai, Changhong; Zhang, Dan. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/learner-innovator-knowledge-transfer-parent-mne/docview/3037705372/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Knowledge transfer from a parent multinational to a foreign subsidiary does not automatically lead to innovation in a host country. To develop from a learner into an innovator, a foreign subsidiary must develop sufficient absorptive capacity. But too much reliance on knowledge transferred from a multinational could hinder local innovation by generating resource constraints and organizational rigidity. We thus predict an inverted U-shaped relationship between knowledge transfer from a parent multinational and local innovation. Moreover, factors which influence the transition from learner to innovator were investigated using data on patent applications by foreign subsidiaries of 75 large multinationals in China between 2008 and 2016. The number of research and development centers the subsidiary maintains was found to be influential, as is hiring a local executive as the subsidiary’s top manager. Greater institutional distance between the parent’s and the subsidiary’s economies was found to promote the transition, as do greater technological richness and more vigorous competition in the host country. The relationship between knowledge transfer from a parent multinational and local innovation is weaker, however, in older subsidiaries.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Nan&amp;aulast=Zhou&amp;atitle=From+Learner+to+Innovator%3A+Knowledge+Transfer+from+a+Parent+MNE+and+Foreign+Subsidiaries%26rsquo%3B+Local+Innovation&amp;stitle=Management+International+Review&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs11575-023-00512-6&amp;title=From+Learner+to+Innovator%3A+Knowledge+Transfer+from+a+Parent+MNE+and+Foreign+Subsidiaries%E2%80%99+Local+Innovation&amp;volume=64&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=89&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Nan&amp;aulast=Zhou&amp;atitle=From+Learner+to+Innovator%3A+Knowledge+Transfer+from+a+Parent+MNE+and+Foreign+Subsidiaries%26rsquo%3B+Local+Innovation&amp;stitle=Management+International+Review&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs11575-023-00512-6&amp;title=From+Learner+to+Innovator%3A+Knowledge+Transfer+from+a+Parent+MNE+and+Foreign+Subsidiaries%E2%80%99+Local+Innovation&amp;volume=64&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=89&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Celebrating 60 Years of The Chinese University of Hong Kong: Research Highlights in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology

Author: Yang, Lin1; Choi, Chung Hang Jonathan1    ; Wang, Jianfang1    ; Xia, Jiang1    ; Zhang, Li1    ; Ngai, To1    ; Zi, Yunlong1    ; Huang, Zhifeng1    1 The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, New Territories, Hong Kong SAR 999077, People's Republic of China

Publication info: Yang, Lin; Choi, Chung Hang Jonathan; Wang, Jianfang; Xia, Jiang; Zhang, Li; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/celebrating-60-years-chinese-university-hong-kong/docview/2904158218/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Recent breakthroughs and advances in nanoscience and nanotechnology have profoundly impacted young-generation education, accelerated knowledge transfer to enhance the quality of life, and improved environmental and economic sustainability. The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), a globally recognized education and research institute, has played a crucial role in promoting major strategic research directions in nanoscience, including translational biomedicine and information and automation technology, as well as environment and sustainability. To celebrate the 60th Anniversary of CUHK, we present this Virtual Issue that showcases the cutting-edge research at CUHK published in ACS Nano .Recent breakthroughs and advances in nanoscience and nanotechnology have profoundly impacted young-generation education, accelerated knowledge transfer to enhance the quality of life, and improved environmental and economic sustainability. The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), a globally recognized education and research institute, has played a crucial role in promoting major strategic research directions in nanoscience, including translational biomedicine and information and automation technology, as well as environment and sustainability. To celebrate the 60th Anniversary of CUHK, we present this Virtual Issue that showcases the cutting-edge research at CUHK published in ACS Nano.

Resume Named Entity Recognition Based on ChatGLM-9B Fine-tuning

Author: Liu, Xin1; Qiu, Quantong1; Jiang, Ruiling1; Lv, Jian11 Jiangxi University of Finance and Economics,Nanchang,China

Publication info: Liu, Xin; Qiu, Quantong; Jiang, Ruiling; Lv, Jian. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/resume-named-entity-recognition-based-on-chatglm/docview/3246358548/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 7th International Conference on Mechatronics and Computer Technology Engineering (MCTE) Conference Start Date: 2024 Aug. 23 Conference End Date: 2024 Aug. 25 Conference Location: Guangzhou, China Named Entity Recognition (NER) technology is a key technique for resume information extraction, and there are current issues with resume NER algorithms such as poor knowledge transfer ability, large model parameter volume, and long model training time. This paper proposes a new method based on Rora instruction fine-tuning of large language models combined with situation simulation. By introducing low-rank matrices to simulate the effect of full-parameter fine-tuning, and transforming the Resume dataset into a knowledge question-and-answer format that integrates situation simulation, the fine-tuned large language model is more suitable for the application scenarios of resume entity recognition. Experiments show that the F1 score on the Resume dataset that integrates situation simulation reached 95.14%. Compared to several models that perform well in the task of resume named entity recognition, the improvements were 5.72%, 4.38%, and 1.62% respectively, thereby validating that the method can effectively leverage the advantages of NLG (Natural Language Generation) language models in text generation to accomplish the task of named entity recognition.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Xin&amp;aulast=Liu&amp;atitle=Resume+Named+Entity+Recognition+Based+on+ChatGLM-9B+Fine-tuning&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FMCTE62870.2024.11117835&amp;title=Resume+Named+Entity+Recognition+Based+on+ChatGLM-9B+Fine-tuning&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=1744&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Xin&amp;aulast=Liu&amp;atitle=Resume+Named+Entity+Recognition+Based+on+ChatGLM-9B+Fine-tuning&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FMCTE62870.2024.11117835&amp;title=Resume+Named+Entity+Recognition+Based+on+ChatGLM-9B+Fine-tuning&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=1744&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

Academic Motivation and Career Decidedness of STEM and HASS Students During Higher Education

Author: Masliyenko, Tetyana

Publication info: Masliyenko, Tetyana. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/academic-motivation-career-decidedness-stem-hass/docview/3235004267/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Motivation shapes the actions of individuals, serving as a driving force behind behavior and decision-making. In education, motivation significantly impacts academic achievement, persistence, engagement, and emotional well-being. Motivated students are more likely to set high academic goals, persist despite challenges, and engage deeply in classroom activities, leading to better knowledge retention and satisfaction. Additionally, motivation fosters self-regulated learning strategies, essential for lifelong learning and adapting to new challenges. This Master’s thesis investigates the relationship between students' dominant academic motivation type and their level of career decidedness, grounded in Self-Determination Theory (Deci & Ryan, 1985). According to this theory, intrinsic motivation, associated with autonomy, is fundamental to personal self-regulation and effective behavior, showing strong associations with academic motivation and potentially, career clarity. A sample of 458 students from the University of Coimbra, encompassing diverse faculties (STEM, Arts and Humanities, Social Sciences), study cycles, age groups, and genders, was utilized to explore this relationship. The study employed a quantitative methodology, using validated questionnaires to assess academic motivation (Academic Motivation Scale by Vallerand, 1992) and career decidedness (Career Decision Scale by Osipow, 1976). The findings reveal that participants exhibited below-average levels of most types of academic motivation, while the general level of career decidedness among students was above average. Gender differences indicated that female students had slightly higher levels of Extrinsic Motivation - Introjected Regulation compared to male students. Students identifying as a gender “other” than male or female reported higher demotivation, although there were no significant differences in demotivation based on gender overall. Age-related differences showed that younger students (aged 18-25) exhibited lower intrinsic motivation and higher extrinsic motivation, while older students demonstrated the opposite dynamics, with no significant differences in demotivation based on age. Regarding study cycles, Master's and Doctorate level students exhibited higher intrinsic motivation compared to Bachelor's students. Additionally, Bachelor's and Doctorate students exhibited higher levels of demotivation compared to Master's students. In terms of the field of study, intrinsic motivation was higher among students in the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences (HASS) compared to those in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). STEM students demonstrated higher levels of extrinsic motivation and demotivation compared to HASS students. Finally, the research found no significant correlation between academic motivation types and career decidedness, raising questions for further investigation on the applicability of Self-Determination Theory in the field of education. This study's findings hold potential for practical applications aimed at improving academic methodologies in higher education institutions, thereby fostering positive career outcomes for students. Alternate abstract: A motivação molda as ações dos indivíduos, servindo como uma força motriz por trás do comportamento e da tomada de decisões. Na educação, a motivação impacta significativamente o desempenho académico, a persistência, o envolvimento e o bem-estar emocional. Alunos motivados são mais propensos a estabelecer metas académicas elevadas, persistir apesar dos desafios e envolver-se profundamente nas atividades em sala de aula, levando a uma melhor retenção do conhecimento e satisfação. Além disso, a motivação promove estratégias de aprendizagem autorregulada, essenciais para a aprendizagem ao longo da vida e adaptação a novos desafios. Esta tese de Mestrado investiga a relação entre o tipo dominante de motivação académica dos alunos e o seu nível de decisão de carreira, fundamentada na Teoria da Autodeterminação (Deci & Ryan, 1985). De acordo com esta teoria, a motivação intrínseca, associada à autonomia, é fundamental para a autorregulação pessoal e comportamento eficaz, mostrando fortes associações com a motivação académica e, potencialmente, com a clareza de carreira. Uma amostra de 458 alunos da Universidade de Coimbra, abrangendo diversas faculdades (STEM, Artes e Humanidades, Ciências Sociais), ciclos de estudo, faixas etárias e géneros, foi utilizada para explorar esta relação. O estudo empregou uma metodologia quantitativa, utilizando questionários validados para avaliar a motivação académica (Escala de Motivação Académica de Vallerand, 1992) e a decisão de carreira (Escala de Decisão de Carreira de Osipow, 1976). Os resultados revelam que os participantes exibiram níveis abaixo da média na maioria dos tipos de motivação académica, enquanto o nível geral de decisão de carreira entre os alunos foi acima da média. Diferenças de género indicaram que as alunas apresentaram níveis ligeiramente mais altos de Motivação Extrínseca - Regulação Introjetada em comparação com os alunos. Alunos que se identificam com um género “diferente” de masculino ou feminino relataram maior desmotivação, embora não tenham sido encontradas diferenças significativas na desmotivação com base no género em geral. Diferenças relacionadas à idade mostraram que os alunos mais jovens (com idades entre 18-25 anos) exibiram menor motivação intrínseca e maior motivação extrínseca, enquanto os alunos mais velhos demonstraram a dinâmica oposta, sem diferenças significativas na desmotivação com base na idade. Em relação aos ciclos de estudo, os alunos de Mestrado e Doutoramento exibiram maior motivação intrínseca em comparação com os alunos de Licenciatura. Além disso, os alunos de Licenciatura e Doutoramento exibiram níveis mais altos de desmotivação em comparação com os alunos de Mestrado. Em termos de área de estudo, a motivação intrínseca foi maior entre os alunos de Humanidades, Artes e Ciências Sociais (HASS) em comparação com aqueles de Ciência, Tecnologia, Engenharia e Matemática (STEM). Os alunos de STEM demonstraram níveis mais altos de motivação extrínseca e desmotivação em comparação com os alunos de HASS. Finalmente, a pesquisa não encontrou correlação significativa entre os tipos de motivação académica e a decisão de carreira, levantando questões para investigação futura sobre a aplicabilidade da Teoria da Autodeterminação no campo da educação. As descobertas deste estudo têm potencial para aplicações práticas voltadas para a melhoria das metodologias académicas em instituições de ensino superior, promovendo assim resultados de carreira positivos para os alunos.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Tetyana&amp;aulast=Masliyenko&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Academic+Motivation+and+Career+Decidedness+of+STEM+and+HASS+Students+During+Higher+Education&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798290688183&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Tetyana&amp;aulast=Masliyenko&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Academic+Motivation+and+Career+Decidedness+of+STEM+and+HASS+Students+During+Higher+Education&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798290688183&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;
