Türkiye’de tasarım merkezi ekosisteminde strateji ve politikaların etkilerine yönelik durum analizi

Author: Tiryakioğlu, Hazan Kara

Publication info: Tiryakioğlu, Hazan Kara. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/türkiye-de-tasarım-merkezi-ekosisteminde-strateji/docview/2939731029/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Bu araştırma, tasarımla ilgili ulusal strateji ve politikalar ekseninde, farklı özelliklerde tasarım merkezlerinin incelenmesiyle etkili ve verimli, sürdürülebilir yapıların sağlanmasına yönelik etki faktörlerini, Türkiye örneği üzerinden ele almaktadır. Son yıllarda öne çıkan Tasarım Merkezi (TM) tanımlamasının yurtdışında ve Türkiye’de nasıl karşılık bulduğu, ne tür çeşitlilik gösterdiği, ulusal politikaların nasıl yansımaları olduğu ile ilgili gelişmeler, araştırmanın temel çıkış noktalarını oluşturmaktadır. TR’de ulusal tasarım politikaları kapsamında ne tür organizasyonel yapıların desteklendiği ile ilgili güncel gelişmelere bakıldığında; yenilik üreticisi kurumsal yapıların tasarım birimlerinde belirli koşulların sağlanması doğrultusunda, bu tür yapılara TM unvanı verilerek birtakım muafiyetler sağlanması, dikkat çekici gelişmeler içinde yer almıştır. Bu araştırmada, Türkiye’de Ulusal İnovasyon Sisteminin (UİS) bileşenleri olarak farklı altyapıda, farklı hedefler doğrultusunda şekillenen ve bu doğrultuda faaliyet ve hizmet alanı, faydalanıcı kitle ve etki alanı çeşitlenen tasarım merkezlerinin yapılarının açığa çıkarılması esastır. Yaratıcı ekonomi ve yenilik ekosisteminin gelişimi doğrultusunda TM’lerin verimliliğine ve sürdürülebilirliğine yönelik strateji ve politikaların etkilerini sebep-sonuç ilişkisi içinde ele alıp, TM ekosistemi ile paydaşları açığa çıkaran ve ilişkilere işaret eden teorik model önerisi sunmak, tezin temel hedefidir. Öncelikle, tasarım merkezlerinin yurtdışında ne tür organizasyonel yapılanmalar için tanımlandığı, ayırt edici temel özelliklerinin neler olduğu, Ulusal Tasarım Sistemi (UTS) içinde rollerinin nasıl tanımlandığı mercek altına alınmaktadır. Daha sonra Türkiye (TR) ölçeğinde ne tür TM yapılanmalarının olduğu incelenmekte, TM faaliyetlerinin verimliliği ve sürdürülebilirliği hususunda temel sorunlar ve etki faktörlerinin neler olduğu, gerekliliklerin nasıl tanımlanabileceği üzerinde durulmaktadır. TR’de TM teşvikleri kapsamında devletin rolünün ne olduğu, ilgili politikaların UTS’ye yansımalarında ne tür sistem hatalarının etki ettiği ile ilgili konular araştırmanın odağındadır. Nitel veri analizinin ön planda olduğu bu durum çalışmasında, mevcut literatürde TM ile ilgili verilerin ele alınmasının yanı sıra, yurtdışındaki TM’lerin kurumsal internet sayfalarından edinilen bilgilerin satır analizi ile açığa çıkarılan temel özellikler de TR odaklı alan çalışmasının kavramsal çerçevesini şekillendirmiştir. TR’de belirlenmiş TM’leri kapsayan alan çalışmasında imalatçıkurumsal yapılanma altında TM’lerin yanı sıra, bölgesel ölçekte veya tematik alanlarda faaliyet gösteren TM’ler, üniversite bünyesindeki araştırma ve uygulama merkezleri, iş birliği ve promosyonel faaliyetleri ile ön planda olan TM’ler, araştırma evrenine dahil edilen temel kategoriler olarak belirlenmiştir. Tanımlanmış bu kümeler dahilinde TM’lerle yarı yapılandırılmış mülakatlar yapılmış olup, kodlama yöntemi ile tematik analiz gerçekleştirilmiştir. Saha çalışmasından elde edilen veriler doğrultusunda TR’de TM ekosisteminde yer alan farklı yapılar, ortaklık ve farklılıklarıyla bir arada değerlendirilmiştir; faaliyet ve hizmet alanlarının, UTS içerisindeki rollerin nasıl çeşitlendiği, faaliyetlerin etkililiği ve sürdürülebilirliği hususunda ne tür etkilerin söz konusu olduğu ortaya konulmuştur. Literatür verileri ve alan çalışması bulgularının bir arada değerlendirilmesi sonucunda ortaya çıkan temel kritik tespit, TR’de UTS içerisindeki tasarım politikalarına ilişkin tanım ve uygulamalarla ilgili sistem hatalarının TM ekosisteminde yapısal bozukluklara sebep olarak, verimlilik ve sürdürülebilirlik hususunda olumsuz etki yaratmasıdır. TR’de ‘Yaratıcı Ekonomi ve Yenilik’ ekosisteminin parçası olarak TM’lerin etkili katma değer yaratabilmeleri için nasıl yapılanması gerektiği, ne tür arka plan ile desteklenmesi gerektiği, elverişli koşulların neler olduğu hususunda tespitler ve öneriler sunulmuştur. TR’de Ar-Ge ile ilgili politikalardan türetilerek hazırlanmış olan tasarım destek politikalarının, tasarımın sunduğu birçok ayırt edici katkı alanının göz ardı edilmesine sebep olduğu ve yeni nesil inovasyon modellerinin gerektirdiği açık inovasyon yaklaşımlarının, iş birliği ve ağ yapılarının gücünün geri planda kaldığı tespit edilmiştir. Bulgular doğrultusunda, TR’de TM olarak tanımlanan ve desteklenen, ürün/hizmet tasarımı gerçekleştiren ve ticari faaliyetleri ile ulusal kalkınmaya katkı sağlayan yapıların yanı sıra, promosyonel faaliyetler gerçekleştiren, araştırma odaklı çalışan, bölgesel ölçekte veya tematik alanlarda faaliyet gösteren, farklı ölçeklerde ve farklı organizasyonel yapılanma biçimlerinde merkezlerin de UİS bileşeni olarak katkı sağlayıcı olduklarına işaret edilmekte; TM tanımlamasının ve destek kriterlerinin ise UTS’nin gelişimi ile ilgili bu açıdan yeterince kapsayıcı ve hedefe yönelik olmayışı tartışılmaktadır. Zira, TM tanımlaması ile ilgili literatüre ve yurtdışındaki uygulama örneklerine bakıldığında, bilgi ve inovasyon üretiminin yanı sıra, paylaşımın, yayılımın ve bilgi transferinin özendirildiği, laboratuvar yapılanmalarının ön planda olduğu, deneysel yöntemlerin uygulandığı, hedef faydalanıcı kitle dahil farklı paydaşların süreçlere katılımının teşvik edildiği, insanın merkeze alındığı ve toplumsal faydanın gözetildiği, açık inovasyon prensiplerinin uygulandığı, dışa dönük, şeffaf, paylaşımcı ve birleştirici rol üstlenilen yapılar ön plana çıkmaktadır. TR’de TM politikaları ile ilgili altyapıya bakıldığında ise bu gelişmelerin göz ardı edilmiş olduğu, desteklerinin çerçevesinin, belirli nicel şartları sağlayan işletmelerin ticari faaliyetleri ekseninde şekillendiği tespit edilmiştir. Sonuç olarak, TM ekosistemindeki paydaşlar ve etki dinamikleri haritalandırılmış; ekosistem üzerine etki eden dinamikleri açığa çıkaran tanımlayıcı bir teorik model önerisi tanımlanmıştır. Bu model kapsamında, yaratıcı ekonomi ve yenilik ekosisteminin gelişimine katkı sağlayan TM faaliyetlerinin gerçekleşebilmesi için, destekleyici koşullar, etki-tepki ilişkisi vurgulanarak tanımlanmıştır. Stratejik gereksinimler, yenilik gelişimini destekleyici altyapı, iş birlikleri ve etkileşimleri destekleyici altyapı başlıkları altında, kısa/orta/uzun vade için sonuç önerileri sunulmuştur. Alternate abstract: The main focus of this research is the investigation of design centers with different characteristics in Turkiye (TR) in the axis of national strategies and policies to discover the impact factors for effective and efficient sustainable infrastructures. The main starting points are how the definition of the Design Center (DC), which has come to the forefront in recent years, is met abroad and in TR; what kind of diversity DCs point out, and how they are affected by national policies. Considering the recent developments regarding what type of organizational structures are supported within the scope of national design policies in TR, it is noteworthy that the design departments of innovative corporate systems are given the official title of DC, and some exemptions are provided for them if they meet certain conditions. In this research, it is considered essential to reveal different types of DCs in TR, with different goals and various infrastructures, whose area of activity and service, beneficiary group, and impact area are diversified in this direction, as components of the National Innovation System (NIS). In line with the development of the creative economy and innovation ecosystem, the main objective of the thesis is to present a theoretical model proposal for the DC ecosystem by considering the effects of strategies and policies on the efficiency and sustainability level in a cause & effect relationship. NIS includes components at different scales and focuses on generation, dissemination, commercialization, use, and impact value of innovation. Educational and promotional activities related to innovation, research and development (R&D), production and supply chains, strategy and policy-making, and implementing mechanisms are different elements of this system. For the system to work harmoniously and correctly, these different elements must work effectively and efficiently among themselves, as well as the requirements of solid interrelationships, ease and frequency of information flow. The National Design System (NDS), which is sometimes considered equivalent and sometimes as a subset of the NIS, also points to different components on a national scale by putting ‘design’ in the center. It focuses on the roles and relationships between various stakeholders to identify and repair malfunctions and failures within the system. The activities of different components to operate in multiple ways, such as creation, distribution, transfer, and transformation of innovation, are also at the center of design-related strategies and policies. Because the primary goal of design policies is to develop the design from different perspectives on a regional and national scale, to create mechanisms that ensure the implementation of rules and objectives that positively affect national and social development, and increase the beneficiary group. This research, which focuses on DCs in the axis of strategies and policies, considers the different roles of different components in the NIS and a vast network that emerges with the diversification in their contribution areas with a systemic approach. It examines what kind of characteristic features and types of design centers exist as a NIS component and how they contribute to design-related development. It relates to how design policies and strategies offer a background in influencing the structural features of DCs and contributing, guiding, supporting, or restricting their beneficiaries. When it comes to the content structure of the thesis, first of all, the triggering climate, value-added economic development, and design relations in the background related to handling design policies on a national scale are mentioned. How strategies and procedures are developed and implemented, the extent to which they affect the design sector and its network, and how they are effective in design-related incentive and support systems are examined through examples from different countries. Current approaches that emphasize the transition from policies focusing on design as a factor of national development and economic competitiveness to human-centered policies are highlighted. Innovation and design policies, the intersection of sectoral and regional development policies, trade policies, science and technology policies, and social innovation policies are emphasized. In this direction, the roles of design centers as a component of NIS are highlighted. In line with the changing dynamics and paradigms, the expanding and changing scope of the design has been expressed, and its reflections on the DCs have been determined. It is examined what kind of organizational structures DCs are defined for abroad, what their distinctive basic features are, and how their roles are defined within the NDS. Then, what kind of DC structures exist in the TR scale is investigated, the main problems and impact factors regarding the efficiency and sustainability of DC activities and how the requirements can be defined are emphasized. The focus of the research is on the role of the state within the scope of DC incentives in TR and what kind of systemic failures affect the reflection of the relevant policies on the NDS. In this qualitative situational study, the main features revealed by the information obtained from the corporate web pages of DCs abroad and the data about DCs in the existing literature shaped the conceptual framework of the TR-focused field study. In the field study covering the DCs determined in TR, in addition to the centers in the manufacturer-institutional structures, centers operating on a regional scale or in thematic areas, research and application centers within universities, centers for cooperation and promotional activities are also included in the research universe, considered as main four categories. Semi-structured interviews were conducted with the centers within these defined clusters, and thematic analysis was carried out with the coding method. As a result of synthesizing the data, conclusions about the characteristics of DCs in TR, their service areas, their position in the NDS, how the strategies and policies they are related to, and what kind of effects are in question on the effectiveness and sustainability of the activities are revealed. In this direction, a theoretical model proposal for the DC ecosystem and conclusion suggestions for future development are presented. In line with the data obtained from the fieldwork, different structures in the DC ecosystem in TR were evaluated together with their similarities and differences. The main critical finding that emerged as a result of the evaluation of the literature data and field study findings together is that systemic failures related to the definition and applications of design policies in the NDS in TR cause structural defects in the DC ecosystem and have a negative impact on efficiency and sustainability. As a part of the creative economy and innovation ecosystem in TR, determinations and suggestions are made on how the 'Design Centers' should be structured to create practical added value, what kind of background they should be supported, and what the favorable conditions would be. It is emphasized that the design support policies, which were prepared by deriving from the policies related to R&D in TR, caused many distinctive contribution areas offered by design to be ignored, that the power of open innovation approaches, collaboration, and network structures required by new generation innovation models remained in the background. The findings obtained from the research show that; in addition to the structures defined and supported as DC in TR that carry out product/service design and contribute to national development with their commercial activities, there are also DCs that are effective in promotional activities, research facilities, regional scale or thematic areas, at different scales and in other organizational infrastructures. These centers are also contributors as components of the NIS. It is criticized that the definition of DC and support criterias in design policies are not inclusive and target-oriented enough, regarding the development of NDS. Because when we look at the literature on the scope of DCs and the application examples abroad; collaboration, dissemination, and knowledge transfer are also encouraged, laboratory structures are at the forefront, experimental methods are applied, the participation of different stakeholders, including the target beneficiary group in the processes is encouraged, as well as the production of knowledge and innovation. Besides, the centers that focus on social benefit are taken into consideration, open innovation principles are applied, and outward-looking, transparent, sharing, and unifying roles come to the fore. When we look at the infrastructure related to DC policies in TR, it has been determined that these features have been ignored, and the framework of the support is shaped in the axis of the commercial activities of the enterprises that meet certain quantitative conditions. In the conclusion part of the thesis, as a part of the 'Creative Economy and Innovation Ecosystem' in TR, final statements, and suggestions are presented on how the 'Design Centers' should be structured to create added value, what kind of background they should be supported with, and what would be the favorable conditions to achieve desired situations. Stakeholders and impact dynamics in the DC ecosystem have been mapped, and the ‘Vortex model for the DC ecosystem' has been defined as a new theoretical model proposal. Within the scope of this model, supporting conditions have been defined by emphasizing the effect-response relationship so that DC activities that contribute to the development of the creative economy and innovation ecosystem can be realized. Final recommendations are prescribed for short/medium/long term under strategic requirements, the infrastructure supporting innovation development, and the infrastructure supporting collaborations and interactions.

Full text: Not available.

Subject: Design; Middle Eastern studies; Mechanics

Classification: 0389: Design; 0346: Mechanics; 0555: Middle Eastern Studies

Identifier / keyword: National Innovation System; Design policies; Design promotion

URL: https://hdl.handle.net/20.500.14124/5417

Title: Türkiye’de tasarım merkezi ekosisteminde strateji ve politikaların etkilerine yönelik durum analizi

Alternate title: Situation Analysis on the Effects of Strategies and Policies on the Design Center Ecosystem in Turkey

Publication year: 2023

Degree date: 2023

Tapping into Retirees to Bolster Knowledge Transfer

Author: Ritter, Beth M, CCP1; Clark, Robert L, PhD11 North Carolina State University

Publication info: Ritter, Beth M, CCP; Clark, Robert L, PhD. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/tapping-into-retirees-bolster-knowledge-transfer/docview/2919464239/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Preservation of knowledge by an organization is critical for ongoing success. The knowledge transfer between retirees and their entity's remaining employees offers a unique opportunity to retain knowledge. Employers that engage with employees prior to their retirement can allow for a longer and more productive knowledge transfer process. The aim of our research has been to learn how to make knowledge exchanges successful by considering methods. Managers should consider new efforts for knowledge-continuity management. Multiple surveys were designed to determine the extent of knowledge-loss risk associated with retirees, the prevalence of informal and formal knowledge-transfer practices and the effectiveness of knowledge transfer for knowledge continuity. Results showed that organizations perceive significant knowledge-loss risk with the impending wave of retirements from an aging workforce and that many are not proactively approaching this opportunity. Organizations are leveraging only a few knowledge-transfer approaches and not leveraging technology for tacit knowledge transfers to occur. The data indicate that there is considerable room for improvement in knowledge-transfer practices - and our research offers practical implications for effective knowledge-transfer activities.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Beth&amp;aulast=Ritter&amp;atitle=Tapping+into+Retirees+to+Bolster+Knowledge+Transfer&amp;stitle=The+Journal+of+Total+Rewards&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Tapping+into+Retirees+to+Bolster+Knowledge+Transfer&amp;volume=32&amp;issue=1&amp;date=First+Quarter+2023&amp;spage=8&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Beth&amp;aulast=Ritter&amp;atitle=Tapping+into+Retirees+to+Bolster+Knowledge+Transfer&amp;stitle=The+Journal+of+Total+Rewards&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Tapping+into+Retirees+to+Bolster+Knowledge+Transfer&amp;volume=32&amp;issue=1&amp;date=First+Quarter+2023&amp;spage=8&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Full text: Headnote "I ran a complex program alone and having time together to go through everything would have been helpful. As it was, we had 3.5 days." - A recent retiree
Preservation of knowledge by an organization is critical for ongoing success. The knowledge transfer between retirees and their entity's remaining employees offers a unique opportunity to retain knowledge. Employers that engage with employees prior to their retirement can allow for a longer and more productive knowledge transfer process. The aim of our research has been to learn how to make knowledge exchanges successful by considering methods. Managers should consider new efforts for knowledge-continuity management. Multiple surveys were designed to determine the extent of knowledge-loss risk associated with retirees, the prevalence of informal and formal knowledge-transfer practices and the effectiveness of knowledge transfer for knowledge continuity. Results showed that organizations perceive significant knowledge-loss risk with the impending wave of retirements from an aging workforce and that many are not proactively approaching this opportunity. Organizations are leveraging only a few knowledge-transfer approaches and not leveraging technology for tacit knowledge transfers to occur. The data indicate that there is considerable room for improvement in knowledge-transfer practices - and our research offers practical implications for effective knowledge-transfer activities.
INTRODUCTION AND CHALLENGE
Most entities have a relatively large group of older workers who are eligible to retire. In the past, many organizations have encouraged older workers to retire to promote upward mobility and allow for the continued introduction of new skills. However, in recent years, given the aging of the global labor force, many organizations are finding it more difficult to recruit and retain enough young and middle-age workers to offset the loss of older workers. The share of the population age 60 and older is projected to increase in nearly every country from 2005 through 2050. Population aging will tend to lower labor-force participation. (Bloom et al. 2010). Add the impacts of the COVID pandemic to that employment dynamic, and organizations could be confronting a substantial loss of knowledge. Each time an employee leaves, an organization risks losing essential knowledge. Without some proactive measures and focus by management, considerable knowledge will continue to leave organizations, eroding their competitive positions. Our research and this paper explore knowledge-continuity management to understand the effectiveness of current institutional knowledge-sharing programs. We study the types and prevalence of knowledge-transfer practices being utilized. We then propose that proactive work, specifically with future retirees, offers a meaningful chance to reduce an organization's knowledge loss. In addition to sharing research, we will offer insights from recent retirees' perspectives and practical advice to minimize the departure of knowledge and experience associated with retirements.
LITERATURE REVIEW OF KNOWLEDGE CONTINUITY
Knowledge management is about finding and developing the right body of knowledge and about using the knowledge to an advantage. According to Durst and Zieba (2019), knowledge loss is a consequence that occurs when an organization loses all or parts of its crucial knowledge from an employee leaving. It can also be from a technical failure, such as a computer breakdown, but our focus will be on departing employees. Knowledge continuity is the efficient and effective transfer of information and knowledge from departing employees to their replacements. Beazley, Boenisch, and Harden (2003) provided a summary of the origins of knowledge management and declared knowledge continuity to be a new management function in their work in 2003. So, managers have been building, and must continue to build, a competency in ensuring knowledge continuity within their departments. Management invests resources to do this because knowledge is a source of competitive advantage for organizations (Beazley, Boenisch, and Harden 2003).
Research indicates two types of knowledge - tacit and explicit. Tacit knowledge is difficult to express, formalize or share, but provides competitive advantage. This is the knowledge that you want to retain and share within your organization, but you do not want it to be shared externally. Roy Lubrit in "Organizational Dynamics" (2001) said that tacit knowledge is the know-how or skills, the ways of solving problems, the mental models or the organizational routines and the knowledge that is embedded in individuals. Alavi and Leidner (2001) summarized more descriptions of knowledge as the "know why," the "know when," and the "know with" knowledge, because it is the ability for one to know why something has or has not happened and what to do at the right time and with whom. Explicit knowledge is documented or codified knowledge, such as job aids and workflows. But one might need the tacit knowledge to interpret the explicit knowledge. Unit performance can depend on the ability to turn knowledge into the right actions.
Effective knowledge sharing or transfer can reduce the learning curve for new hires and internal employees and preserve the knowledge that the organization has invested to develop. This successful transfer of knowledge results in better decision making or fewer operational mistakes for the organization and its customers (Beazley, Boenisch, and Harden, 2003). The two-party process includes those who convey knowledge and those who receive knowledge. Since the process involves people, it can be hampered by motivation, trust, relational competence, common language, culture and the type of knowledge itself (Tangaraja et al. 2016; Alavi and Leidner 2001). We advocate that leaders should be working to create an environment for the effective transfer of knowledge for knowledge continuity and that their support of this effort will be an enabler for it.
DATA AND METHODS
In a series of surveys, we have developed a research methodology that provides an understanding of how both risk managers and recent retirees are thinking about knowledge transfer as a risk - a risk that is increasing with the increase in retirements. We partnered with two organizations to understand perceptions of risk, which tactics or knowledge-transfer approaches are in use in organizations, and what attempts at transferring knowledge between retirees and remaining employees are happening. Because knowledge loss is a risk to organizations, we partnered with the Enterprise Risk Management Initiative at North Carolina State University to survey risk managers about the current knowledge-transfer practices of organizations. The survey had 119 responses, with 34% of respondents coming from private for-profit entities, 31% from publicly traded firms, 19% from nonprofit entities and 16% from government agencies. Our respondents were almost evenly split between international and U.S. entities. Fifty-one percent of respondents were from organizations headquartered in the United States with only U.S. employees. The international perspective is represented by 49% of respondents. Twenty-seven percent of respondents were employed by U.S.-headquartered multinational entities with both global and U.S.-based employees, 13% were employed by internationally headquartered multinational entities with no U.S.-based employees, while 9% were employed by internationally headquartered multinational entities with U.S.-based employees. From a size perspective, 31% percent of respondents employed more than 5,000 employees, while 20% employed from 1,000 to 5,000 employees.
To further confirm or test our findings, we also partnered with Osher Lifelong Learning Institutes (OLLI) to access recent retirees to learn the knowledge-transfer practices they utilized as they attempted to share knowledge. Via survey, we were able to reach a group of 200 OLLI members who retired in the past five years. Osher Institutes deliver non-credit courses and educational activities specifically designed for people who are 50 or older. Nine sites throughout the United States agreed to share the survey with their members, and 205 people responded to the survey request, with only five reporting that they retired outside our five-year timeframe. The breakdown of numbers and percentages of the 200 respondents that met our criteria is evenly distributed with retirees from each of the years from 2016 to 2021. The breakdown by year of retirement was: 2016, 53 respondents or 26.5% of respondents; 2017, 33 or 16.5%; 2018, 43 or 21.5%; 2019, 32 or 16.0%; 2020, 27 or 13.5%; and 2021,12 or 6.0%.
In our surveys, we asked about the extent of knowledge-loss risk perceived with impending retirements, the effectiveness of knowledge-transfer practices, and the approaches used for knowledge transfer with retirees. We also asked retirees for their advice to improve the knowledge-transfer process. Respondents wrote in response to the question, "What, if anything, could the company have done to improve this process?"
RESEARCH RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Our first finding is that risk managers identify the potential knowledge loss associated with retirees to be a risk in the next three to five years, but the extent of risk varied. Survey respondents were asked "To what extent does your organization face a risk of significant loss of knowledge due to an aging workforce who may leave the organization in the next 3-5 years?" While 43.7% of the overall group found the knowledge-loss risk to be somewhat significant, risk managers from governmental entities indicated this risk as more significant, with 73.7% identifying the risk as "extensive" or "mostly extensive" (see Table 1).
Next, we sought to learn about which methods or approaches entities were using in their efforts to minimize loss of knowledge. We identified 11 potential knowledge-transfer practices that organizations may be using to enable the knowledge-transfer process. We separately asked the risk managers as well as the recent retirees which methods were utilized. The retirees' perspectives confirmed the results. Our findings from both groups are summarized in Table 2, where we list the 11 potential knowledge-transfer practices and how prevalent they were in organizations as ranked by risk managers and recent retirees. Respondents of the surveys were instructed to indicate as many activities as necessary to represent the entirety of activities occurring in their organization to share knowledge between sender and receiver. One interesting finding is that both groups' rankings reinforce that on-the-job training with shadowing and one-to-one mentoring are the most often used approaches.
Another observation is that technology-based knowledge-sharing practices were some of the least utilized by respondents and retirees. For example, collaborative software solutions such as wikis or blogs ranked low in usage on both lists. Artificial intelligence (AI) systems ranked the least used by both groups.
It is important to determine how effective these knowledge-sharing approaches were perceived to be. Responses were quite telling when asked to determine "How effective your organization's processes are for helping transfer critical knowledge from employees as they retire to others in the workforce who will remain." Thirty-seven percent of responding risk managers indicated the processes were "minimally effective," while 42% indicated "somewhat effective."
To continue to learn about current practices, one can consider the number of different activities in use within an entity. Once again, we see consistency in our separate survey responses, where one to four practices were most indicated, and rarely were seven or more different approaches used in one organization. Figure 1 illustrates the data and the decrease in number of methods used after the combined use of three or four knowledge-transfer methods.
To round out this research, we asked how well organizations effectively transfer knowledge. Four out of five (79%) surveyed professionals said their organization's knowledge-transfer efforts are either "somewhat effective" or "minimally effective." This implies that there is room for improvement in the knowledge sharing in most organizations. The other finding is that 25% to 28% of organizations are using just one knowledge-transfer approach. This suggests that improvements to the knowledge-transfer process may occur simply by increasing the number of approaches. Another consideration for improving the transfer would be to consider new approaches. Those approaches that use technology and those that involve groups were some of the least used by all respondents.
Last, when checking this data by retirement year, we found two interesting patterns of responses. First, the use of collaborative software only began in 2018. Second, knowledge transfer appeared to become more formal in 2020, as there were no formal knowledge-transfer processes for retirees.
After considering the knowledge-transfer methods being used by organizations, managers should consider how a unit develops knowledge-transfer policies and programs that will be successful and allow for an orderly knowledge transfer. We offer the following considerations for managers and leverage the open responses of retirees as well as outline further research in our recommendations.
PRACTICAL PROGRAMS AND APPROACHES
First, identify critical knowledge and the knowledge holders
In their work on knowledge-continuity management, Bidian and Evans (2019) suggested that managers should conduct a knowledge audit to identify critical or valuable knowledge and use strategic plans to determine a time horizon for how long this knowledge is needed. Once critical knowledge is identified, then one must consider who holds that knowledge. A manager may know this for their immediate area, but if one is working at an enterprise level, an organization chart or job description database may be the first sources to identify knowledge by role. Another approach is to access HR metrics to predict individuals at risk of leaving and compare that list of employees to the lists of critical knowledge. The metrics can be as simple as the ages of the workforce or could be voluntary turnover rates. In this paper, we advocate that leaders focus efforts to support the knowledge transfer of retirees and that they prioritize this over the knowledge transfer of other departing employees, for two reasons. The first is that under the right conditions, when the retiree feels secure in a job and valued, that employee is more likely to give a longer notice than an employee resigning will provide. Our research confirmed that notice period for retirees to be a mechanism to support effective knowledge transfer. The second reason is that impending retirement is more predictable than other voluntary turnover scenarios and that predictability lends itself to planning and effectiveness. This effort and focus allow an entity to make an assessment for each potential retiree. One can imagine a question similar to this: "Is there critical knowledge that needs to be retained by the organization before this individual retires, and can we begin this process well before they retire?"
Next, make the ask
Once critical knowledge is identified and it is determined that a retiree may be the holder of that information, a leader needs to manage the knowledge-sharing process. Only one-third of retirees we surveyed were asked to share knowledge with others inside the organization. Even acknowledging that some work may not have been worthy of knowledge transfer, it seems that increasing the number of people asked to knowledge-share might help to improve the effectiveness. We propose having a supportive and assuring conversation with the individual who holds the key knowledge to learn about their retirement plans and ask for their advice on a good transfer strategy.
Consider this real-life example. A function leader in an organization was approached by her manager, a person she trusted, and was asked if others knew what she knew. They discussed if there were internal employees who might know the same information. They agreed there was not really anyone who shared her knowledge. This is more than a conversation about successors. It is about learning if others in the entity know the explicit or tacit knowledge that she knew. The manager then asked what her desired retirement date was, indicating that she hoped it was not soon. The employee felt comfortable to share that she was about five years away from retirement. The two then created a formal plan for her to begin a process to share her knowledge with a colleague. The subject-matter expert was to begin knowledge sharing with the other person, and boundaries were set that she should not exceed 50% of the receiver's time. The person was not necessarily her successor. The interviewee shared she may not have revealed her retirement plans to her new leader if there was no trust between them. The new leader expressed the person's value and the organization's vulnerability if she were to leave. Kudos to the manager who first identified critical knowledge the organization needed that was held by one source and then conducted a productive conversation to get the knowledge-transfer process started. A fiveyear plan like the one described may not be workable for most critical knowledge holders, but the model of iterative conversations to identify receivers and a plan is attractive.
Remember, time is of the essence
Our research of open responses from recent retirees tells us that time is often not factored into the knowledge-sharing scenario. Speaking with senior employees early about their timing preferences for retirement allows for a longer time for knowledge transfer compared to the short time that a voluntary resignation and a two-week notice provides. It may mean that work is restructured for both the knowledge conveyer and the knowledge receiver(s) to allow extra time for this activity. There may be an extra expense to having several people learning and observing, but the redundancy may increase the chances of successful knowledge transfer, specifically for tacit knowledge. One retiree's advice was to "start (the) transfer of knowledge and building of relationships early in (the) process" and allocate time up front "instead of working in crisis mode up till the last minute."
Open your mind to potential knowledge receivers
Next, work to identify potential knowledge receivers. Think more broadly than finding a perfect "ready now" successor from the succession charts. Often terms such as "ready now" and "ready in 1-3 years" are used to classify internal employees for succession. One might argue that your "ready-now candidate" has already left or is interviewing, so an organization may be best served to invest in knowledge transfer with more than one person and with those who may seem less ready than you'd like. The advice we learned from recent retirees even highlighted the need for a solid plan for knowledge management when outsourcing. An outsourced activity requires monitoring and management and the knowledge to do that. Consider a knowledge transfer from the retiree to whichever department will become the outsource vendor manager as effective knowledge continuity management of outsourced activities. Also, think about how the knowledge can be shared with more than one person to improve your odds of retaining the knowledge and how that knowledge transfer can be positioned as career enhancing for those who are less experienced.
Research by Fasbender, Gerpott, and Unger (2021) indicated that receivers who are motivated to grow, increase competence and master new skills and knowledge are better receivers. Being an insider, someone who knows the entity, adds an advantage to the successful knowledge transfer. If you must go externally for a candidate, allow for longer-than-expected times to fill the role and expect more of a learning curve as the person learns both the company and the knowledge. A recent retiree said that to improve the knowledge sharing, the organization could have "hired a replacement with some level of institutional and program knowledge - at least a foundation to build upon." If that is not possible, having several employees within the organization who already have some knowledge because of previous successful knowledge-sharing efforts can support new hires more effectively.
Now, consider the type of knowledge and which transfer practices are best suited
As described earlier, organizations are most often using on-the-job training, job shadowing and one-to-one mentoring to attempt their knowledge transfers but are not always satisfied with the effectiveness of the transfers. Research indicates that working with a coach or expert to learn tacit knowledge is most effective when the receiver of the knowledge can problem-solve with the expert or learn their decision-making process experientially. This takes time. In his work on tacit knowledge transfer, Lubrit (2001) offered the idea that structured group discussions are a way to increase the numbers of people who have access to the expert and their expertise. As you consider the list of 11 knowledge-transfer tactics (see Table 2) and the idea that structured group activities may increase access to knowledge, two moderately used options stand out as options to make knowledge transfers more efficient and effective.
Consider the use of communities of practice and after-action reviews. Communities of practice, also called centers of excellence, are groups that regularly convene and share information. They often cross traditional organizational structures, allowing all levels of the entity to participate and learn from others outside their formal departments. These are often set up for a specific discipline or process. If a manager were to direct the center of excellence to focus on critical knowledge that was identified in a knowledge audit, group members can begin the sharing process earlier and add time to what has historically been rushed knowledge-transfer activities. They can also improve the format for the knowledge transfer by allowing topics to be more problem solving in nature and less like forced explicit knowledge exchanges. Greene offered an interesting example in his work on knowledge management (Greene 2020). He told of Xerox repair technicians who created an informal breakfast club where they shared solutions to difficult problems that did not appear in repair manuals. This form of applied learning benefited the company. It would also be beneficial to encourage them to document what they learn.
Next, consider after-action reviews. These have a heritage in the Army, but the concept may also be a way to pivot your current knowledge-transfer approaches to become more effective. A large construction business shared its approach to after-action reviews using the following questions after a planned activity:
| What was supposed to happen? What happened?
| What went well? Why?
| What could be improved? How?
A manager can strategically choose which activities are worth this deliberate expense of time by using the knowledge audit of critical knowledge. The structure of the questions allows experts to unpack their knowledge in a way that shares their logic, which is more effective for tacit knowledge sharing and receiving.
Knowledge-management systems provide another opportunity for knowledge transfer identified from the utilization data in Table 2. Technology or systems are not highly leveraged. Systems can be enablers of knowledge sharing, but we saw collaborative software was not often used and retirees in our survey only reported its use starting in 2018. One might speculate that COVID-related experiences with technology may have increased the usage of these tools, but our data for 2020 and 2021 retirees do not indicate an increase in the use of collaborative tools in the knowledge-transfer process. Collaborative software can facilitate global, remote and other distributed organization interaction. Center of excellence exchanges and after-action reviews can become an even more significant resource for knowledge sharing with many when enabled by collaborative technology.
Consider adding new tricks to your current knowledge-continuity goals to increase the number of approaches your organization utilizes. Once you have identified the critical knowledge, the person who holds that knowledge and the potential receivers, then consider increasing the types of knowledge-transfer approaches. Our research with both organizations and retirees indicates 53% to 56% of organizations are using only one or two approaches. Building a competency for knowledge transfer may involve learning about alternative methods that are available for this work and then expanding the types of approaches. Managers should leverage more critical knowledge-focused group approaches such as communities of practice or centers of excellence. They should implement strategic after-action reviews and support those activities with collaborative software to amplify the reach of these actions to more people. The biggest mind shift for managers may be thinking less about one successor and more about ongoing knowledge sharing to larger groups.
PROVIDE STRUCTURE AND CLARITY TO THE PROCESS
Recent retirees indicate clarity of purpose, documentation and role specification is needed from managers to support effective transfer. Twenty percent of those who wrote comments in our survey discussed these types of topics in their advice to improve knowledge transfers. Hofer-Alfeis (2008) offered a detailed process that can be considered. We highlight a few of the questions from that paper here as ideas in your efforts for more clarity. For example, what are business-critical relationships and knowledge networks that need to be created by the retiree and the unit? What are the knowledge assets needed, the documentation and where will it be stored and by whom and when?
LASTLY, CONSIDER CULTURE
Building a competency for knowledge transfer in an organization will also require a culture that values this work. Measurements, rewards, policies and practices reinforce company values. One way to demonstrate the importance is to measure the completion and effectiveness of this work. One could measure if there is a formal and specific plan with content and knowledge-transfer goals for each critical-knowledge category identified in your audit and for each departing retiree who holds that information. Then ultimately measure and give visibility to whether those goals are achieved. Another way to reinforce a culture of knowledge sharing is to implement new policies or programs that support the effort.
The U.S. government's phased-retirement program is an interesting example. Named the Moving Ahead Program, it allows future retirees to shift to a parttime status where they work reduced hours as they begin retirement. The work schedule shifts to one that is half work and half retirement, but with an important stipulation. The program includes a requirement that 20% of hours worked need to be focused on knowledge-sharing activities. That 20% focus and formalization is the critical knowledge-transfer enabler (Clark and Ritter 2020a). Our surveys and workshops from 2018 to 2020 indicated that most companies were not pursuing phased-retirement plans because of management and cost issues (Clark et al. 2019, Clark and Ritter 2020b). Recent Mercer research findings indicate a shift has occurred and offerings of these programs have doubled since before the pandemic (Tergesen and Weber 2022).
Last, you may also want to consider ending a policy or activity. The use of earlyretirement programs that accelerate the rate of retirements has been a practice for workforce reduction for many years. This practice may no longer be prudent. In fact, we found that 60% of risk managers indicated early-retirement packages were not offered in the past year at their organization. An early-retirement incentive could be sending the signal that there is no knowledge to capture from this group and could be accelerating knowledge loss. Leaders must consider all ways to build a knowledge culture and indicate their support of knowledgesharing activities.
CONCLUSIONS AND IMPLICATIONS FOR MANAGERS
So, what do these findings mean for managers? How can one focus efforts to increase effectiveness of knowledge transfer and minimize knowledge loss? Future retirees can be a potential significant knowledge loss for organizations and, accordingly, this loss is a knowledge-continuity management issue. Our previous research found that orderly retirement of employees is important to business strategy, with 83% of respondents indicating knowledge transfer as a key concern (Clark et al. 2019). We propose that managers focus efforts and resources on future retirees. This offers a more predictable knowledge loss that can be better managed than knowledge loss from other types of employee turnover. We offer practical approaches to be taken to transfer knowledge before it leaves with those retirees.
Recent retiree feedback allows for a view into the knowledge-exchange attempts in the past five years. Their feedback indicates that most efforts were rushed, informal and did not consider the best receivers of the knowledge. Managers hoping for knowledge continuity should conduct a knowledge audit to determine critical information and then consider if potential retirees hold that critical knowledge. They should engage knowledge holders who are potential retirees in a conversation about knowledge sharing of the critical information and develop formal plans with longer time horizons. Those plans should consider knowledge-transfer practices that are problem solving in nature and enable sharing with many instead of with only one person. Efforts should be shifted away from one-to-one, role-based knowledge sharing and succession to efforts that support a culture of knowledge transfer to many people in approaches that better support tacit knowledge transfer and with technology to enable knowledge continuity.
LIMITATIONS AND POTENTIAL AVENUES FOR FUTURE RESEARCH
While our research was novel with the identification of 11 methods for knowledge transfer and the inclusion of recent retirees to learn about recent knowledgetransfer activities, it did not collect demographic data on either the retiree or the knowledge receiver. Future research into the ages and genders of the participants in the knowledge-transfer process should include this data to determine if there is any bias that could inhibit the effective knowledge transfer that may need to be mitigated. While our research indicates a need for more time to support effective knowledge transfer, we did not survey to learn about the ideal time for the knowledge transfer. Future research should explore the time needed for a range of activities from complex to the least complex transfers.
Sidebar AUTHORS' NOTE: We thank the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation for a series of grants that have supported our research. We appreciate the support of the North Carolina State Enterprise Risk Management Initiative (ERM) and several Osher Lifelong Learning Institutes. We appreciate the support of Patrick Royal on analysis and charts.
ABOUT THE AUTHOR
Beth M. Ritter, CCP, fbmritte2@ncsu.edu) is a professor of practice in the Department of Management, Innovation and Entrepreneurship at North Carolina State University, where she teaches and conducts research about human resources and talent management issues. Prior to joining NC State, Ritter was a senior vice president of human resources at Burt's Bees, which is now a part of Clorox. She received an MBA from Old Dominion University and a BA in labor studies from Pennsylvania State University. Ritter is a member of WorldatWork's Editorial Advisory Council.
Robert L. Clark, Ph.D., frobert clarkrancsu.edu) is a professor in the Department of Economics and the Department of Management, Innovation and Entrepreneurship in the Poole College of Management at North Carolina State University. He teaches and conducts research focused on the economic aspects of population and workforce aging, specifically, how organizations develop compensation policies to attract, retain, motivate and ultimately retire quality workers. He received his Ph.D. in economics from Duke University.

Pictoquizezz: Engaging Cognitive Learning

Author: Gladiss Merlin N R1; Tamizh, Malar S, G1; Prathiksha, K1; Nivedha, P1; Pavithra, K11 R.M.K Engineering College,Department of ADS,Tiruvallur,Tamil Nadu

Publication info: Gladiss Merlin N R; Tamizh, Malar S, G; Prathiksha, K; Nivedha, P; Pavithra, K. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/pictoquizezz-engaging-cognitive-learning/docview/2909272340/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2023 International Conference on Research Methodologies in Knowledge Management, Artificial Intelligence and Telecommunication Engineering (RMKMATE) Conference Start Date: 2023, Nov. 1 Conference End Date: 2023, Nov. 2 Conference Location: Chennai, India In the era of virtual interactions, finding innovative ways to engage participants in activities such as quizzes can be exciting. One captivating approach is hosting a virtual quiz without relying on keyboards and a mouse but solely utilizing webcams, active internet, and hand gestures. The virtual quiz utilizes computer vision algorithms to detect and track hand gestures through participants' webcams. By mapping specific gestures to different quiz actions, participants can select answers and interact with the quiz interface without the need for traditional input devices. Participants are presented with a series of questions displayed on the screen, and they can indicate their chosen answer by making specific hand gestures. Monitor the participants' webcam feeds attentively to identify their hand gestures. Provide immediate feedback on the accuracy of their responses, indicating whether they are correct or incorrect. This feedback mechanism ensures that the quiz serves as an educational tool, promoting a continuous learning experience. The use of AI in virtual quizzes can enhance the experience by providing personalized learning time-saving quiz generation, instant feedback, and adaptable difficulty. By leveraging webcam technology and hand gestures, this virtual quiz offers a novel and immersive approach to quiz participation. The virtual quiz employs computer vision algorithms to identify and monitor hand movements using participants' webcams. This innovative concept aims to create a fun and engaging experience for participants, encouraging active participation and knowledge retention through gesture-based interactions.

MKGS: Maintains the Original Structure of Knowledge Graph

Author: Yao, Zheng1; Cen, Jianhe1; Sun, Shiqi1; Yin, Dahu1; Li, Jingyuan2; Wang, Yuanzhuo31 Zhengzhou University,Zhengzhou,China2 Beijing Technology and Business University,Beijing,China3 Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences,Beijing,China

Publication info: Yao, Zheng; Cen, Jianhe; Sun, Shiqi; Yin, Dahu; Li, Jingyuan; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/mkgs-maintains-original-structure-knowledge-graph/docview/2904606228/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2023 IEEE International Conference on Web Intelligence and Intelligent Agent Technology (WI-IAT) Conference Start Date: 2023, Oct. 26 Conference End Date: 2023, Oct. 29 Conference Location: Venice, Italy In the field of graph-generated text, one of the core issues commonly explored is how to maintain the structural information of the graph to the maximum extent and reduce the problem of knowledge loss during training. Current research has mainly focused on exploring the ability of models to learn graph structures by increasing model size and refining the graph representation. In contrast, our work emphasizes the importance of perceiving and exploring edges in the graph itself. Edges provide a wide variety of structures to the graph structure, offering it freedom and diversity. Therefore, improving the model's ability to perceive edges could potentially enhance the task metrics of graph generation for text. To address this, we propose a graph-generated text model MKGS that maintains the original structure of the knowledge graph, effectively reducing knowledge loss during the learning process. Our approach achieves this at three levels: reorganizing the knowledge sequence as input to the model, enhancing edge perception during processing, and incorporating a graph rational activation function at the output. We validate our method using the Kg-to-text benchmark dataset WebNLG, where MKGS achieves a score of 66.22%. Additionally, the model exhibits fewer syntactic errors and produces smoother expressions in the generated text.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Zheng&amp;aulast=Yao&amp;atitle=MKGS%3A+Maintains+the+Original+Structure+of+Knowledge+Graph&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FWI-IAT59888.2023.00074&amp;title=MKGS%3A+Maintains+the+Original+Structure+of+Knowledge+Graph&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Zheng&amp;aulast=Yao&amp;atitle=MKGS%3A+Maintains+the+Original+Structure+of+Knowledge+Graph&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FWI-IAT59888.2023.00074&amp;title=MKGS%3A+Maintains+the+Original+Structure+of+Knowledge+Graph&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;
