This paper contributes to the strategic human resource management (SHRM), comparative institutional perspectives on HR strategies and practices, and the literature on the green economy and the development of green skills in firms in the following ways. First, this paper focuses on examining how the institutional context of Thailand shapes the development of green knowledge and skills among employees across firms in Thailand. In this regard, the paper aims to fill the gap in the literature on strategic HRM and comparative institutional perspectives on HR strategies and practices as proposed by Batt and Banerjee (2012) and Batt and Hermans (2012), who suggested that the literature on strategic HRM should go beyond the organizational context and examine how firms adopt and implement HR practices in response to the national institutional context. Second, the paper aims to extend the literature on the green economy regarding the roles played by institutional factors in shaping the development of green knowledge and skills across firms. Finally, strategic HRM, comparative institutional perspectives on HR strategies and practices and green economy studies have overlooked the under-researched country of Thailand. Most studies in these three areas focus more on developed countries. Thus, the findings of this paper should extend the literature on those areas regarding the development of green skills among employees across firms in response to the Thai institutional context.
Literature review and theoretical framework
The following three main bodies of literature are reviewed to help develop the theoretical framework used in this paper: the roles of institutional contexts, strategic HRM and the green economy and the development of green skills across firms. Additionally, the institutional context in Thailand in terms of the education and skill-formation system is reviewed to provide a better understanding of how this context shapes the development of the green skills examined in this paper.
The roles of institutional contexts
The comparative institutional theory (Aguilera and Grogaard, 2019; Kostova et al ., 2019; Morgan et al ., 2010; Hall and Soskice, 2001; Streeck and Thelen, 2005; Whitley, 1999) proposes that national institutions play a key role in shaping and constraining firm-level behaviors and HR strategies and practices adopted and implemented across these firms (Batt and Hermans, 2012). One of the popular frameworks for comparative institutional theory that examines the role of institutions in each country is the varieties of capitalism (VoC) framework (Hall and Soskice, 2001). Hall and Soskice argued that to develop and coordinate core competencies, firms must maintain various relationships within five institutional domains, including the education and skill-formation system.
Here, the education and skill-formation system refers to the full range of formal and informal vocational, technical and skills-based education and training for employment in each country. Specifically, in countries with liberal market economies (LMEs), such as the US and the UK, the system offers formal education that focuses on general instead of firm- or industry-specific skills. In other words, firms in LMEs are reluctant to develop managerial and professional employees internally and to invest in firm-specific training (Hall and Soskice, 2001; Napathorn, 2018a). By contrast, in countries in coordinated market economies (CMEs) such as Germany, the national education and skill-formation system provides workers with firm- or industry-specific skills (Finegold and Wagner, 2002). Specifically, firms in CMEs such as Germany pay more attention to the internal development of managerial and professional employees and invest in firm-specific training instead of general training (Crouch, 2005; Finegold, 1999; Culpepper, 1999; Napathorn, 2018a). In this regard, the national education and skill-formation system plays a supporting role in supplying a skilled workforce that responds to the needs of industries and firms and in alleviating the country's skill shortage (Finegold et al ., 2000). However, other systems, such as those in the US, may not play this role due to their sole focus on general training.
In fact, the skill shortage problem is particularly severe in emerging market economies (Napathorn, 2020). Kuruvilla and Ranganathan (2008) examined the business process outsourcing (BPO) industry in India and proposed that the primary macro HR problem in India is the shortage of a skilled workforce (i.e. managerial and professional employees). Specifically, India's education and skill-formation system cannot produce a sufficient number of software engineers and high-skilled manpower that the BPO industry will need. Therefore, firms in the BPO industry are reluctant to invest in the internal development of their managerial and professional employees. Rather, there has been an increase in poaching in this industry. In addition to India, Thailand has faced a skill shortage problem in the labor market because the Thai education and skill-formation system is not likely to produce qualified employees for firms across several industries (Napathorn, 2018a).
Strategic HRM
Within the strategic HRM (SHRM) literature, the development of HR systems and practices that achieve both horizontal fit and vertical fit enables the organization to achieve its objectives/goals (Wright and McMahan, 1992; Baird and Meshoulam, 1988; Delery, 1998; Napathorn, 2018b; Kehoe, 2021). Horizontal fit refers to internal consistency among HR practices within an organization, whereas vertical fit refers to the alignment of the HR systems and practices with other organizational characteristics such as business strategies or organizational objectives/goals (Baird and Meshoulam, 1988; Delery, 1998).
In terms of the vertical fit, it is important to match HR systems and practices with the organization's strategies or objectives/goals. In other words, the fit between the HR systems and the organization's strategies or objectives/goals is important as it leads to superior organizational performance (Baird and Meshoulam, 1988). For instance, Wright et al . (1995), Youndt et al . (1996) and Chadwick et al . (2013) empirically tested the vertical fit argument and emphasized the need to match HR systems and practices with business strategies or organizational objectives/goals to maximize organizational performance.
However, Batt and Banerjee (2012), Batt and Hermans (2012), Napathorn (2018a) and Napathorn (2020) proposed that the literature on strategic HRM has paid too much attention to the organizational context (e.g. the influence of organizations' business strategies on the implementation of HR systems and practices) and should go beyond the organizational context to examine how institutional contexts shape the adoption and implementation of organizations' HR practices.
Green economy and the development of green skills across firms
Within the green economy literature (Pearce et al ., 1989; Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), 2011; United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), 2011; Barbier, 2012; World Bank, 2012a, b; EAA, 2013; European Environment Agency (EEA), 2014; Loiseau et al. , 2016; Policy Research Center on Green Economy at the Faculty of Economics, Thammasat University, 2019; D'Amato et al. , 2017; Merino-Saum et al ., 2020), the concept of a green economy refers to an economic paradigm that simultaneously focuses on both economic development and sustainable environmental conservation. That said, this paradigm assumes that economic advancement and environmental conservation must be in the same direction and must not contradict each other (Maclean et al ., 2017; Tien et al ., 2020). In other words, the development of a green economy and sustainable environmental conservation must not obstruct the wealth creation of the country and must not serve as barriers to the employment of local people. By contrast, the development of a green economy fosters the opportunities of investment in new industries and the development of green jobs in existing industries, leading to job creation for people in that country (Loiseau et al. , 2016; Dordmond et al ., 2021). In particular, the transition toward a green economy maximizes the use of resources such that the younger generations of each country are still able to utilize those resources in the long term (UNEP, 2011; Georgeson et al ., 2017).
Additionally, a green economy is defined as an economic system that leads to the improvement of people's well-being in each country, fosters fairness within society and reduces environmental risks and the shortage of natural resources (Loiseau et al. , 2016; Merino-Saum et al ., 2020). In this regard, the concept of a green economy was proposed by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) to alleviate the problems incurred by liberalism and to move the economic system in a direction that aims for sustainable development (UNEP, 2011; Zhu, 2017).
According to the report by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in 2017, development that aims to decrease carbon emissions into the atmosphere and that pays special attention to the climate does not diminish the economic growth rate of the country. In addition, this development has no impact on the country's competitive advantage and the well-being of people in society. This report also provides the guideline that the government of each country should follow to foster the transition to a green economy (OECD, 2017).
There have been no best practices in creating the green economy across countries because policies and strategies to create the green economy usually depend on the economic condition and contexts of each country. However, every country across the globe, including developed countries, developing countries, emerging market countries and poor countries, can effectively adopt and implement the green economy model, leading to the sustainable growth of economy and society. A green economy will also foster the development of eco-friendly innovations and generate new markets for green technologies, products and services. This will eventually create green jobs for people in that country (World Bank, 2012a, b; OECD, 2011; Loiseau et al. , 2016; Dordmond et al ., 2021).
Nevertheless, the transition toward a green economy and green jobs may result in the displacement of some jobs or skills. At the same time, this transition may lead to the creation of several types of green jobs. In this case, the main challenge is whether the level of knowledge and skills of people in that country is sufficient to allow them to effectively perform green jobs (Maclean et al ., 2017; Bombiak and Marciniuk-Kluska, 2018). Here, “green jobs” refer to jobs that help protect the ecosystem and biodiversity, foster the efficient use of energy and resources, reduce the emission of carbon into the environment and reduce waste and pollution in the environment (UNEP, ILO, International Organization of Employers (IOE), and International Trade Union Confederation (ITUC), 2008, p. 3; Sulich et al ., 2020). These jobs may be found in the agricultural, manufacturing, research and development, and service industries (UNEP, ILO, IOE, and ITUC, 2008, p. 3; Dordmond et al ., 2021). Additionally, green jobs may provide sufficient wages/salaries, safety and security and appropriate rights for employees/workers (UNEP, ILO, IOE, and ITUC, 2008, p. 3).
Typically, employees/workers who perform green jobs must have green skills. In this study, “green skills” refer to skills related to the environmental awareness and sustainability, science, technology, engineering and mathematics required to perform green jobs. Green skills also include the management skills required when organizations are in the process of transitioning from regular jobs to green jobs according to the concept of a green economy. Examples of green skills include efficient energy usage, water resource conservation, wastewater treatment and zero waste management (Heong et al ., 2016; Maclean et al ., 2017; Cecere and Mazzanti, 2017).
The education and skill-formation system plays a crucial role in equipping employees/workers with green knowledge and skills. That is, vocational colleges and/or universities must train their graduates to possess green knowledge and skills. In particular, graduates must be trained to change their attitudes, perspectives and ideas to be ready to perform green jobs. Therefore, the education and skill-formation system must be adapted to fit with the national policy regarding the development of a green economy and to be ready for the transition toward a green economy. However, if employees/workers do not have green skills, they may not be able to achieve the goals of efficiently utilizing several types of natural resources, protecting and conserving the environment while simultaneously generating income and profits for organizations, and reducing the pollution that may be produced in the process.
However, the main problem among countries across the globe is that their education and skill-formation systems may not be able to produce a sufficient number of graduates who have the requisite green knowledge and skills to respond to the needs of industries and firms, leading to a skill shortage problem in the labor market (Napathorn, 2018a, 2020). This problem may result from the fact that the curricula taught in vocational colleges and universities located in those countries do not fit with the need for green skills among firms/industries (UNEP, 2011; Setiawan, 2017). In that case, firms across industries may have to implement several HR practices to solve this macro-level (i.e. national level) HR problem.
Thailand: institutional context
A combination of ordinary education and vocational education characterizes the education and skill-formation system in Thailand (Suehiro and Yabushita, 2014). These two types of educational tracks are divided at the stage of upper secondary education. Due to the fact that the ordinary educational track (standard educational track) became the dominant mode in public education during the past years, the percentage of students in vocational colleges or schools declined from 44% in 1990 to approximately 35% in 2008 (Suehiro and Yabushita, 2014). Later, the government attempted to increase the percentage of students in those colleges/schools to at least 45% in 2019 (ThailandPlus, 2018). In fact, the labor market in Thailand requires a large number of graduates from those institutions. For instance, in 2018, more than 50,000 graduates from vocational colleges/schools were required by firms in the area of the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) of Thailand, whereas vocational colleges in that area cannot produce a sufficient number of graduates to respond to that demand (Katchwattana, 2018).
In particular, although Thailand is “one of the East Asia's most active countries in educational development,” according to Suehiro and Yabushita (2014, p. 273), there are some problems in the Thai education and skill-formation system, including low student achievement, low academic credentials among teachers and a skill shortage and mismatch between education and the labor market. In terms of the skill shortage and mismatch between education and the labor market, this problem is considered to be the most serious for Thailand because the country has entered the upper-middle-income group of countries in 2011 (a country with a per capita gross national income (GNI) between US$3,976 and US$12,276) according to the World Bank (World Bank, 2011). With regard to the skill shortage problem, most companies in Thailand have been unable to fill vacancies within three months (Siam Commercial Bank Economic Intelligence Center, 2015; Bangkok Post, 2019; Napathorn, 2020). The challenge in recruiting university graduates is the lengthy time needed to find individuals with the right skill set. Regarding the skill mismatch, this problem results from the fact that public universities in Thailand have traditionally focused on the skills needed by the bureaucracy (e.g. political science, law and education) instead of the skills needed by private corporations (e.g. business administration, engineering and sciences). The 1997 Asian financial crisis revealed this mismatch of graduate profiles and skills required in the labor market (Pongpaichit and Baker, 1998; Jestin, 2009; Yabushita, 2020). According to OECD (2011), this phenomenon is referred to as “the over-qualified and under-skilled” problem, which is expressed in an imbalance in academic fields at universities (about 45% in social sciences, business and law; about 20% in engineering and natural sciences) (Siam Commercial Bank Economic Intelligence Center, 2015). The Thai government has attempted to improve this situation by implementing the Second 15-Year Educational Development Plan (2008–2022). This plan intends to increase the proportion of university students in natural sciences major to 50% by the year 2022 (Matichon, 2012; Yabushita, 2015).
To alleviate the problems of skill shortage and mismatch, private institutions and corporations in Thailand have established new types of higher educational institutions to meet the needs of the labor market (Suehiro and Yabushita, 2014). The Technology Promotion Association (TPA), for instance, opened the Thai-Nichi Institute of Technology (TNI) in Bangkok in July 2007, in cooperation with the Japanese Chamber of Commerce, to train students in the areas of production technology and practical knowledge in the automotive and electronics industries and in the science of industrial management. At the same time, Japanese firms provide scholarship and internship services for these students. The Charoen Pokphand (CP) Group, the world's largest producer of animal feed and shrimp and one of the leading producers of poultry and food products, with a strong stake in mainland China, opened its own corporate university (the Panyapiwat Institute of Management or PIM) to educate professionals in management including business practices in China (Napathorn and Kuruvilla, 2018). PIM invites Chinese students from abroad and, at the same time, delegates Thai students to China, Japan and countries in Europe. Similarly, PTT Public Company Limited, the largest petrochemical complex listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET), has established its own institution to educate engineers specializing in the petrochemical industry. All of these projects have emerged to solve the problem regarding “a massive under-supply from standard educational institutions of engineers and professionals specializing in several growing industries” (Suehiro and Yabushita, 2014, p. 275) such as the agro food-processing, petrochemical and automotive industries as well as modern retail businesses.
Although Thailand's skill shortage and mismatch have been found to be one of the most serious problems in the nation's education and skill-formation system, and private institutions and corporations have attempted to solve this problem, according to Cha-laamwong (2014), it has persisted and is considered to be one of the threats to the country's ability to extricate itself from the so-called middle-income curse (Napathorn and Kuruvilla, 2018).
Based on the literature review of the three theoretical perspectives (the roles of institutional contexts, strategic HRM, and green economy and the development of green skills across firms); the review of the institutional context in Thailand; the qualitative data obtained from in-depth interviews with a variety of stakeholders including top managers of vocational colleges; top managers and directors of environmental/green management programs at universities across the country; a top executive from the Ministry of Education; top managers and project managers at the Thailand Environmental Institute (an NGO); students who performed green jobs during their internship period or after graduating with a bachelor's degree from Thai universities; and each firm's top managers, HR managers and employees; field visits to vocational colleges, universities, an NGO and firms across industries in both Bangkok and other provinces in Thailand; the non-participant observation of a variety of stakeholders; and a review of archival documents and web-based reports and resources, this paper proposes the following.
Firms across industries in Thailand must be responsible for helping their employees/workers obtain the green knowledge and skills necessary to perform green jobs through high-road HR practices in response to the fact that the Thai education and skill-formation system is unlikely to produce a sufficient number of employees/workers who have green knowledge, skills and abilities and are industry-ready to perform green jobs, leading to a shortage in the labor market of employees/workers who possess green skills. Specifically, curricula in vocational colleges and universities in Thailand are unlikely to respond to the needs of firms in producing those employees/workers.
In sum, this paper aims to fill the research gap by examining the development of green skills among employees across firms in response to the institutional context in terms of the education and skill-formation system of the emerging market economy of Thailand.
Research setting and methodology
Research setting
Thailand has been considered an appropriate site for conducting research on how firms develop green knowledge and skills among employees in response to the institutional context in terms of the education and skill-formation system because the Thai government has attempted to overcome various problems relevant to environmental pollution and climate change, including the severe PM 2.5 dust particle problem, deteriorating natural resources, global warming and the plastic waste crisis (Kraivijitr, 2019). In this regard, the government has recently paid special attention to the sustainable development goal of the country according to the strategy for driving Thailand based on a bioeconomy, circular economy and green economy (BCG economy) model 2021-2026 (NSTDA, 2021). Therefore, the development of green skills among employees has been considered to be a crucial factor in moving the country toward this goal. However, the Thai education and skill-formation system has faced a skill shortage problem in that most firms in Thailand have been unable to fill vacancies within three months and there is a skill mismatch problem in that a majority of university students graduate with degrees in social sciences, business and law, whereas firms need students with the degrees in engineering and sciences (Siam Commercial Bank Economic Intelligence Center, 2015). These two problems might negatively influence the transition of the country toward the BCG economy model. Relatively little research has focused on the adoption and development of green skills among employees across firms in response to the institutional context in terms of the education and skill-formation system of emerging market economies, including Thailand. In this paper, the author thus examines the Thai education and skill-formation system and conducts a cross-case analysis of four firms across different industries in Thailand – SSS Ceramics Public Company Limited in the manufacturing industry, PPP Public Company Limited in the energy industry, Chaophya Park Hotel in the hotel and resort industry and Thanya Shopping Park in the retail industry.
Research methodology
The author qualitatively examined the Thai education and skill-formation system, specifically at the vocational college and university levels, to understand how this system plays a role in producing employees/workers who have green knowledge, skills and abilities. Additionally, the author designed a cross-case comparison of four firms across industries to examine the similarities and/or differences in how these firms develop green skills among employees. Cross-case analysis enables the so-called logic of replication, although each case study confirms or disconfirms arguments regarding the development of green skills among employees drawn from previous cases (Eisenhardt and Bourgeois, 1988). In addition, a cross-case analysis encourages the author to extend initial impressions regarding the data findings (Eisenhardt, 1989) to develop an accurate and reliable theory from the case studies. In fact, this paper uses a qualitative approach − the case study approach − because the nature of this study is exploratory, and the author aims to establish the status quo (Patton, 2002). In addition, the author aims to collect comprehensive and holistic data (Eisenhardt, 1989; Yin, 1994) on the Thai education and skill-formation system and four case study firms. This type of approach also permits the deep exploration of the interactions among several actors at different levels of analysis (Cooke, 2012). The actors in this current study included top managers of vocational colleges; top managers and directors of environmental/green management programs at universities across the country; a top executive from the Ministry of Education; top managers and project managers at the Thailand Environmental Institute (an NGO); students who performed green jobs during their internship period or after graduating with a bachelor's degrees from Thai universities; and each firm's top managers, HR managers and employees.
However, an important recommendation for conducting trustworthy case study research is that the researcher must remain neutral and detached from the cases (Yin, 1984, 2009). Thus, the author attempted to conduct this research and present the findings based on this recommendation. Additionally, another advantage of conducting a cross-case comparison is that it allows for the collection of data using multiple methods such as semi-structured interviews, field observations and analyses of archival documents and web-based resources (Yin, 1994); facilitates the theory-building process (Zhu et al ., 2012); and helps mitigate the problem of single-source bias that might occur when an author relies on only one data source (Napathorn, 2018a). This study also provides data for more extensive research and hypothesis development as part of the ongoing research on green skills and green HRM.
Sampled vocational colleges and universities were purposively selected because these vocational colleges and universities are highly respected and well known in Thailand. These colleges and universities have also offered various educational curricula to a large number of students for quite a long time. Four organizations across industries in Thailand were also selected via purposive sampling (Teddlie and Tashakkori, 2009) because they are located in the key industries that consume large amounts of energy. However, these four organizations have continuously received both national and international awards, such as Thailand Energy Awards and ASEAN Energy Awards, from several organizations for their energy-conservation practices and environmental/green management practices in prior years. Additionally, the top managers of these companies have long paid special attention to the environmental conservation and sustainable growth of their business for a long time and have successfully created green jobs and developed green knowledge and skills among their employees for a certain period. These top managers have always been under the spotlight regarding their green leadership and green management practices. Thus, these four companies should be considered to be good candidates for examining how firms develop green knowledge and skills among employees in response to the national institutional context. In fact, some other companies continuously received both national and international awards for their energy conservation practices and environmental/green management practices in prior years. However, these other companies have not been in the spotlight, and the top managers of these companies are not willing to allow the author to access the data and conduct research concerning this topic. This is one of the reasons that these four companies were purposively selected for this research.
The data in this paper were collected in 2018 and 2019 during approximately 9 months in the field. This research involved 38 semi-structured interviews with a variety of stakeholders including top managers of vocational colleges; top managers and directors of environmental/green management programs at universities across the country; a top executive from the Ministry of Education; top managers and project managers at the Thailand Environmental Institute (an NGO); students who performed green jobs during their internship period or after graduating with a bachelor's degree from Thai universities; and each firm's top managers, HR managers and employees (see Table 1 for a list of interviewees). The age range of the interviewees was between 22 and 65 years. Additionally, this research involved several field visits to vocational colleges, universities, the Ministry of Education, an NGO and firms across industries in both Bangkok and other provinces in Thailand, as well as research using a review of archival documents and web-based reports and resources, including firms' websites (if applicable).
Nonparticipant observation in this study occurred during the pre-interview, interview and post-interview periods. The primary objective of the nonparticipant observation was to observe the characteristics and behaviors of the interviewees and the employees working in the four case companies. In summary, the author collected data for this study via different methods (i.e. semi-structured interviews, nonparticipant observation and reviews of archival documents and web-based resources) to triangulate the data and overcome the single-source bias problem in this paper.
This study, which is a part of a research project on the creation of green jobs and the development of green skills, was ethically approved by the Human Research Ethics Committee of the author's university, which consists of well-known scholars in the social sciences and humanities fields. In particular, this committee reviewed the research project's proposal, the research methodology and interview protocols for approximately 2 months in 2018 before the committee approved the research project. That said, the author was eligible to start collecting the data only after the research project was approved by the committee. To gain access to each of the organizations, the author submitted a formal letter to them (via email and fax), using the fax numbers and email addresses provided on their websites. Each letter described the research project on the creation of green jobs and the development of green skills, provided some preliminary interview questions and asked for approval to conduct interviews with the organizations' representatives, top managers, HR managers and assigned employees. Finally, after waiting for firms' responses for some time, the author obtained permission to conduct the interviews as requested.
Each of the 38 semi-structured interviews lasted between 1.5 and 3.5 h. All of the interviews were conducted face-to-face and in Thai. The author used different interview protocols for each group of interviewees: (1) top managers of vocational colleges and universities; (2) top managers of the Ministry of Education and the Thailand Environmental Institute; (3) students who performed green jobs during their internship period or after graduating with a bachelor's degree from Thai universities; and (4) top managers, HR managers and employees at each case study firm. The questions for the semi-structured interviews with the top managers of vocational colleges and universities addressed the strengths and weaknesses of environmental/green management programs of each vocational college or university in developing green skills among graduates and in supporting the transition of the Thai economy toward a green economy, the qualifications of the applicants to those programs and the jobs performed by most graduates of those programs. The questions for the top managers of the Ministry of Education and the Thailand Environmental Institute included asking that they provide an overview of environmental/green management programs in Thailand to support the transition toward a green economy, create green jobs and develop green skills among graduates; the strengths and weaknesses of environmental/green management programs in Thailand; and insights into how to improve the weaknesses of those programs to help foster the development of green skills among graduates. The questions for students who performed green jobs during their internship period or after graduating with a bachelor's degree from Thai universities addressed how the environmental/green management programs in which they had participated supported them in developing green skills, the challenges they faced when they performed green jobs, how industry-ready they were when they performed green jobs and the extent to which their employer firms trained their employees to perform green jobs. Finally, the questions for the top managers, HR managers and employees of each case study firm addressed why each case study firm paid special attention to green businesses and green jobs, the nature of green jobs in each firm, the green job policy of each firm, the types of green skills that employees needed to perform green jobs, the challenges or problems each firm faced in recruiting and selecting employees from the labor market who have green skills, how each firm provided training and helped employees develop green skills, how environmental/green management programs in Thailand support each firm's employees' acquisition of green skills and the weaknesses of these programs. Each interview was digitally voice recorded, and the author took field notes during the interviews to facilitate transcription.
This paper applied a thematic analysis (Teddlie and Tashakkori, 2009) (via Atlas.ti) to pinpoint, examine and record patterns or themes within the data. In particular, the thematic analysis here involved three important steps. The author first categorized the raw data obtained from the semi-structured interviews and nonparticipant observation into empirical themes. To identify the empirical themes, the author used language that was as close to the data as possible. As the empirical themes emerged, the author compared the themes within and across these interview transcripts and notes to ensure that the themes fit the data well across the transcripts and field notes. Based on the empirical themes, the author constructed conceptual categories for the creation of green jobs and the development of green skills in firms to respond to the institutional context (Table 2 shows how the author categorized the raw data into empirical themes and consolidated those themes into conceptual categories; Table 3 shows the frequency of each empirical theme). Regarding the saturation of the data, the author believed that 38 semi-structured interviews with a variety of stakeholders should be sufficient to obtain robust results because no new themes, issues or insights were obtained beyond this number of interviews (Strauss and Corbin, 1990).
In conclusion, the author triangulated interviews with the top managers, HR managers and employees in each case study firm with perspectives from the top managers of vocational colleges and universities, the top managers of the Ministry of Education and the Thailand Environmental Institute and the students who performed green jobs during their internship period or after graduating with a bachelor's degree from Thai universities. Additionally, the nonparticipant observation of the attitudes and behaviors of the various groups of interviewees during company visits, the analysis of archival documents and web resources and the analysis of the author's field notes were used to triangulate the interview transcripts before developing the inductive analysis of the creation of green jobs and the development of green skills within firms in response to the national education and skill-formation system.
Empirical findings
The findings show that firms across industries in Thailand must be responsible for helping their employees/workers obtain the green knowledge and skills necessary to perform green jobs through high-road HR practices in response to the fact that the Thai education and skill-formation system is not likely to produce a sufficient number of employees/workers who have green knowledge, skills and abilities and who are industry-ready to perform green jobs, leading to a shortage of employees/workers who possess green skills in the labor market. Specifically, curricula in vocational colleges and universities in Thailand are not likely to respond to the needs of firms in producing those employees/workers. The detailed case studies below provide empirical evidence to support these findings.
The Thai education and skill-formation system
The Thai education and skill-formation system has been divided into two main levels: vocational colleges and universities.
Vocational colleges
Vocational colleges play a crucial role in the skill development and the sustainable development of the country. However, curricula that focus on the development of green knowledge and skills among students or curricula that support students to be able to perform green jobs or environmental/green management curricula have not been integrated into educational programs for vocational college students in Thailand (Interviews#1-2; Interview#3; Interview#4). According to an interview with a top manager of a vocational college, In fact, curricula related to environmental conservation and green management should have long been integrated into educational programs for vocational college students in Thailand. However, this issue has not been addressed successfully. (Interview#1)

In other words, educational programs for vocational college students in Thailand have paid special attention to the development of technical knowledge and technical skills, the use of hands-on learning and the implementation of on-the-job training among students. However, the knowledge and skills related to environmental conservation, green management, energy management and wastewater treatment has not been integrated into curricula. In this regard, in terms of the vocational education, the national education and skill development system does not play a role in the production of labor/employees who have the knowledge, skills and abilities to perform green jobs in Thailand. Thailand has continued to face a shortage of labor/employees who graduate from vocational colleges and who have been trained to perform green jobs or jobs related to environmental conservation (Interviews#1-2; Interview#3).
Nevertheless, in the future, content related to the environment and clean energy should be incorporated into every educational program offered by vocational colleges due to the fact that the issues of the environment, green management and sustainable growth have become increasingly important in Thailand. In addition, requirements may be imposed such that graduates from vocational colleges who wish to apply for a professional certificate must also obtain a certificate for environmental professionals. Because of this, vocational colleges certainly play an important role in the transition of the national economy to a green economy, the creation of green jobs and the development of green skills among employees (Interviews#1-2; Interviews#5-7).
Universities
Universities have played an important role in producing employees/workers who have knowledge and skills in green/environmental management because educational programs at the university level in Thailand have incorporated content related to green/environmental management into their programs. However, the majority of curricula that support the production of employees/workers who have the knowledge, skills and abilities necessary to perform green jobs have only been offered by schools/departments/programs directly relevant to the environment and natural resources. By contrast, the schools/departments/programs that are not directly related to green/environmental management have still not incorporated content on green/environmental management into their programs. According to an interview with a top manager and scholar of the Faculty of Social Sciences and Humanities, Mahidol University, This issue is quite understandable because, although the notion of green management, green jobs, and the green economy have been increasingly popular in today's situations, most of these notions have still been considered in terms of ‘discourse’ more than ‘serious action’. (Interview#8)

Additionally, the government has not allocated a sufficient budget for the creation of green jobs and the implementation of green management within firms. In this regard, the issues of green management, green jobs and green economy have not been as widely mentioned in Thailand as they should be (Interview#8; Interview#9).
Moreover, due to the fact that educational programs related to the environment and green management depend heavily on students who have special interest in the areas of the environment and green management while classes are still taught primarily based on technical knowledge, schools or programs that are not directly related to the environment and green management may not be able to incorporate content on those issues into their programs. One important finding is that universities in Thailand are not likely to respond to the needs of labor markets and industries in that they are not likely to produce a sufficient number of employees/workers who are industry-ready to perform green jobs. The rationale behind this finding is that curricula related to environmental/green management offered by several universities in Thailand are not likely to directly respond to the needs of industries. That said, to perform jobs in several areas of environmental/green management, including wastewater treatment, employees/workers must possess knowledge and skills that are tailored to fit with the contexts of each firm (firm-specific knowledge and skills). In other words, these firms must invest their own budgets in producing and/or training employees/workers to obtain knowledge and skills in green management and environmental conservation. However, the above-described problems may not result solely from the national education and skill-formation system. It may be possible that firms in Thailand (especially small- and medium-sized firms) are not likely to have the necessary readiness in every respect, including budgets, personnel, policies and management support, to seriously and systematically implement environmental/green management policies and practices. In this regard, most universities in Thailand may not have a clear direction regarding environmental and green management programs that fit well with the current demand of the labor markets and firms (Interview#8; Interview#9).
The empirical findings regarding the Thai education and skill-formation system at the university level can be summarized into several issues as follows.
Bachelor's degree programs
Most bachelor's degree programs in the areas of environmental and green management tend to primarily focus on theoretical knowledge, a variety of techniques and sophisticated calculation. However, these programs are not likely to pay attention to the promotion of students' environmental awareness and the development and practice of employability skill and environmental management skill to foster students' abilities to work in real employment situations, although there are a number of graduates from these programs each year. For instance, the bachelor's degree program of the Faculty of Environment and Resource Studies at Mahidol University accepts approximately 110 students each year. However, the number of graduates may be lower than this number for several reasons, including poor academic performance and withdrawal before graduation to pursue study at other universities. One important fact is that not every graduate from that program ultimately finds employment in the areas of green management/environmental conservation. Based on this fact, the number of graduates in these areas who are industry-ready may not be sufficient to respond to the needs of markets and firms. Therefore, these firms have had to invest their budget in training new employees for some time (6 months to one year) before they can begin to function effectively in real working contexts. Most of the graduates in these areas work in environmental impact assessment (EIA) and social impact assessment (SIA) consulting companies, in NGOs such as TEI or in other relevant public agencies. Scholars have expressed expectations that the labor market for this group of graduates will be more open in the future when new environmental laws and regulations are enforced (Interview#8; Interview#9; Interview#10; Interview#11). According to an interview, Graduates from our faculty are competent and are of good quality. They have strong theoretical knowledge. Most employers really appreciate the quality of our students. However, these graduates may lack practical skills because we do not have a sufficient budget to foster them in obtaining those skills. (Interview#8)

Master's degree programs
Master's degree programs in environmental and green management focus on both technical knowledge and environmental management skills so that graduates will have opportunities for promotion to top management in the future. For instance, in the case of the Graduate School of Environmental Development Administration at National Institute of Development Administration (NIDA), its educational program aims to train graduates to be eligible for promotion to top management positions responsible for overseeing environmental/green management of their firms in the future. Additionally, this educational program focuses on the production of employees/workers who are industry-ready to perform green jobs. In this regard, the emphasis of the program offered by the Graduate School of Environmental Development Administration at NIDA is not based on technical knowledge but on practical skills and environmental/green management skills, although the students do not have any background in environmental science and management. In other words, this program can help graduates function in real working contexts (Interview#8; Interview#9; Interview#10; Interview#11; Interviews#12-15; Interview#16).
However, the number of graduates from master's degree programs in environmental/green management from universities in Thailand has been quite small, and it is likely to decline in the future due to Thailand's aging population and its movement toward becoming an aged society. [By the year 2035, Thailand will be the first emerging market economy to become a superaged society (Bank of Thailand, 2018). A superaged society here refers to a country in which the number of aging people who are more than 60 years of age accounts for approximately 30% of the total population or in which the number of aging people who are more than 65 years of age accounts for more than 20% of the total population (World Health Organization, 2002).] In this regard, the number of students who attend universities and who enter the labor market will decline continuously (Interview#8; Interview#9; Interview#10; Interview#11; Interviews#12-15; Interview#16; Interviews#17-18).
Aging society and Thai universities
Thailand is now an aging society, and it will soon become an aged society. The nation's declining birth rate has led to lower numbers of students entering universities. Many second-tier and third-tier universities in Thailand have therefore attempted to adapt themselves to the changing environment by offering bachelor's degree and master's degree programs that aim to produce graduates who are industry-ready to perform green jobs. In this regard, firms do not need to invest a huge part of their budgets in training these graduates. Therefore, the educational programs in this group of universities focus on employability skills and case study analysis. Additionally, this group of universities has, to a greater extent, paid attention to offering educational programs in environmental/green management for sustainability because top managers of these universities believe that the domains of environmental/green management will become increasingly important in the future (Interview#11; Interviews#1-2).
Firm-level practices regarding green jobs
In Thailand, firms typically invest their budgets in training employees/workers to perform green jobs for several reasons. First, the number of graduates who have graduated with degrees in environmental/green management and who are industry-ready to perform green jobs is not sufficient to respond to the demand of the labor market. Second, the top managers of some firms, especially small- and medium-sized firms, still believe that their firms do not need to hire persons who are specialized in environmental/green management to perform green jobs. Additionally, Thailand has had no clear rules, regulations or incentives to force firms to hire environmental/green management specialists to perform those jobs (Interviews#19-22; Interviews#23-27; Interviews#28-30; Interviews#31-32; Interviews#33-38). The empirical findings regarding firm-level requirements regarding green jobs and how green knowledge and skills have been developed among employees within the four case study firms across industries are presented below.
SSS Ceramics Public Company Limited
SSS Ceramics Public Company Limited manufactures, sells and distributes ceramic tiles under the brands of COTTO, CAMPANA and SOSUCO. It has been considered the flagship company that operates businesses related to ceramic tiles in Thailand, and the company has also exported its ceramic tiles to other countries (SSS Ceramics Public Company Limited, 2018).
SSS Ceramics Public Company Limited has paid special attention to green management and environmental conservation. In this regard, it has maximized the utilization of energy and natural resources and managed and conserved the energy in the manufacturing factory via waste heat recovery from kiln to dryer and via the reduction of air leakage based on employee participation. Additionally, the company has initiated a high-efficiency burner activity; installed an air booster system, a photovoltaic (PV) solar rooftop and new spray dryers; and now uses light emitting diode (LED) tube light. Moreover, it has reduced the factory's emissions of chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) and dust into the atmosphere, treated its wastewater well and focused on zero waste management. In other words, the company works to ensure there are no emissions of any type of waste into the public sphere (Interviews#23-27; Observation).
SSS Ceramics Public Company Limited has primarily used various machines and automation technologies to facilitate the performance of green jobs. For instance, it has used machines and automation technologies to collect the data regarding the utilization of electricity for the purpose of environmental conservation. The company has not emphasized the use of employees/workers to perform these jobs. The reason behind this issue is that the use of various machines and automation technologies helps improve the reliability of the company's manufacturing process, generate efficiency in business operations and reduce waste or various problems that may affect the environment (Interviews#23-27; Observation). According to an interview, I believe that this idea is also in compliance with Thailand's aging society, which has caused a lower number of graduates to enter the Thai labor market. The use of machines and automation technologies to replace labor has led to a hiring freeze at my company. (Interview#23)

However, in the case of some environmental/green management jobs that cannot be performed by machines and automation technologies such as quality assurance, audit and control of the quality of new products made from waste, SSS Ceramics Public Company Limited has trained its existing engineers and foremen to obtain new knowledge and skills in performing environmental/green management jobs through on-the-job training and classroom training. The company has not recruited new employees who have graduated with degrees in environmental/green management directly from the labor market. The main reason why SSS Ceramics Public Company Limited has paid special attention to environmental/green management jobs is that the company wants its products to be widely accepted as environmentally friendly by consumers in Thailand and in other countries. Therefore, the company has attempted to have its products certified by several well-known agencies including TEI (a product carbon footprint) (Interviews#23-27; Observation).
PPP Public Company Limited
PPP Public Company Limited is considered to be the national energy services company in Thailand. It operates its energy and petroleum businesses from upstream to downstream. including natural gas, international trade, technologies and engineering services. Other related businesses include the exploration and production of petroleum, infrastructure, coal, petrochemical engineering and distillation, oil and retail services (PPP Public Company Limited, 2018).
The primary focus of PPP Public Company Limited is to successfully implement zero waste management and zero emission policies by 2050 (Interviews#28-30). One of the important issues at PPP Public Company Limited is the idea of “24 go green.” Based on this idea, the company has attempted to change its employees' attitudes toward green behaviors. Thus, employees must pay special attention to climate change and environmental conservation. The company continually searches for green idols to motivate employees to care about environmental issues (Interviews#28-30; Observation). According to an interview, Our company has implemented blockchain technologies to separate recycled waste so that our employees can review the company's blockchain system to learn their score with regard to using recycled waste such as glass. (Interview#28)

Employees also realize their role in reducing CFC and can monitor the progress of transforming recycled waste into new products from the system. Additionally, PPP Public Company Limited has continuously developed and implemented green management policies, and the company has become the leader in green technology in Thailand. Moreover, the company has successfully integrated environmental issues with digital issues (such as the idea of blockchain technologies mentioned above). Furthermore, PPP Public Company Limited has launched more than 200 green products/services, including bio cups, to customers. The company's products are environmentally friendly and are certified with the “green for life label.” PPP Public Company Limited has also implemented environmental accounting policies and practices for some time (Interviews#28-30; Observation).
PPP Public Company Limited has invested a huge budget into training and developing green knowledge and skills among its employees. It has developed a PPP environmental training course for newly recruited employees. Thus, all newly recruited employees across departments must attend the company's security, safety, health and environment (SSHE) training course. This training course aims to generate environmental awareness among attendees and focuses on the company's environmental management policies and practices as well as safety procedures. It also focuses on environmental and climate change across countries throughout the globe. All the company's employees must regularly attend SSHE training brush-up courses. PPP Public Company Limited has realized that graduates with degrees in environmental/green management may not be prepared to perform green jobs in a real context. Thus, PPP Public Company Limited has continuously trained its employees so they will possess green knowledge and skills, and it also offers its employees mentoring, job shadowing and coaching programs. In other words, PPP Public Company Limited equips its employees with both green management theory and practice for at least 6 months to 1 year so its employees can perform green jobs immediately after training. At PPP Public Company Limited, persons who can successfully perform green jobs must have technical knowledge and must have various types of skills to perform those jobs, including digitalization, communication, teamwork and problem-solving skills (Interviews#28-30; Observation).
Chaophya Park Hotel
Chaophya Park Hotel is located on Ratchadapisek Road, Din Daeng sub-district, Din Daeng district, Bangkok. This hotel began its operations on October 15, 1992. Currently, it has approximately 401 employees and 402 guest rooms in total (i.e. 231 premier rooms, 132 business deluxe rooms, 19 executive rooms, 19 executive suite rooms and 1 Chaophya suite) (data obtained from a field visit on June 19, 2019).
Chaophya Park Hotel has received several awards related to environmental/green management, including the ASEAN Green Hotel Award (data obtained from a field visit on June 19, 2019). The hotel has developed and implemented environmentally friendly service policies and practices, appointed a green team, held meetings with all levels of managers to monitor the progress of green energy projects every second Tuesday of the month and publicized knowledge regarding environmentally friendly services to employees via various media, including posters, leaflets, newsletters, broadcasting, email and exhibitions. Chaophya Park Hotel has a huge monitor located in the lobby area so that everyone can monitor the hotel's real-time usage of electricity. Additionally, the hotel has attempted to treat wastewater and use that treated water for plantation and for washing dirty areas. Moreover, the hotel has attempted to produce biodiesel from used oil, and it has used that biodiesel for small trucks or vehicles used in the hotel. Furthermore, Chaophya Park Hotel produces its own energy to replace the use of external sources of electricity, such as through the installation of solar cells and the production of biogas from waste and wastewater (Interviews#31-32; Observation).
Overall, Chaophya Park Hotel has paid special attention to the environmental/green management for sustainability, as recognized in its environmentally friendly services, green procurement and energy-saving practices. The success of the hotel in performing green management practices is the result of the initiative and support of its top managers, including the hotel's managing director. Additionally, one of the key success factors of Chaophya Park Hotel is its employees/workers. The hotel has not hired specialists/experts in environmental/green management to perform green jobs. Rather, it has gradually trained its existing employees to generate environmental awareness and develop green knowledge and skills. Specifically, the hotel has regularly trained its employees regarding environmentally friendly services. In many cases, its green team has visited several organizations to learn about environmental conservation, energy savings and green management practices. The hotel's top managers have also acted as role models for their employees. For instance, the managing director of the hotel has engaged in behaviors regarding water and electricity saving. She attended a class regarding how to make environmentally friendly dish detergent (so-called green plus). Then, she tried to use it in advance of obtaining certification for the dish detergent from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) of Thailand. Afterward, she taught her employees/workers how to make this dish detergent. Additionally, she attended a class regarding how to make green soap and followed the same steps as in the case of green plus. Moreover, on-the-job training has played a crucial role in helping the hotel's employees perform green jobs. That said, Chaophya Park Hotel has encouraged its experienced or senior employees to teach inexperienced or newly recruited employees. For instance, experienced or senior employees teach inexperienced or newly recruited employees to classify various types of waste. This classified waste will ultimately be sold to outsiders, and the income from sales will be returned to the hotel's employees. In some cases, experienced employees teach inexperienced employees to make environmentally friendly soap/shampoo to be used in the hotel. Additionally, experienced employees teach newly recruited employees how to make effective microorganism (EM) liquid and how to make coasters from used napkins. Overall, several activities are performed to create green awareness among employees so that the employees will pay attention to green management endogenously (Interviews#31-32; Observation).
The managing director of Chaophya Park Hotel emphasized the significance of acting as the role model for employees, on-the-job training, study visits to other organizations/firms, generating green awareness among employees and developing green skills among employees. According to an interview with the managing director, Educational programs in environmental/green management offered by universities may equip graduates with knowledge. However, these programs cannot help graduates be industry-ready, possess green skills, and have inner motivation to find green jobs. Thus, on-the-job training and serving as the role model for employees are very important here. (Interviews#31)

In summary, the most important factor that has led Chaophya Park Hotel toward success in developing green jobs is its cultivation of its employees' realization of the importance of non-monetary rewards, that is, the sustainable growth of the country and society.
Thanya Park
Thanya Park was established on November 1, 2012, on the initiative of Mrs. Sununtha Somboondhamma, executive chairman of Thaniya Group. It has been considered to be the first eco-friendly shopping mall in Thailand (Interviews#33-38; Observation). Thanya Park has received several awards related to environmental/green management including the 2016 Thailand Energy Award, the Second Runner-Up 2016 ASEAN Energy Award (energy conservation), the Green Building Award and Green Office Award (data obtained from a field visit on May 23, 2019). The top managers of Thanya Park have realized that, in terms of shopping malls/centers, the service industry typically consumes large amounts of energy and natural resources. Therefore, they proposed that the design and construction of Thanya Park should be environmentally friendly, have the least impact on its surrounding environments and facilitate energy savings (Interviews#33-38; Observation). According to an interviewee, The primary philosophy of Thanya Park is environmental conservation. We are willing to invest huge budgets in the design and construction of the shopping mall in order to conserve the environment and to make a beautiful world for the next generation. (Interviews#33)

In addition to top management support, one of the key success factors regarding the success of Thanya Park's environmental/green management is its employees. Thanya Park has not hired employees/workers who are environmental/green management experts to perform green jobs. However, it has trained its line managers and employees to recognize the importance of environmental conservation. It has gradually developed its employees to possess green knowledge and skills by emphasizing that all Thanya Park's employees must have so-called green DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). In this regard, it has focused on on-the-job training so that its employees have gradually generated environmental/green awareness. Moreover, coaching and mentoring systems are considered one of the crucial tools for Thanya Park to create environmental/green awareness among newly recruited or inexperienced employees (Interviews#33-38; Observation).
In fact, Thanya Park's line managers and employees who are responsible for performing green jobs are persons who have already had their own duties and responsibilities (i.e. marketing and customer service). Thus, when this group of line managers and employees is assigned by top managers to perform environmental/green management jobs, they must develop their own environmental awareness and give special attention to green jobs. In addition to top management support and top managers as role models, on-the job training and other management tools play an important role in developing environmental awareness and green skills among managers and employees. In turn, line managers and employees also serve as role models for other groups of employees, newly recruited employees and even lessees (i.e. persons who rent Thanya Park's property) (Interviews#33-38; Observation). According to an interview with an HR manager, Educational programs at the university level may equip students with theories and knowledge. However, environmental/green awareness, green consciousness, and environmental/green skills may not be integrated into those programs. Therefore, typically, it is firms' duties and responsibilities to cultivate such awareness and consciousness and to develop green skills among their employees. (Interview#34)

In summary, according to the empirical findings, firms across industries must be responsible for helping their employees/workers obtain the green skills necessary to perform green jobs by focusing on various HR practices, including classroom training, on-the-job training, coaching and mentoring systems, and managers as role models in response to the fact that the Thai education and skill-formation system, especially at the levels of vocational colleges and universities, is unlikely to produce a sufficient number of employees/workers who have green knowledge, skills and abilities and are industry-ready to perform green jobs in firms, leading to a shortage of employees/workers who possess green skills in the labor market (see Table 4 for the HR practices used by the four case study firms).
Discussion
Based on the empirical findings at the level of the Thai education and skill-formation system and at the level of firms, this study found support for the following arguments regarding the creation of green jobs and the development of green skills in firms across industries in response to the Thai institutional context. First, firms create green jobs and develop green skills among employees through several HR practices to respond to the institutional context in terms of the deficiencies in the Thai education and skill-formation system. The Thai education and skill-formation system is not likely to produce sufficient numbers of employees/workers with green skill sets for firms. The curriculum tends to primarily focus on technical skills; however, those skills are not likely to be aligned with the needs of industries and firms. Additionally, curricula are not likely to reflect the real working environment of industries and firms. In particular, at the level of vocational colleges, educational programs in terms of environmental/green management have not been integrated into curricula of study. By contrast, at the level of universities, programs of study in terms of environmental/green management have already been offered to students. However, curricula related to environmental/green management policies and practices offered by several universities are likely to focus primarily on theory and knowledge so they cannot directly respond to the needs of industries and firms. Actually, to perform jobs in several areas of environmental/green management, including wastewater treatment, employees/workers must possess both theoretical knowledge and practical skills. Therefore, firms must invest their own budget in producing and/or training employees/workers so these employees/workers will possess the appropriate knowledge and skills in environmental/green management. Nevertheless, the above-noted problems may not solely result from deficiencies in the Thai education and skill-formation system. Most small- and medium-sized firms in Thailand may not have the necessary readiness especially, in terms of budgets, personnel and management support, to systematically implement environmental/green management policies and practices. However, in the future, it is expected that Thai environmental/green regulations and laws will become more apparent and will be more seriously enforced to facilitate the movement toward a BCG economy. At that time, every type of organizations in Thailand will have to hire environmental/green management specialists and/or employees/workers who possess knowledge and skills in environmental/green management to perform green jobs. Therefore, the demand for this group of employees/workers from the labor market will be higher in the future. In other words, changes in relevant regulations and laws in the future will tend to lead to an upskilling of environmental/green job requirements in Thailand. Here, upskilling means that employees/workers must learn new skills that extend the present duties and responsibilities of their jobs. In this case, the group of employees will require higher levels of training (Kearsley, 1989; MacDuffie and Kochan, 1995; Osterman, 1995). This upskilling of environmental/green jobs will ultimately exacerbate the skill shortage problem in the Thai labor market.
Second, to alleviate the problem resulting from the deficiencies in the Thai education and skill-formation system, firms tend to internally develop their own environmental/green management specialists over time through internal labor market systems. According to Doeringer and Piore, an “internal labor market” is “an administrative unit, including a manufacturing plant, a hotel, or a shopping mall, within which the pricing and allocation of labor is governed by a set of administrative rules and procedures” (1971, p. 2). The main argument here is that the pricing and allocation of the labor market occur within a firm, a plant, a hotel or a shopping mall (Osterman, 1984; Bidwell and Keller, 2014; Keller, 2018). In this respect, firms apply several training methods, including classroom training, on-the-job training, coaching, mentoring systems and job shadowing; top managers act as role models for younger generations of employees, to internally train and develop line managers and employees/workers to obtain the necessary environmental/green knowledge and skills to perform green jobs. In other words, to develop green skills among employees, firms tend to apply “high-road” or “high-commitment” HR practices to improve the functional flexibility within firms (Erickson et al ., 2003). Functional flexibility here refers to actions that foster stability within the workplace including investments in training and skill development, the promotion of multiskilling and job rotation. In this regard, the case study firms internally train and develop their existing employees to be multiskilled. For instance, at Thanya Park, the firm's line managers and employees are internally developed to possess green knowledge and skills so that managers and employees can alternate between their line functions and green management functions. In the case of Chaophya Park Hotel, the hotel has gradually trained its existing employees to generate environmental awareness and develop green skills. Notably, the movement of firms toward greater functional flexibility plays a crucial role in helping firms develop green skills among employees to successfully perform green jobs.
Third, the skill shortage problem in the labor market may not be unique to the case of the development of green skills among employees across firms in Thailand. In fact, this problem typically arises when a new economy/industry develops or when there is a change in a development strategy (e.g. the movement toward a BCG economy in the case of Thailand).
Here, to minimize the skill shortage problem in the labor market and to optimize long-term green skill development upon transition to the new BCG economy, Thailand needs to adopt a concerted national effort that involves multiple actors, encompassing multiple institutions, at national, university and firm levels (Finegold and Soskice, 1988; Singh and Zammit, 2000; Kuruvilla and Ranganathan, 2008). Solving both macro (i.e. national level) and micro (i.e. firm level) HR problems regarding the development of green skills among employees across firms — problems that tend to require different policy interventions by multiple actors — implies a well-integrated effort. In particular, the Thai government can play a crucial role in increasing the supply of a skilled labor force with green skills necessary to perform green jobs through a number of approaches. For instance, the government should incorporate green/environmental management issues into national education policy. Specifically, national education policy should require vocational colleges to incorporate content/courses related to environmental/green management into their educational programs. Additionally, the government should support the development of various skills, especially green skills, among vocational college students so that they will be industry-ready to function in a real working context. In fact, these educational programs should encourage vocational college students who tend to have creativity and innovation skills to learn how to develop environmentally friendly products and processes by aiming to reduce emissions and the consumption of water, electricity and other raw materials (so-called green innovation). Moreover, the government should foster cooperation between vocational colleges or universities and firms in designing environmental/green management educational programs that respond to the needs of firms to prevent the skill shortage problem and skill mismatches in the Thai labor market. Furthermore, the government should offer a variety of incentives, including tax reductions or tax exemptions, for firms, especially SMEs that pay special attention to environmental conservation/green management. One of the most important notions here is that the government should take serious actions regarding the creation of a BCG economy and the implementation of environmental/green management policies and practices across firms; otherwise, the issue regarding the creation of a BCG economy and the implementation of environmental/green management policies and practices is considered to be only “discourse.”
Similarly, universities should redesign environmental/green management educational programs at the undergraduate level to enable those programs to focus simultaneously on both theories and employability skills. Additionally, those programs should be taught based on real case studies in terms of environmental/green management. In this way, graduates will be industry-ready to perform green jobs. Universities should also cooperate/partner with both public and private firms in designing educational programs/curricula related to environmental/green management to be able to produce graduates whose qualifications respond to customers' needs (i.e. firms). Moreover, universities must welcome questions/problems related to environmental/green management from industries to help firms across industries solve these problems. This action will help firms realize the importance of universities, and both undergraduate and graduate students will have an opportunity to solve real environmental/green problems experienced by industries. These students will ultimately understand real working contexts and be industry-ready to perform green jobs.
Universities in Thailand should also cooperate with world-class universities in other countries to design environmental/green management educational programs that fit the national context of Thailand and support the movement of Thailand toward a green economy. These universities in Thailand should sign a memorandum of understanding with leading research institutes and world-class digital technology companies such that these institutes and/or companies admit high-potential university students from Thailand to work as trainees/entry-level employees for a certain duration (1 year or 2 years). This action can facilitate knowledge transfer from these institutes and/or companies to Thai students who will finally return to work in Thailand.
Furthermore, NGOs, including the Thailand Environmental Institute, should cooperate/partner with vocational colleges, universities and the Ministry of Education to design educational programs/curricula related to environmental/green management. The special expertise of NGOs' officers in the areas of environmental management/conservation should help these vocational colleges and universities produce graduates who have environmental/green management knowledge and skills to directly respond to firms' needs. NGOs should also encourage both public and private firms to pay special attention to green/environmental management and the development of green skills among their existing employees by providing discounts or incentives to such firms that allow them to assign their existing employees to attend NGOs' training programs/courses related to environmental/green management. NGOs can also offer certificates or labels for those firms' green/environmentally friendly products to foster a green image among them. Of course, to obtain green certificates or labels and carbon footprints from NGOs, firms need to intentionally develop green skills among their existing employees and future employees to enable them to have green awareness and serve as an important mechanism to help firms obtain these certificates or labels.
In addition to partnerships with universities in designing educational programs/curricula related to environmental/green management, both public and private firms should pay special attention to the implementation of high-road HR practices or high commitment HR practices to develop green skills among their existing employees, enabling these employees to successfully perform green jobs. In fact, these firms should consider adopting so-called green human resource management (GHRM) practices. GHRM practices are a set of HR practices that enable and sustain environmental/green management within firms (Renwick et al ., 2013; Renwick, 2018). These HR practices consist of green recruitment and selection, green training and development, green performance management, green pay and rewards and green employee relations. In fact, these practices aim to upgrade both the environmental and social performance of firms. They are considered an important tool for incorporating the organizational policies of environmental and social sustainability into HR practices. Specifically, GHRM practices focus on the development of employees' green knowledge, skills and abilities; employees' motivation to demonstrate green behaviors at work; and the maintenance of a green organizational culture and values.
