Waterlogging mitigation and safe water supply: lessons learnt from low-lying areas of Basirhat municipality, India

Author: Dey, Aniruddha1; Islam, Sheikh Tawhidul2; Biplabketan, Paul3; Bandyopadhyay, Swarnabha4; Sengupta, Piu5; Sanyal, Nandini6; Mondal, Krishna Prosad2; Jubaer, Al2; Mitra, Rangeet71 Department of Research and Development, Professional Institute for Development and Socio Environmental M anagement – Professional Institute for Development and Socio Environmental Management – PRISM, Gobardanga, India2 Institute of Remote Sensing and GIS, Jahangirnagar University, Dhaka, Bangladesh3 Naireeta Services Pvt. Ltd., Ahmedabad, India4 Department of Research and Development, Bongs Prayukti International, Kolkata, India5 Department of Women's Empowerment and Development, Professional Institute for Development and Socio Environmental Management – PRISM, Kolkata, India6 Department of Research and Development, Science Connect Ltd., Dhaka, Bangladesh7 Department of Technical, Bongs Prayukti International, Kolkata, India

Publication info: Dey, Aniruddha; Islam, Sheikh Tawhidul; Biplabketan, Paul; Bandyopadhyay, Swarnabha; Sengupta, Piu; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/waterlogging-mitigation-safe-water-supply-lessons/docview/2666151243/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Purpose > The purpose of this paper is to develop a replicable model that ensures Household Water Treatment and Safe Storage as well as water treatment facilities at the community level by providing total service coverage at community scale. An intervention was implemented in one of the low-lying areas of Basirhat Municipality (West Bengal, India) that included a number of action programs in order to address household- and community-level water-induced challenges. Design/methodology/approach > A research study was undertaken to identify the root causes of the problems that are generally spawned from geomorphological, hydro-fluvial, climatic factors and processes and the situation becomes complicated when many other cumulative problem-contexts layovers the existing ones. A number of social and technological innovations were tested in the field and this paper critically examined the intervention processes and outcomes. It was implemented through participatory process by involving related stakeholders working at that scale so that necessary public acceptance is received for scaling up, at least, in the similar physical, social, economic and institutional contexts. Findings > The problem conceptualization process, spatial assessment for contextualizing the problem, design of interventions for different scales, development of project deployment strategies from field-based learnings contributed in developing a total solution based on fusing of household-level technical solutions, social innovations and actions for community engagements towards sustainability. Mobilized community members in addressing local inundation and waterlogging crisis. Satellite image-based maps shown to make them understand the upper-lower connection of drainage. People also developed their own action plans and engaged themselves in resuscitation of an old canal, removed the garbage that resulted in improved drainage conditions in the area. Research limitations/implications > Pandemic due to COVID 19 and its related prolonged lock down, West Bengal State Assembly Election, closure of municipal governance system due to the forthcoming municipal election, closure of educational institutions, closure of Anganwadi Centre in the field area were the limitations. Due to the lock down, it was difficult for the team to maintain the time frame as well as the budget. As per the Election’s Code of Conduct gets released no public meeting was allowed without permission, people in the vicinity became suspicious, hence movement of the team members got restricted. Practical implications > Due to the COVID protocols, the team could not organise mass training programs. It was difficult for the team members to commute in public/private transport, hence filed work got impacted. As the team could not access data from the health department, they developed a strategy of generation data on body mass index, mid-upper arm circumferences and waist-to-hip ratios to understand the status of health and nutrition of the community. It was difficult to access the Public Health Engineering Department’s laboratory situated in the municipality for water sample test. Cost escalated due to extension of the project time. Social implications > During the second phase (wave) when people lost access to health facilities they requested the team to stop field visit. Women’s empowerment through acquiring knowledge and skill on treatment and safe storage of drinking water at home. Men appreciated and recognized this, which improved the status of women in the society. Children after expressing their willingness to learn the new technology of water purification were given handholding training by their mothers and knowledge transfer has taken place in the next generation. Mobilized community members in addressing local inundation and waterlogging crisis. Satellite image-based maps to understand the upper-lower connection of drainage helped them develop their own action plans and engaged themselves in resuscitation of an old canal, removed the garbage that resulted in improved drainage conditions in the area. Originality/value > Household-level solutions include supply of low cost, easy operable, sustainable water purifiers, community-level solution focused on securing water-related challenges at social/public gathering places and wider catchment area level solutions include the engagement of local communities to drain out stagnant waters by clearing drains, creating/digging small canals through collective actions. Geo-spatial techniques (topographical mapping, spatial survey, water quality tests) along with social methods such as participatory appraisals for gathering information on human health, public awareness campaigns and partnership development with local government agencies were the major activities performed as part of the implementation of interventions. It is imperative to mention that water-related challenges in the low-lying settlement areas of Basirhat Municipality have effectively been addressed by relying on necessary theoretical underpinnings (Disaster risk reduction/humanitarian principles) transmitted through application of scientific techniques and mediated through local people and their agencies.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Aniruddha&amp;aulast=Dey&amp;atitle=Waterlogging+mitigation+and+safe+water+supply%3A+lessons+learnt+from+low-lying+areas+of+Basirhat+municipality%2C+India&amp;stitle=International+Journal+of+Disaster+Resilience+in+the+Built+Environment&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1108%2FIJDRBE-08-2021-0106&amp;title=Waterlogging+mitigation+and+safe+water+supply%3A+lessons+learnt+from+low-lying+areas+of+Basirhat+municipality%2C+India&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2022&amp;spage=386&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Aniruddha&amp;aulast=Dey&amp;atitle=Waterlogging+mitigation+and+safe+water+supply%3A+lessons+learnt+from+low-lying+areas+of+Basirhat+municipality%2C+India&amp;stitle=International+Journal+of+Disaster+Resilience+in+the+Built+Environment&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1108%2FIJDRBE-08-2021-0106&amp;title=Waterlogging+mitigation+and+safe+water+supply%3A+lessons+learnt+from+low-lying+areas+of+Basirhat+municipality%2C+India&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2022&amp;spage=386&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Full text: 1. Introduction
Inundation-related challenges in low-lying areas located, especially in the deltaic plains, received less attention and therefore problems remained less addressed (Ahmed and Sarker, 2015; Ghosh and Mistri, 2020; Rahman and Islam, 2018). Cities are intensifying, encroaching open fields, flood plains and water bodies are depleting rapidly to cater various needs of exploding population (Ahmed et al. , 2021; Ahsan et al. , 2021; Ghosh and Mistri, 2020; Pallavi et al. , 2021; Zhang et al. , 2021). As a result versatile, self-sufficient city landscapes become depleted, degraded zone that aew generally known as peri-urban areas (Liu et al. , 2021; Sansare and Mhaske, 2020). The peri-urban areas are the transitional zones and endure in a crossroad between the development furore and a decaying or destroyed ecosystem. These transitional zones located in city outskirts that are generally situated in low-lying back swamps behind the relatively elevated natural levees on which cities developed (Ascott et al. , 2019; Brelih et al. , 2018). Urbanization has brought in drastic changes in both the topography and adaptability of these peri-urban areas. Cities fail to recognize the importance of peri-urban areas and their ecosystems as store house of resources, act to safeguard from floods and droughts are supposed to be kept as city buffer zones for long-term sustainability of the city and to give a range of ecosystem services to the urban communities (Ascott et al. , 2019; Brelih et al. , 2018). But unfortunately, these areas are becoming occupied by people and cause breakdown of physical/environmental integrity by bringing abrupt change in the pattern of land use. As a result, the vital drainage services that the areas had been providing become jeopardized and water congestions take place leading to long-term waterlogging crisis in the area. It is also important to note, the governance system in the areas is quasi-urban (neither urban, nor rural) although the areas are generally being governed by formal rural governance system (e.g. Panchayet system in India), people primarily depend on urban areas to pursue their livelihoods and other economic activities, the demographic composition is heterogenic as mixed occupational groups live there and thus the choices, priorities, practices are different in many instances. All these in combined fashion seriously affects the service provisions in the areas such as human health, physical communication, education including safe water supply. Sometimes problems take serious turns that need humanitarian support to ensure everyday living of the people safe and secured. In this backdrop, an initiative was taken in the low-lying areas of Basirhat Municipality of West Bengal, India to address water-related challenges at three scales such as household level, community-level and relatively broader area level. Household-level solutions include supply of low cost, easy to operate, sustainable water purifiers; community-level solution focused on securing water-related challenges at social places of public gatherings by setting 1,000 litre water purifier systems and wider area-level solutions include the engagement of local communities to drain out stagnant waters by clearing drains, creating and digging small canals through collective actions. These three types of solutions in mutually complying styles provided a total water solution in the low-lying areas in Basirhat Municipality. In addition to this technical solution, efforts were also given towards developing social innovations so that systems introduced are owned by the community and can sustain long-term. This paper describes the results of pilot interventions implemented at three scales aiming to show why an all-out, total water solution is required in the low-lying settlement areas of the cities and the peri urban areas. Arguments are provided that partial solutions to water-related challenges might not address the difficulties people face in the low-lying settlement areas of the cities and peri-urban contexts happened as results of water-induced challenges.
2. Data collections methods
At the beginning it was conceived that the water-induced challenges are complicated since natural, physical, technological, social, economic, biological elements are involved in the issue. On top of that impacts of disasters such as floods, cyclones and their subtle changes (e.g. frequency of occurrence, magnitude, intensity, etc.) happening under the influence of climate change make the situations worse. It is also imperative to mention that governance system in the low-lying settlement areas of the cities, peri-urban areas/quasi-urban/quasi-rural/pseudo-formal/informal and effective execution of decisions in this context is difficult. In common practices, all these issues are generally not taken into consideration while designing and implementing safe water plans for local-level communities. This is why, detail level conceptual discussions were conducted at the beginning, happened in two phases in Delhi (August and December 2019) where a number of stakeholders including the members of the Professional Institute for Development and Socio Environmental Management (PRISM) and partner agencies (from India and Bangladesh) were participated. The conceptual discussions led to develop project proposal on safe water options for urban flooding settings, related strategies towards field implementation of the activities. Therefore, the pilot intervention that aimed at providing micro, meso, macro water solutions (also short-term, long-term sustainable solutions) in a peri-urban setting in Mathpara area (Ward No. 14) of Basirhat municipality were carried out in four major phases. These are as follows:
- conceptualizing the problem;

- gathering baseline data about the field situations, rapport building with the community members and to secure local ownership over project activities;

- implementation of interventions at three scales such as providing household level water purifiers, community-level safe water facilities and motivating communities to address community-level water congestion (labelled as total safe water solutions); and

- gathering of data on the impacts of interventions implemented.



As indicated earlier that at the beginning a multi-partner consultation meeting was held in Delhi (August and December 2019) led by the Humanitarian Innovation Fund, supported by ELRAH (UK) and that facilitated a process to critically review the drawbacks in the current way of conceptualizing a problem that may ended up into a humanitarian crisis. It stressed on innovation needs (social, technological) of various kinds and their convergence at various levels so that humanitarian crisis can be reduced if not fully eliminated. The follow-up actions of the Delhi-consultation was developing project proposal with strong innovation components. Afterwards, PRISM (India) teamed up with three agencies and relevant experts, did a number of internal discussions and finally an all-agreed proposal was developed where water-induced community challenges were proposed to be addressed in a usually negligent low-lying settlement area in Basirhat Municipality, West Bengal (Figure 1) by ensuring convergence of a number of social–technological–institutional innovations.
Field data collection was done primarily using semi-structured, in-depth interview with 87 households (women were the major respondents); in addition, 10 community consultations and 20 Key Informants were carried out. The community living in the area (Figure 2) is heterogenic by professions and work as daily wage-earners (Table 1) but share common attributes such as poor economic status, lower literacy rate (Figure 3), living in the scarcity of safe water resulted into poor health conditions, filthy environmental conditions and restricted/difficult movements due to widespread waterlogging. The interviews with the people and consultations with community members helped to get an in-depth understanding about the urban flooding and water crisis in terms of seasonality concerns, impacts of safe water scarcity and waterlogging on people like women-elderly-children-disabled, health, economy (both direct and indirect).
Scientific methods such as geo-spatial techniques (topographical mapping, spatial survey) were also conducted to know about the water flow patterns of the area, land topographical conditions to identify the potential areas for water congestion. Locational information of the households using global positioning system were also taken and overlaid on top of local physical conditions so that water-induced problems could be seen relative to the locational attributes such as land morphology and water flow pattern. These maps were later used as tools to convince people for collective actions for excavating local drains towards addressing waterlogging situations. The results of water samples were presented that were tested in different laboratories to know about the quality of drinking water in pre-project situations and also the samples taken from household-level water purifiers cum storage devices distributed under the pilot interventions. This pre and post situation water quality assessments helped to know about the improvements in water quality that is safe for drinking and other purposes.
3. Physical and social settings of the study area
The pilot intervention was implemented in Basirhat Municipality of North 24 Parganas District of West Bengal (India) which is a small city located in the southern deltaic plain of the Hooghly-Ichhamati rivers, came down as right-bank tributaries of the mighty Ganga River (Figure 4). Basirhat Municipality is a sub divisional headquarter of North 24 Parganas District, Gazetted in 1869 and is one of the moderately growing cities of West Bengal in present times. The town has its border with Bangladesh in the East and is often referred to as the “gateway” of eastern Sundarbans to other areas of West Bengal. The city has not any significant industrial base and remained dominantly as a commercial trading center. Its basic urban structure and services are not developed in a planned manner. Presently, the municipal authority has limited capacity to provide basic services like clean urban environment, safe piped water, drainage, solid waste treatment, sanitation, health services, sufficient transport network and other urban amenities.
The Municipality of Basirhat is divided into 23 wards, and this study was conducted in Ward Number 14 (Bhawanipur-Mathpara). The river Ichhamati flows along the northern and eastern side of the municipality (Figure 4). The city has a total area of 22.5 square kilometres with a population of 125,254 and population density of 5,567 per square kilometre as per 2011 census. Basirhat city is located in flat riverine plain with gently sloping lands towards the south. This plain is a part of the Ganga Delta System and is developed by deposition of clay and fine sand by the tributaries of the river Ganga. This soil conditions cause to get the topsoil water saturated in moderate or high rainfall occurrence and generate surface runoff and flooding. Maximum altitude of above mean sea level is 6.31 meters and the land slopes gently towards south east of the city. The municipality is known mainly for its hot and humid climate. The Hallmark of the climate is the prevalence of monsoon from early June to mid-September (Figure 3). Summer or pre-monsoon (March–May) is the principal hot season in the city and South-West monsoon or rainy season (June–September) is the principal humid season. The weather remains dry during the winter (mid-November–mid-February). Based on historic observed data, it has been observed that Basirhat is getting warmer by the day. The total amount of monsoon rainfall which accounts for more than 74% of total annual rainfall (Figure 5) over the area has changed (though non significantly) during the last century though high variability in inter annual rainfall in time and space has been observed. Annual normal rainfall is 1,608 mm with standard deviation of 268.92 and coefficient of variation is 16.71. Monsoon months (June–September), contribute 74% of total annual rainfall with an average variability of 21.6%. Pre-monsoon and post monsoon months contribute 10.5% and 15.5% of rainfall, respectively. Annually Basirhat experiences 77 average rainy days. Annual mean maximum temperature is 29.70°C and annual mean minimum temperature is 21.68°C. Whereas highest maximum temperature reaches even up to 41°C in May and lowest minimum temperature hovers around 10°C in January. Annual average humidity is 77%. Basirhat is one of the vulnerable cities to climate change with extreme climate driven multifarious threats including tidal surges, alternate occurrence of drought and water scarcity and waterlogging. The city is prone to either drought condition as a regular feature or sporadic flood situation due to its climatic state.
It is indicated before that unplanned urbanization process have been happening in Basirhat during past 3–4 decades in the contexts of delicate hydro-meteorological, land morphological conditions of the region (Table 2). These unplanned and inappropriate actions contributed in widening inequality in resources allocations and benefits sharing, especially in low-lying settlements, coupled with disaster induced stresses and caused people to endure with living in poor and miserable conditions. In the current process, concentration of people and communities takes place first in an area and then public service providers enter into the area to provide their services, which is supposed to be happened in the opposite way. In many cases, these agencies provide services in hesitation and unwillingly because the local dwellers are not officially entitled to receive services there due to many reasons. As a result, road communication, safe water supply, proper drainage and sanitation facilities, health-care systems, did not develop in the study locations following a proper planning process.
4. Climate change and disaster risks in the low-lying settlements: humanitarian challenges in Basirhat
Disaster risks are viewed through different lens (Pal, 2019). Study of the direct impacts of hazards, vulnerability assessment, response strategies (adaptation) and resilience building are the keys to measure disaster risks these days (Blaikie et al. , 1994; Wisner et al. , 2004; Olson et al. , 2020). Similarly, any assessment of the scale and nature of urban risk depends on how risk is conceived – whether technological hazards, infectious diseases, violence and terrorist activity are included, how “disasters” are defined and measured and whether consideration is given to post-disaster risks also (Quarantelli, 1998). In this backdrop, low-lying areas of Basirhat city was assessed from disaster and climate change contexts where intensive and erratic rainfall cause widespread flooding leading to develop water-related challenges.
Some of the key changes witnessed in the peri-urban ecosystems of Basirhat are, rapid land use change that took place during the past 10–15 years and open spaces and agriculture land (about 10%) have been converted to residential buildings. There is a gradual shrinkage in water bodies due to rampant encroachment and about 30% ponds are contaminated due to hybrid fish rearing. Drinking water is a major issue impacting on the health of urban poor people. The current problem in Basirhat low-lying settlement areas is the reduction in the area for agricultural activities and continuous waterlogging, impacting the flood resilience of the city. These chronic risks are consequences of poor drainage system of the area. Excessive rainfall in the monsoon months increase the risk of waterlogging. The problem persists in 12 Wards of the Municipality out of 23 Wards and has taken a severe toll on health, livelihoods of people, access to office, school and health-care institutions. The typical features in these affected wards include, standing water for a period of 3–4 h, and the season of waterlogging can stretch for 4–7 months in a year.
One of the major factors of waterlogging is absence of effective urban flood management system, particularly in low-lying outskirt areas of Basirhat. An uncleared solid waste dumped in haphazard manner has added to the problem of waterlogging. Even after receding of flood, water remains stagnant in large number in some pockets. Basirhat city, situated by the side of Ichhamati river, is at a vulnerable location due to rise in river bed as a result of silt deposits where systematic removal of sediments generally does not happen. On top of this, there are tidal surges happen, especially in tidal pick season and saline water from estuary rushes into the river course. Other associated risks are supply of drinking water in some wards (especially in Ward 14), lack of efficient operation of transport vehicles, closed transport routes and health issues (Figure 6), including outbreak of waterborne diseases. Lack of solid waste management, unplanned construction, poor infrastructural development are the causes behind the continuation of water logging problem of Basirhat city. As a result, city’s general public health condition is deteriorating leading to spread of diseases, particularly of vector borne and waterborne diseases in summer and rainy seasons. To add to the already overburdening problems of risk of epidemic, the poor have only local government hospitals to depend upon for treatment.
It was observed during the survey that most of the households (51.72%) were having unstable housing structures and people were suffering a decade long adverse effects of urban floods. Because of urbanization and unscientific drainage system, urban flood is taken place and it persists for more than 7 months in a year. In the same context, it has impacted banefully on the quality of life of inhabitants of this locality by creating water pollution and vector borne diseases. Locals have informed to the team members that because of inundation, taste and smell of water have changed and citizens of this locality have understood that due to waterlogging, health situation of the locality is rapidly deteriorating. It was also observed that cold and fever are the major diseases in this locality and route cause behind the fever and indigestion is water logging as indicated by the respondents. The respondents also mentioned that this situation has damaged the social well-being and cohesion of the society. The field investigation also found unscientific solid waste management process in the locality, which is one of the key reasons for environmental pollution leading to groundwater contamination.
5. Social processes innovations and the deployment of the interventions
It is commonly observed that the people remain less consulted for whom the interventions are designed, who will use and operate the systems and finally personally or collectively own the asset towards the sustainability of the systems/functions provided. Therefore, adequate consultation was carried throughout the project intervention processes to know about the living patterns of the communities, their occupation and risks associated mainly with water. It was found that rapport building with the households and communities is one of the major components to gain community trusts for achieving the maximum benefits from the interventions implemented. In this pilot project, the rapport building has been achieved through conducting field works, experience-visits and interaction and exchange of information with communities on a range of problem-facts such as connection of water with health challenges, direct and indirect cost savings from safe water use, production loss happened as results of waterlogging, costs of communication disruptions, etc. Initially, it was found that winning trusts of people of a completely new person, agency or technology is a big issue. Paying huge and careful attention in household and community consultations helped the rapport building process effective – people gradually expressed their queries, shared their sufferings from waterlogging and water quality concerns (i.e. excess of iron in water), mentioned about their complaints on how they were rejected to receive services from service delivering agencies, showed willingness to receive information and to get skilled in operating and maintaining the water purification and storage device and also gave their own innovative suggestions how problems can be overcome. This consultation phase revealed the history of the problem of the area. Their anguish and struggle to settle in this city outskirt, peri-urban lands were gradually discovered. They shared that decade before the area was under-populated. The area was almost vacant and partly used for agricultural activities. Everything came into discussion – not in pen and paper but many emotions were handled carefully when mother shared her elder son died untimely. It was revealed that majorly women suffered the most, in case of inundation. Pregnant woman, especially, those who were in advanced stage were afraid of living such areas in time of rainy season. No vehicles can reach the area few years back in time of need. Now, only approachable roads are built which is made of concrete but still they are narrow in nature. In general, the people or communities who receive services are generally labelled as “beneficiaries”, but the consultation process helped how to make the community members as “partners” who has a number of roles to play on their parts to ensure the services and solutions sustainable. The community members also selected one female person from them as their leader and to make a bridge between community and the project partners.
6. Total safe water solutions: deployment of interventions at different scales
It was indicated earlier that the project aimed to provide a total solution that may give benefits to the people across the scale. The three scales where the interventions were implemented were as follows:
- safe water solution at household level;

- water availability at community scale; and

- solutions of drainage congestion or waterlogging at wider area scale.



Sections before indicated how people suffer from the challenges happening at different scales separately and also simultaneously. The problem conceptualization process, spatial assessment for contextualizing the problem, design of interventions for different scales, development of project deployment strategies from field-based learnings – all contributed in developing a total solution based on fusing of household-level technical solutions, social innovations and actions for community engagements towards sustainability. The three-stage actions for three scales are described in the sections below.
6.1 Technical solutions at household level
The household level technical solution include a domestic water purifier and safe storage device which is labelled as “AMRITADHARA - DWP”, developed by PRISM, under Safe Water Mission, is entrusted with WHO recommended Household Water treatment and Safe Storage – HWTS. This low-cost device (US$27) was distributed free of costs to all 87 households that was found to be easy to operate by the members of the household. It has the capacity to remove almost all kinds of physical, chemical and biological contaminants and can eliminate bad odour and colour from the water (Table 3). Before the installation of the device, it was comprehensively tested and proven to be effective in many different parts of India, Bangladesh and Vietnam. The device has the capacity to supply safe drinking water for years if properly maintained.
At community scale three large size water treatment plants were installed in the Mathpara (Ward 14 of Basirhat Municipality). The water purification capacity of each unit is 1,000 litres per day by which about 330 people or 60 families can get adequate drinking water (3 litres of water per person per day) from the facility. The facilities were installed in a school, Hindu temple and community place (market place) where hundreds of people meet every day.
6.2 Social innovations
The social innovation is an important pre-requisite for any interventions to serve and sustain in the long run, in community spheres. It is evident that many good technological innovations were introduced towards service improvements and to ensure social well-being but few were successfully remained in service mainly due to the absence of social innovation component in that. In this project, the members of the community were with the project implementation team (Figure 7).
It was indicated earlier (Section 5) that initiatives taken to read and understand the society deeply and created a negotiated space as to find the gateway for implementing the project interventions. The household level water purification units, the Amritadhara needs periodic management, replenish the filter with chemical substances and social processes helped to get the users involved into the process. Efforts given in social innovations also helped to receive necessary motivation of people about why little effort should be given for health and economic benefits by getting continuous supply of safe water for the family members of the household.
6.3 Community engagement and ownerships towards sustainability
The third intervention of the project was to mobilize community members in addressing local inundation and waterlogging crisis. In doing that consultation meetings were conducted with community people which informed them about the causes of waterlogging problem in the area such as:
- unplanned construction of buildings;

- blocking areas by some people for fishery development;

- dumping of garbage and waste materials into the drains that reduces the water drainage capacities of local drains and canals; and

- raising of river bed by sediment depositions and lowering the water conveyance capability of the river resulted in inundation of low-lying areas when river overflows during monsoon floods and cyclone induced water surge (Figures 2 and 8).



People also informed that occurrence of intense rainfall over a short period also cause waterlogging in the area. Satellite image-based maps were shown to them to make them understand the upper-lower connection of drainage. People also informed about social movements and raised the issues with local Panchayet, Block Development Officer and sub-Divisional officer and District Magistrate. But when the community members failed to convince the formal authorities, they developed their own action plans and engaged themselves in resuscitation of an old canal, removed the garbage that resulted in improved drainage conditions in the area according to elevation data from Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) (Figure 8).
7. Conclusion and way forward
The natural drainage system in the back swamp, low-lying areas of Basirhat Municipality is composed of canals, creeks which drain out excessive local waters and waters discharged from urban areas into the main river channels and thus urban areas remain flood free and peri-urban areas can sustain physically agile and unharmed. These water retention areas are supposed to be kept as city buffer zones for long-term sustainability of the city and to give a range of ecosystem services to the urban (also local) people. In this backdrop, an initiative was taken in the low-lying settlement areas of Basirhat Municipality of West Bengal, India to address water-related challenges at three scales such as household level, community-level and relatively broader water catchment levels. Household level solutions include supply of low cost, easy operable, sustainable water purifiers, community-level solution focussed on securing water-related challenges at social/public gathering places and wider catchment area level solutions include the engagement of local communities to drain out stagnant waters by clearing drains, creating/digging small canals through collective actions. Scientific methods such as geo-spatial techniques (topographical mapping, spatial survey, water quality tests) along with social methods such as participatory appraisals for gathering information on human health, public awareness campaigns and partnership development with local government agencies were the major activities performed as part of the implementation of interventions. It is imperative to mention that water-related challenges in the low-lying settlement areas of Basirhat Municipality have effectively been addressed by relying on necessary theoretical underpinnings (disaster risk reduction/humanitarian principles) transmitted through application of scientific techniques and mediated through local people and their agencies. However, the outcomes of the pilot interventions such as financial viability, capacity to supply safe and adequate water, social acceptance, community ownership and collective actions, co-creation of knowledge may suggest, with a strong degree of confidence, that the proposed solutions could be replicated in other areas, especially, at least, in other deltaic coastal settings. The water interventions provided at different scales (i.e. household, community, landscape level wider areas) gave local communities relief from waterlogging crisis and reduced health risks associated with unsafe water consumption. The research findings showed that addressing waterlogging crisis in peri-urban contexts needs total solutions irrespective of scales. In doing that in-depth assessment of both human dimensions and physical contexts of the problem is necessary to understand the impacts of one challenge happening in a certain scale on the challenges occurring in other scales. In this study, these issues were critically assessed by using different methods that results in identifying three scales where problem persist that finally helped to design water interventions for peri-urban areas of Basirhat municipality. The community members and the representatives of the local government, i.e. the Panchayet members mentioned that segmented solutions of water crisis will not water-related challenges in peri-urban settings.
The authors acknowledge the Basirhat Municipality Authorities, people of Bhabanipur Daspara of 14-number ward, SEEDS India, Asian Disaster Reduction and Response Network (ADRRN) and RedR UK for supporting us directly and indirectly.
Funding : The research was supported by Elrah, Under Humanitarian Innovation Fund program.

Table 2. The water induced crisis in Basirhat against the backdrop of geographical attributes
Regional geographical attributes (regional scale attributes) Influences of factors Impacts in Basirhat (impacts at local scale)
Slope conditions of the region (North to South direction) Intensity of currents in flood waters contributes in increasing water and sediment loads Flooding and inundation, sometimes flash floods causing degradation of water retention ponds
Water supply from large watershed areas Determines amount of water mass (intensity and magnitude of floods) and sediment load Lengthening flood durations, waterlogging happens in low lying areas of the city. Cause to contaminate groundwater
High lands in the upper region and low in the south Water discharge capacity increase, receives more monsoon rainfall-led water mass towards down-slopes May cause flash floods and cause damage of assets (tube wells, water supply infrastructure, etc.)
Sediment deposited soft topsoil Sediment loads, low water infiltration capacity of topsoil and generation of surface runoff Soils becomes saturated by water because of poor drainage conditions of the soil and generate surface runoff and cause floods quickly
Length of the river More water with more length of river Floods may engulf wider area (whole floodplain region)
Relative position of the location Closeness to the sea, geographical position (e.g. situating at the mouth of an estuary) Natures, types, intensity of hazards are determined such as cyclonic induced strong wind and water surge may cause the water issues worse. Basirhat is also under the threats of Sea level Rise due to its location

Digital Health Intervention Design and Deployment for Engaging Demographic Groups Likely to Be Affected by the Digital Divide: Protocol for a Systematic Scoping Review

Author: Jenkins, Catherine L1    ; Imran, Sumayyah2    ; Mahmood, Aamina2    ; Bradbury, Katherine3    ; Murray, Elizabeth2    ; Stevenson, Fiona2    ; Hamilton, Fiona L2    1 North East London Foundation Trust, Essex, United Kingdom2 eHealth Unit, Research Department of Primary Care & Population Health, University College London, London, United Kingdom3 School of Psychology, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom

Publication info: Jenkins, Catherine L; Imran, Sumayyah; Mahmood, Aamina; Bradbury, Katherine; Murray, Elizabeth; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/digital-health-intervention-design-deployment/docview/2640994294/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Digital health interventions refer to interventions designed to support health-related knowledge transfer and are delivered via digital technologies, such as mobile apps. Digital health interventions are a double-edged sword: they have the potential to reduce health inequalities, for example, by making treatments available remotely to rural populations underserved by health care facilities or by helping to overcome language barriers via in-app translation services; however, if not designed and deployed with care, digital health interventions also have the potential to increase health inequalities and exacerbate the effects of the digital divide. BACKGROUND Digital health interventions refer to interventions designed to support health-related knowledge transfer and are delivered via digital technologies, such as mobile apps. Digital health interventions are a double-edged sword: they have the potential to reduce health inequalities, for example, by making treatments available remotely to rural populations underserved by health care facilities or by helping to overcome language barriers via in-app translation services; however, if not designed and deployed with care, digital health interventions also have the potential to increase health inequalities and exacerbate the effects of the digital divide.The aim of this study is to review ways to mitigate the digital divide through digital health intervention design, deployment, and engagement mechanisms sensitive to the needs of digitally excluded populations. OBJECTIVE The aim of this study is to review ways to mitigate the digital divide through digital health intervention design, deployment, and engagement mechanisms sensitive to the needs of digitally excluded populations.This protocol outlines the procedure for a systematic scoping review that follows the methodology recommended by the PRISMA-ScR (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews) guidance. The following databases will be searched for primary research studies published in English from October 1, 2011, to October 1, 2021: Cochrane Library, Epistemonikos, NICE Evidence, PROSPERO, PubMed (with MEDLINE and Europe PMC), and Trip. In addition, the following sources of gray literature will be searched: Conference Proceedings Citation Index, Health Management Information Consortium, International HTA Database, OpenGrey, The Grey Literature Report, Google Scholar Basic Search UK, MedNar Deep Web Search Engine, and Carrot2. We will select publications that meet the following inclusion criteria: primary research papers that evaluated digital health interventions that describe features of digital health intervention design and deployment that enable or hinder access to and engagement with digital health interventions by adults from demographic groups likely to be affected by the digital divide (eg, older age, minority ethnic groups, lower income, and lower education level). A random selection of 25 publications identified from the search will be double screened by four reviewers. If there is >75% agreement for included/excluded publications, the team will continue to screen all the identified publications. For all included publications, study characteristics will be extracted by one author and checked for agreement by a second author, with any disagreements resolved by consensus among the study team. Consultation digital health intervention design and deployment, and digital health intervention users will also be conducted in parallel. METHODS This protocol outlines the procedure for a systematic scoping review that follows the methodology recommended by the PRISMA-ScR (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews) guidance. The following databases will be searched for primary research studies published in English from October 1, 2011, to October 1, 2021: Cochrane Library, Epistemonikos, NICE Evidence, PROSPERO, PubMed (with MEDLINE and Europe PMC), and Trip. In addition, the following sources of gray literature will be searched: Conference Proceedings Citation Index, Health Management Information Consortium, International HTA Database, OpenGrey, The Grey Literature Report, Google Scholar Basic Search UK, MedNar Deep Web Search Engine, and Carrot2. We will select publications that meet the following inclusion criteria: primary research papers that evaluated digital health interventions that describe features of digital health intervention design and deployment that enable or hinder access to and engagement with digital health interventions by adults from demographic groups likely to be affected by the digital divide (eg, older age, minority ethnic groups, lower income, and lower education level). A random selection of 25 publications identified from the search will be double screened by four reviewers. If there is >75% agreement for included/excluded publications, the team will continue to screen all the identified publications. For all included publications, study characteristics will be extracted by one author and checked for agreement by a second author, with any disagreements resolved by consensus among the study team. Consultation digital health intervention design and deployment, and digital health intervention users will also be conducted in parallel.The review is underway and is anticipated to be completed by September 2022. RESULTS The review is underway and is anticipated to be completed by September 2022.The results will have implications for researchers and policy makers using digital health interventions for health improvement peripandemic and post pandemic, and will inform best practices in the design and delivery of digital health interventions. CONCLUSIONS The results will have implications for researchers and policy makers using digital health interventions for health improvement peripandemic and post pandemic, and will inform best practices in the design and delivery of digital health interventions.PRR1-10.2196/32538. ____________________________________________________________

Digital Health Intervention Design and Deployment for Engaging Demographic Groups Likely to Be Affected by the Digital Divide: Protocol for a Systematic Scoping Review

Author: Jenkins, Catherine L    ; Sumayyah Imran    ; Aamina Mahmood    ; Bradbury, Katherine    ; Murray, Elizabeth    ; Stevenson, Fiona    ; Hamilton, Fiona L    

Publication info: Jenkins, Catherine L; Sumayyah Imran; Aamina Mahmood; Bradbury, Katherine; Murray, Elizabeth; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/digital-health-intervention-design-deployment/docview/2645680266/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: Digital health interventions refer to interventions designed to support health-related knowledge transfer and are delivered via digital technologies, such as mobile apps. Digital health interventions are a double-edged sword: they have the potential to reduce health inequalities, for example, by making treatments available remotely to rural populations underserved by health care facilities or by helping to overcome language barriers via in-app translation services; however, if not designed and deployed with care, digital health interventions also have the potential to increase health inequalities and exacerbate the effects of the digital divide. Objective: The aim of this study is to review ways to mitigate the digital divide through digital health intervention design, deployment, and engagement mechanisms sensitive to the needs of digitally excluded populations. Methods: This protocol outlines the procedure for a systematic scoping review that follows the methodology recommended by the PRISMA-ScR (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews) guidance. The following databases will be searched for primary research studies published in English from October 1, 2011, to October 1, 2021: Cochrane Library, Epistemonikos, NICE Evidence, PROSPERO, PubMed (with MEDLINE and Europe PMC), and Trip. In addition, the following sources of gray literature will be searched: Conference Proceedings Citation Index, Health Management Information Consortium, International HTA Database, OpenGrey, The Grey Literature Report, Google Scholar Basic Search UK, MedNar Deep Web Search Engine, and Carrot2. We will select publications that meet the following inclusion criteria: primary research papers that evaluated digital health interventions that describe features of digital health intervention design and deployment that enable or hinder access to and engagement with digital health interventions by adults from demographic groups likely to be affected by the digital divide (eg, older age, minority ethnic groups, lower income, and lower education level). A random selection of 25 publications identified from the search will be double screened by four reviewers. If there is >75% agreement for included/excluded publications, the team will continue to screen all the identified publications. For all included publications, study characteristics will be extracted by one author and checked for agreement by a second author, with any disagreements resolved by consensus among the study team. Consultation digital health intervention design and deployment, and digital health intervention users will also be conducted in parallel. Results: The review is underway and is anticipated to be completed by September 2022. Conclusions: The results will have implications for researchers and policy makers using digital health interventions for health improvement peripandemic and post pandemic, and will inform best practices in the design and delivery of digital health interventions. International Registered Report Identifier (IRRID): PRR1-10.2196/32538

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Catherine&amp;aulast=Jenkins&amp;atitle=Digital+Health+Intervention+Design+and+Deployment+for+Engaging+Demographic+Groups+Likely+to+Be+Affected+by+the+Digital+Divide%3A+Protocol+for+a+Systematic+Scoping+Review&amp;stitle=JMIR+Research+Protocols&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.2196%2F32538&amp;title=Digital+Health+Intervention+Design+and+Deployment+for+Engaging+Demographic+Groups+Likely+to+Be+Affected+by+the+Digital+Divide%3A+Protocol+for+a+Systematic+Scoping+Review&amp;volume=11&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2022&amp;spage=e32538&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Full text: Introduction
Background
The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated widespread adoption of digital health interventions internationally. This rapid shift to digital delivery has laid bare the impact of pre-existing and emerging systemic health inequalities on communities most in need of accessible health care, specifically people from ethnic minority backgrounds, people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, older people (aged ≥65), and people living with disabilities [1,2]. Belonging to one or more of these groups (intersectionality) is a risk factor for experiencing more severe illness and mortality [3]. These same groups are likely to make up a large proportion of people vulnerable to health inequalities regardless of initial illness severity [4].
Health inequalities have been defined as “the systematic, avoidable and unfair differences in health outcomes that can be observed between populations, between social groups within the same population or as a gradient across a population ranked by social position” [5], but the term is also used for differences in access to health care, quality of care received, wider determinants of health such as housing and education, and opportunities to lead healthy lives, including differences in risky behaviors such as smoking [6]. The related term “health inequity” implies a normative judgement about the fairness or otherwise of these differences, “expressing a moral commitment to social justice,” as described by Kawachi et al [7]. For this review, we use the term health inequalities.
The digital divide—the gap between populations able to benefit from access to and use of health information and services online and populations unable to take up such opportunities—is a clear example of health inequality and exacerbates the inverse care law [8] such that digitally delivered health care runs the risk of excluding the people who could most benefit. This review seeks to address issues of social justice in the digital delivery of health care by providing a comprehensive overview of the literature on strategies to reduce the digital divide through the design and deployment aspects of digital health interventions.
The Digital Divide and Digital Health Literacy
Health literacy and digital literacy are both key determinants of health [9]. The term digital health literacy (also referred to as eHealth literacy) brings both literacies together to describe the degree to which individuals can access, understand, and apply digitally delivered health information and services to make informed decisions about their health. Importantly, digital health literacy extends beyond personal responsibility to encompass the responsibility of digital health systems and services to support and dynamically respond to the digital health literacy skills, and the confidence and motivation to develop such skills, in the populations they serve [10].
Digital health literacy competence fluctuates depending on context, but a clear link has been demonstrated between low digital health literacy and poor health outcomes [11]. The accelerated shift to digital health care to comply with social distancing measures arising from COVID-19 heightens the risk of poor health outcomes in digitally excluded groups and further complicates an already complex interplay between intersectionality and digital health literacy as a distributed, or outsourced , concept. For example, many older people may have the financial capital to afford digitally enabled devices and data plans but not the skills, motivation, or confidence to engage directly with such technology; instead, they may be reliant on their networks—family members, friends—to navigate digital health care on their behalf [12,13].
Digital health intervention design and deployment therefore need to be proportionate and prioritize those groups most affected by low digital health literacy on both individual and systemic levels via a two-pronged approach: first, to develop patients’ skills in accessing, understanding, and using digital health information and services, and second, to develop the digital health literacy responsiveness of the systems and health care professionals (HCPs) supporting digital health intervention deployment in practice. This review will have wider implications for research into digital health interventions and will address:
- The digital divide: How should digital health interventions be designed and deployed to mitigate the digital divide (eg, patient access to WiFi-enabled digital devices or subsidized data plans, the inclusiveness of recruitment methods for studies evaluating digital health interventions, strategies to increase uptake and use of a digital health intervention app by people from demographic groups likely to be affected by the digital divide, or the content of onboarding scripts used by HCPs when introducing patients to a digitally delivered health service)?
- Digital health literacy: How can app design and digital skills training be optimized to reduce digital health inequalities arising from low digital health literacy (eg, integration of user testing into the design process, readability of app content, gamification/social features to engage users, or support for HCPs to train as “digital health champions” as part of improving their own skills)?

Rationale for Conducting a Systematic Scoping Review
The decision to conduct a systematic scoping review rather than a systematic review is informed by the purpose of scoping reviews, which is to provide a comprehensive picture of the available evidence to guide further research. This purpose is of relevance to the study of digital health interventions because digital health intervention design and deployment is frequently captured in gray literature (eg, charity reports).
This review will be conducted using methods outlined by the Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI) Reviewers’ Manual [14] and will conform to the PRISMA-ScR (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews) [15]. The protocol for this review is based on the JBI framework by Peters et al [16] with further process updates from Levac et al [17] and is structured as follows: identification of the review aims and search questions, selection of evidence sources, charting of data extracted from the evidence sources, reporting of results, and consultation with stakeholders (including HCPs, digital health experts, and digital health intervention users). Results from this review will support decision-making when designing and deploying digital health interventions.
Review Question
The purpose of this systematic scoping review is to identify research that reports on the design and deployment of digital health interventions to reduce the digital divide and increase digital health literacy at macro- (national policy), meso- (national program), and micro- (localized or individual) levels [18]. It aims to do this by discovering peer-reviewed qualitative, quantitative, and mixed methods research, and gray literature relevant to mapping the contextual and process factors that enable or hinder engagement with digital health services by people vulnerable to the digital divide and individual or systemic low digital health literacy.
This review will seek to answer the review question, “What features of digital health intervention design and deployment enable or hinder engagement with digital health interventions by people from demographic groups likely to be affected by the digital divide?”
Health interventions are increasingly delivered through digital platforms, and it is important that they do not exacerbate or create health inequalities. Our hypothesis is that existing knowledge in the literature can inform our objective to find ways to bridge the digital divide and improve digital health literacy in underserved groups, for example, through digital health intervention design, development, and deployment.
Figure 1 outlines how this review will be conducted.
Figure 1. Systematic scoping review flow diagram. DHI: digital health intervention.
Methods
We will follow the methods recommended by the PRISMA-ScR framework [15].
Protocol Registration
At the time of writing, scoping reviews are ineligible for registration in PROSPERO. For transparency and to enable the systematic scoping review method outlined here to be repurposed for onward research, a summary of the protocol and any supplementary material will be registered with the Open Science Framework [19] and assigned a Digital Object Identifier (DOI) for long-term retrieval.
Eligibility Criteria
We will include primary research studies reporting on the design or deployment of digital health interventions that meet the following inclusion criteria.
Population
Adults from different demographic groups (defined based on gender, age, ethnicity, income, and education) in high-income and low-income countries.
Intervention
Digital health interventions are defined as any service intended to improve physical or mental health, or to promote health improvement through, for example, lifestyle change delivered digitally (formally or informally), such as via smartphone apps, social media, email, SMS text message, using wearable technologies, video games (eg, for motor or cognitive training), websites, or telehealth (eg, remote consultations) but excluding telemedicine if this consists solely of remote monitoring without any input from the patient [15].
Comparator
There may or may not be a comparator, depending on the study design.
Outcome
The primary outcome of interest is the capacity to mitigate the digital divide and increase digital health literacy either through the digital health intervention itself or its deployment. Health impact is not considered an outcome of interest for this review.
- “Mitigate the digital divide” refers to removing barriers to digital inclusion, for example, an intervention that provides free smartphones or tablets, or low-cost cellular data or WiFi for people with low incomes [10].
- “Increase digital health literacy” refers to digital skills development [9], either through the design of the digital health intervention or through programs to deploy the digital health intervention, resulting in higher levels or use or confidence in using the digital health interventions, measured either by interview or self-report (eg, the eHealth Literacy Scale questionnaire [20] or use data). Changes in these outcome measures suggest that both users and the health professionals administering the digital health intervention are confident in the use of digital resources for safe and sustainable self-management and to promote safe and sustainable self-management.

For the purposes of this review, gray literature covers conference abstracts and proceedings, white papers, and stakeholder reports (eg, by charities with an interest in digital literacy or who promote the health and well-being of people from different demographic groups) that enhance the contextual understanding of the field.
There will be no limitation by geography because lessons from low-income countries could inform strategies to reduce digital health inequities in high-income countries. We will report and interpret data within the context of the country where the study was based.
Limitations will be placed on user population and on study date. The user population will prioritize the marginalized demographics previously outlined; the study date will be limited to post-2011 (for preprint or publication) in recognition of the rapid change of pace in digital health intervention development [21]. No limitations will be placed on the study design or publication status. However, we will limit included studies to those published in English.
Decisions on whether data should be included or excluded from further analysis will be guided by criteria that, in line with a systematic application of scoping review method [16], will be iteratively refined based on increasing familiarity with the literature under review.
The use of the term digital health intervention is a possible challenge as it covers a range of digital health technologies [22] and may contribute to an imbalance in this review that favors comprehensiveness over precision. This will be addressed by working closely with information specialists to peer review the preliminary search strategy in line with the PRESS (Peer Review of Electronic Search Strategies) procedure [23], ensuring a feasible and focused approach that is also flexible enough to be iteratively reworked in response to the results retrieved.
Evidence Sources
Reviews
A preliminary search for registered, preprint, or published systematic, scoping, and other review types will be conducted to pilot the search strategy, covering the following databases (via the Ovid interface, where applicable):
- Cochrane Library
- Epistemonikos
- NICE Evidence
- PROSPERO
- PubMed (with MEDLINE and Europe PMC)
- Trip

The preliminary search will provide keywords that can be incorporated into searches across evidence tiers below that of the gold standard represented by reviews. It will also serve to identify Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and PubMed IDs, which can be inserted into the Yale MeSH Analyzer [24] to extract further MeSH and to identify keywords to capture preprints not yet indexed with MeSH. A cap of 100 review articles will be applied in cases where unfeasible amounts of hits are retrieved.
Model papers for citation “ pearl-growing ”—papers already identified as highly relevant to this review—will be mined for their keywords and applied as test cases for honing the search strategy. Vernacular search terms will be identified from hand searching, including reference list scanning, forward/backward citation snowballing, and table of contents scanning of relevant journals online, such as the Journal of Medical Internet Research and its sister journals.
Further sources for other tiers of evidence include:
- Databases of peer-reviewed primary research (qualitative, quantitative, mixed methods studies):
* CINAHL
- EMBASE
- PsycINFO
- OTseeker
- PubMed

- Gray literature* Conference Proceedings Citation Index
- Health Management Information Consortium
- International HTA Database
- OpenGrey
- GreyNet
- The Grey Literature Report

The Grey Literature Report [25], available up to 2016, is a key source of gray literature that, unusually, is indexed using MeSH. It may be helpful in providing alternative MeSH to feed back into the search strand for peer-reviewed literature.
Alongside database searching, web searching will be conducted systematically, to the extent that this is feasible given that web searching is vulnerable to changing web content and algorithms [26]. Search terms will be used consistently between database and web searching and screen captures of content, and where available, DOIs will be saved for transparency. Web searching will also support the discovery of human-computer interaction (HCI) literature, which is not reliably indexed in MEDLINE. Searching the HCI literature will be helpful for the provision of further perspectives on design challenges (eg, designing for people with low vision or motor impairments).
Web Searching
The following databases will be used for the web searching: Google Scholar Basic Search UK, with use of the “Cited by” function (see Figure 2), for the first 100 results retrieved; MedNar Deep Web Search Engine, for the first 100 results retrieved; and Carrot2.
Targeted consultation with experts in digital health intervention design and deployment and digital health intervention users will also be conducted in parallel. This is part of the added value of scoping reviews. Ethics approval is not required for such consultation.
Figure 2. "Cited by" feature for forward citation snowballing in Google Scholar.
Search Strategy
The following search strategy was used for PubMed (November 2021): ((“digital health” OR “digital health intervention*” OR “DHI” OR “digital rehabilitation”) OR “eHealth” OR “mHealth” AND (app OR intervention OR technology) AND (barrier* OR design OR disparit* OR divi* OR engage* OR exclu* OR inequ*)) AND literacy.
This search strategy will be modified by incorporating MeSH and keywords used to index relevant papers and will inform the search strings for parallel searching in Google Scholar Advanced Search UK and MedNar.
Screening of identified literature will follow the recommendations of the JBI [16]. Of the studies and gray literature initially identified from the searches, 25 publications will be selected at random by dividing the total by four (the number of screeners), then selecting every nth paper (where n=the total divided by four) to assign for double-screening of titles, abstracts, or full-text by four reviewers; if there is greater than 75% agreement for included/excluded publications, then the team will continue to screen all of the identified publications. If agreement is 75% or less, we will hold a further training session to resolve differences in interpretation of the criteria and, if necessary, tighten the wording. Further rounds of double-screening and calculation of interrater agreement will continue until we meet concordance. For included publications, study characteristics will be extracted by one author and checked for agreement by a second author, and any uncertainty over data retrieved will be discussed and resolved via consensus with all contributing authors. Retrieval of a model paper [27] served as the test case for the search strategy.
PRISMA-ScR
The PRISMA-ScR framework will be used to transparently record the selection, deduplication, and screening decision process, supplemented by updated recommendations from Tricco et al [28]. Gray literature may not be searchable by abstract (due to a lack of abstract fields in the gray literature discovery interfaces), so the PRISMA-ScR flow diagram will be adapted to accommodate this. Critical appraisal, for example, of the underlying evidence informing the studies retrieved, is not generally operationalized in scoping reviews [16]. Instead, the focus of this review type is on providing as complete a picture as possible of what is currently known about the topic of interest.
Data Extraction and Charting
Data will be extracted from full-text sources relevant to the review question using the JBI data extraction guidance for scoping reviews [14]. If required, missing data will be requested from authors. Google Sheets [29] will be used to record the initial data extraction of all included sources. In accordance with the iterative approach taken by scoping reviews, the following headers will be trialed and refined as needed [30]:
- Reference
- Region and setting of digital health intervention design/deployment
- Study type (qualitative, quantitative, mixed methods, review)
- Funding source
- Stakeholder involvement
- Digital health intervention type
- Digital health intervention purpose
- User population
- Summary of results relevant to this review question

Collating, Summarizing, and Reporting Results
Unlike a systematic review—where evidence sources that do not meet the quality criteria applied are excluded—scoping reviews seek to present an overview of all material reviewed (including gray literature) [24]. We will summarize the results visually [30] to assist validation of the results by stakeholders (described in the following section) and later dissemination.
Consultation Exercise
In parallel with the aforementioned stages, consultation with stakeholders (eg, representatives from charities, experts in researching digital health interventions, and patients or members of the public) will be conducted to validate emerging results. Stakeholders will be identified both a priori (known to the authors) and iteratively as this review progresses (through their representation in relevant sources).
Results
This systematic scoping review is in progress. The final draft of this review will be submitted by September 2022. We expect to report a narrative summary of the findings of included peer-reviewed primary studies and gray literature that describe differences in the ability of people from different demographic groups or people with lower health literacy or digital health literacy to access and use digital health interventions, and any change in this following specific measures taken by the researchers to make digital health interventions more accessible and usable by people from these groups; and the results of qualitative studies that discuss barriers and facilitators to access and use digital health interventions by people from different demographic groups.
Discussion
This review will present a summary of evidence regarding strategies for optimizing the design and deployment of digital health interventions to mitigate the effects of the digital divide and low digital health literacy on populations disproportionately affected by health inequalities and the digital divide. Its results will inform the design and deployment of digital health interventions at a time when they are more used than ever before and will have wider implications for researchers and policy makers using digital health interventions for health improvement. For example, HCI strategies for developing content for websites and apps, such as use of personas with a range of demographic characteristics (including those of digitally excluded populations) [31,32] and use of video and audio to help people of low health literacy use digital health interventions [33].
In conclusion, this review is among the first to examine the design and deployment of digital health interventions specifically in the context of the challenges presented by the digital divide and low digital health literacy at individual and systemic levels. The results of this review will support researchers, digital health intervention developers, and HCPs in identifying what works to optimize digital health intervention design and deployment, with the aim of promoting social justice.

Authors' Contributions
FLH, KB, and EM conceived the initial idea for the review. CLJ developed the protocol, which was then revised and approved by all authors. CLJ, SI, AM, and FLH will conduct the search strategy, screening, extraction, and analysis. CLJ will write up the systematic scoping review paper with support and contribution from all authors.
Conflicts of Interest
None declared.

Key topicsPowered by Web of Science® Description for Powered by Web of Science: Digital divide; Public health intervention; Intervention; Social determinants of health; Digital health

Privacy preservation of cloud data in business application enabled by multi-objective red deer-bird swarm algorithm

Author: Balashunmugaraja, B1; Ganeshbabu, TR21 Computer Science and Engineering, SRI Venkateswara Institute of Science & Technology, India2 Electronics and Communication Engineering, Muthayammal Engineering College, India

Publication info: Balashunmugaraja, B; Ganeshbabu, TR. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/privacy-preservation-cloud-data-business/docview/2631678663/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Decision-making is one of the important deals in knowledge transfer and it can be useful for the multi-source domains. Meanwhile, the existing knowledge transfer schemes do not use privacy-preserving techniques for preserving security. This can be a problem for critical domains like financial market forecasting as the misuse of security can lead to legal and financial implications. In recent years, cloud services have revolutionized various technological applications. Cloud computing has become more popular with digital technologies as it provides uninterrupted services like transmission, storage, and intensive computing of data. The architecture of the cloud is also cost-efficient. Besides, various promising services from the cloud, some challenges need to be addressed to secure the privacy of the cloud users as millions of users access its services. Privacy preservation is an important aspect in the field of data mining, and the necessity of securing important data in the cloud from hackers is on the rise. Privacy-preserving data mining algorithms have been analyzed over recent years to provide sufficient solutions for securing the privacy of the data in the cloud. This paper plans to introduce a new hybrid meta-heuristic concept for developing a privacy preservation strategy towards business data under the cloud sector. The main objective of this paper is to design a new hybrid red deer-bird swarm algorithm (RD-BSA) to ensure higher convergence and since the use of control parameters over the solution generation is minimized. The proposed privacy preservation scheme on three financial databases is evaluated with the performance against the existing privacy preservation schemes. Different analyses like statistical, key sensitivity, Known-Plaintext Attack (KPA), and Chosen-Plaintext Attack (CPA) are used for evaluating the efficiency of the algorithm. The comparative analysis of the proposed model over the conventional models demonstrates its effective performance via diverse analysis.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=B&amp;aulast=Balashunmugaraja&amp;atitle=Privacy+preservation+of+cloud+data+in+business+application+enabled+by+multi-objective+red+deer-bird+swarm+algorithm&amp;stitle=Knowledge-Based+Systems&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.knosys.2021.107748&amp;title=Privacy+preservation+of+cloud+data+in+business+application+enabled+by+multi-objective+red+deer-bird+swarm+algorithm&amp;volume=236&amp;issue=&amp;date=2022&amp;spage=1&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=B&amp;aulast=Balashunmugaraja&amp;atitle=Privacy+preservation+of+cloud+data+in+business+application+enabled+by+multi-objective+red+deer-bird+swarm+algorithm&amp;stitle=Knowledge-Based+Systems&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.knosys.2021.107748&amp;title=Privacy+preservation+of+cloud+data+in+business+application+enabled+by+multi-objective+red+deer-bird+swarm+algorithm&amp;volume=236&amp;issue=&amp;date=2022&amp;spage=1&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Full text: Not available.
